Social_Relationship_and_Structures-house.feature: After the mid-19th century, France experienced a significant shift from rural to urban living, with remote and mountainous rural areas losing population while urban areas grew rapidly due to industrialization and modernization of agriculture.
Social_Relationship_and_Structures-house.original:
- Quoted text "Until about the mid-19th century, rural and urban populations both increased, but thereafter there was a marked depopulation of the more remote, mostly mountainous, rural areas and a swing to urban growth."
- Location p2===from https://www.britannica.com/place/France/Population-distribution

Social_Relationship_and_Structures-house.feature: As young people left rural areas for cities, especially during postwar agricultural modernization, rural regions were left with an older population and lower birth rates.
Social_Relationship_and_Structures-house.original:
- Quoted text "Postwar rural depopulation was associated with the exodus of labour following the modernization of French agriculture. At the time, rural areas were left with an aging population and low birth rates as the young departed to the cities..."
- Location p2===from https://www.britannica.com/place/France/Population-distribution

Social_Relationship_and_Structures-house.feature: The increase in urban population after World War II was fueled not only by migration from rural areas but also by immigration, particularly of young adults who contributed to higher city birth rates.
Social_Relationship_and_Structures-house.original:
- Quoted text "The massive postwar movement from rural areas to the cities was supplemented by immigration, which also focused on urban areas where employment was available. Because immigrants to the cities tended to be young adults of childbearing age, city dwellers multiplied."
- Location p3===from https://www.britannica.com/place/France/Population-distribution

Social_Relationship_and_Structures-house.feature: Starting around 1975, migration patterns changed due to economic shifts, with declining industrial regions losing population while southern, western, and southwestern coastal regions saw growth due to retirement migration, tourism, and decentralization.
Social_Relationship_and_Structures-house.original:
- Quoted text "From about 1975, migratory flows were greatly modified, the most immediate cause being economic... Growth subsequently switched to the south, to the coastlands of Languedoc and of Provence–Alpes–Côte d’Azur; to the west, in the Atlantic regions of Poitou-Charentes and Pays de la Loire; and to the southwest, in the Midi-Pyrénées and Aquitaine."
- Location p4===from https://www.britannica.com/place/France/Population-distribution

Social_Relationship_and_Structures-house.feature: Early suburban growth in France was driven by working-class and lower middle-class populations, but after World War II, suburbanization became increasingly dominated by middle-class residents moving into new low-density satellite developments.
Social_Relationship_and_Structures-house.original:
- Quoted text "In the first half of the 20th century, suburban growth, where it did occur, was not the result of middle-class suburbanization... It was the working class and the lower middle classes that moved out... In the postwar period, however, suburbanization took increasingly middle-class forms, with the building up of satellite low-density subdivisions known as 'new villages.'"
- Location p6===from https://www.britannica.com/place/France/Population-distribution

Social_Relationship_and_Structures-house.feature: Since the 1980s, population growth has concentrated in the outer suburbs of major cities like Paris and in small towns or rural communes on the expanding edges of urban regions.
Social_Relationship_and_Structures-house.original:
- Quoted text "Since the 1980s, population growth has been concentrated in the outer Paris suburbs (grande couronne)... Increasingly, the most rapid population growth is relegated to small towns and nominally rural communes on the expanding fringes of the city regions."
- Location p5 and p7===from https://www.britannica.com/place/France/Population-distribution

Social_Relationship_and_Structures-house.feature: Rural households in France tend to prioritize materialist values over post-materialist concerns like environmentalism due to lower income, education levels, and economic precarity, which shapes their social and political behavior.
Social_Relationship_and_Structures-house.original:
- Quoted text "Lower educational attainment and declining socioeconomic status lead to a prioritization of materialist values over post-materialist concerns, such as environmentalism, which is often seen as an “urban” value by French country dwellers."  
- Location p4===from https://blogs.ed.ac.uk/political_behaviour/2025/06/19/reducing-the-political-divide-between-urban-and-rural-voters-the-case-of-france/

Social_Relationship_and_Structures-house.feature: Rural populations in France are generally older and less educated than urban populations, contributing to differences in social integration and political engagement.
Social_Relationship_and_Structures-house.original:
- Quoted text "Rural populations in France are, on average, poorer, older, and less educated than their urban counterparts."  
- Location p3===from https://blogs.ed.ac.uk/political_behaviour/2025/06/19/reducing-the-political-divide-between-urban-and-rural-voters-the-case-of-france/

Social_Relationship_and_Structures-house.feature: Declining employment opportunities in rural areas result in weaker social integration, which is linked to lower political participation among rural residents.
Social_Relationship_and_Structures-house.original:
- Quoted text "Additionally, social precarity, characterized by declining employment opportunities, results in weaker social integration, which correlates with lower political participation."  
- Location p4===from https://blogs.ed.ac.uk/political_behaviour/2025/06/19/reducing-the-political-divide-between-urban-and-rural-voters-the-case-of-france/

Social_Relationship_and_Structures-house.feature: There is a growing divide between urban and rural areas in terms of employment opportunities, income levels, and access to high-end industries, with cities concentrating well-paid jobs while suburban and rural populations face declining prospects.
Social_Relationship_and_Structures-house.original:
- Quoted text "Behind the 'revolution' is an expanding rift between urban and rural areas. When a vast majority of highly-paid jobs are based in cities, a gradual difference in education, income and employment opportunities has begun to show between people living in urban areas and those in suburbs and rural areas."
- Location p5===from https://www.globaltimes.cn/page/201812/1133656.shtml

Social_Relationship_and_Structures-house.feature: High-end industries such as finance, technology, and insurance are primarily located in urban centers, contributing to the marginalization of manufacturing-dependent populations who mostly reside in suburbs or rural regions.
Social_Relationship_and_Structures-house.original:
- Quoted text "Because high-end industries like finance, technology and insurance are dominating urban areas, people who lived on manufacture are sliding to the bottom of society. Most of them live in suburbs or rural areas and are involved in relatively low-end work."
- Location p6===from https://www.globaltimes.cn/page/201812/1133656.shtml

Social_Relationship_and_Structures-house.feature: Workers from suburban and rural areas are increasingly displaced from manufacturing jobs and often forced into insecure service-sector roles, often remaining in suburban areas even when employed.
Social_Relationship_and_Structures-house.original:
- Quoted text "Most can only live in the suburbs even if they find a way to live on service work."
- Location p8===from https://www.globaltimes.cn/page/201812/1133656.shtml

Social_Relationship_and_Structures-house.feature: The application of artificial intelligence is exacerbating the income gap between urban and rural populations, as technological advancements displace manufacturing workers and shift new job creation toward urban service industries.
Social_Relationship_and_Structures-house.original:
- Quoted text "The application of AI has been further widening the income gap between people living in cities and the countryside."
- Location p7===from https://www.globaltimes.cn/page/201812/1133656.shtml

Social_Relationship_and_Structures-house.feature: Rural and urban areas in France are becoming increasingly interconnected, with blurred boundaries due to shared spaces among agriculture, residential zones, and natural environments.
Social_Relationship_and_Structures-house.original:
- Quoted text "One major aspect of the future of ruralities resides in the increasingly intricated relationships between rural and urban areas."  
  - Location p2===from https://www.inrae.fr/en/news/new-ruralities-france

Social_Relationship_and_Structures-house.feature: Agricultural land is no longer separate from residential development, as farming increasingly coexists with housing and natural spaces in rural areas.
Social_Relationship_and_Structures-house.original:
- Quoted text "More and more, agriculture is sharing space with residential zones and natural environments."  
  - Location p2===from https://www.inrae.fr/en/news/new-ruralities-france

Social_Relationship_and_Structures-gende.feature: Certain abstract concepts, particularly those related to sciences, disciplines, and abstract ideas like liberty or tenderness, are frequently assigned feminine gender in French, possibly due to linguistic heritage from Latin.
Social_Relationship_and_Structures-gende.original:
- Quoted text "Abstract ideas are frequently feminine (la liberté, la joie), possibly due to Latin roots."  
- Location paragraph 4===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/8/1/understanding-french-gender-logic-behind-the-chaos

Social_Relationship_and_Structures-gende.feature: The feminine grammatical gender in French is perceived as carrying a linguistic "cadence" that aligns with meanings associated with softness and tenderness, reflecting how the language conceptualizes such qualities.
Social_Relationship_and_Structures-gende.original:
- Quoted text "You’ll start noticing how la douceur (softness) and la tendresse (tenderness) have a feminine cadence that matches their meaning..."  
- Location paragraph 8===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/8/1/understanding-french-gender-logic-behind-the-chaos

Social_Relationship_and_Structures-gende.feature: In French, when a group includes at least one male member, the masculine form of the adjective must be used for the entire group, regardless of the number of female members.
Social_Relationship_and_Structures-gende.original:
- Quoted text "Le masculine l’emporte sur le feminin, which means 'masculine trumps feminine.' This refers to the use of the masculine form of an adjective when referring to a group, in which at least one member is male."  
- Location p6===from https://thetalkingticket.blog/2025/04/21/7-things-you-didnt-know-about-gender-in-french/

Social_Relationship_and_Structures-gende.feature: The rule that masculine overrides feminine in agreement was introduced in the 17th century and replaced the earlier "rule of proximity," which allowed adjectives to agree with the nearest noun.
Social_Relationship_and_Structures-gende.original:
- Quoted text "Historian and linguist Eliane Viennot explains that the rule was invented in the 17th century, and replaced 'the rule of proximity', which previously allowed agreement between an adjective or past participle and the closest noun to that agreeable word."  
- Location p7===from https://thetalkingticket.blog/2025/04/21/7-things-you-didnt-know-about-gender-in-french/

Social_Relationship_and_Structures-gende.feature: Even after the Académie Française approved the feminisation of job titles in 2019, some female politicians still faced resistance when requesting to be addressed using feminised forms like “Madame LA Ministre.”
Social_Relationship_and_Structures-gende.original:
- Quoted text "Until L’Academie Française voted in favour of the feminisation of jobs in 2019, many female politicians continued to request that their male counterparts refer to them as 'Madame LA Ministre', sometimes to no avail."  
- Location p8===from https://thetalkingticket.blog/2025/04/21/7-things-you-didnt-know-about-gender-in-french/

Social_Relationship_and_Structures-gende.feature: Using the feminine form of a profession may imply exclusivity to women, so the masculine form is sometimes retained to indicate a woman's superiority among all professionals, regardless of gender.
Social_Relationship_and_Structures-gende.original:
- Quoted text "If one says elle est l’écrivaine la plus titrée de France, rather than using the masculine form écrivain, then the implication is that she is the most successful female author in France. We’d need to use the masculine écrivain to make clear that she is the most successful writer out of all authors."  
- Location p8===from https://thetalkingticket.blog/2025/04/21/7-things-you-didnt-know-about-gender-in-french/

Social_Relationship_and_Structures-gende.feature: Inclusive writing promotes using gendered forms of job titles that match the individual’s gender, such as using “une charpentière” or “une autrice” for women.
Social_Relationship_and_Structures-gende.original:
- Quoted text "Words relating to rank, job or title should agree with the gender of the person they refer to e.g. une charpentière, une autrice, un homme de ménage."  
- Location p10===from https://thetalkingticket.blog/2025/04/21/7-things-you-didnt-know-about-gender-in-french/

Social_Relationship_and_Structures-gende.feature: Inclusive writing suggests replacing the traditional dominance of the masculine form by either following the rule of proximity or prioritizing the gender of the majority in group descriptions.
Social_Relationship_and_Structures-gende.original:
- Quoted text "Instead of the principle of le masculin l’importe sur le féminin (masculine trumps feminine), either follow the rule of proximity or prioritise the noun that represents the majority when it comes to adjectives e.g. les décorateurs et les décoratrices sont satisfaites OR les décorateurs et la décoratrice sont satisfaits."  
- Location p10===from https://thetalkingticket.blog/2025/04/21/7-things-you-didnt-know-about-gender-in-french/

Social_Relationship_and_Structures-gende.feature: Inclusive writing uses a midpoint symbol (•) to combine masculine and feminine forms of nouns, such as in “les citoyen•ne•s,” to represent both genders equally.
Social_Relationship_and_Structures-gende.original:
- Quoted text "Condense two genders with a mid-point e.g. les citoyen•ne•s"  
- Location p10===from https://thetalkingticket.blog/2025/04/21/7-things-you-didnt-know-about-gender-in-french/

Social_Relationship_and_Structures-gende.feature: Adding a feminine grammatical ending to a traditionally masculine place name is used as a symbolic act to promote gender equality and raise awareness about gender inequality.
Social_Relationship_and_Structures-gende.original:
- Quoted text "The change is meant as a show of support for the women in society and as a way to raise awareness about ongoing gender inequality."  
- Location paragraph 5===from https://www.themayor.eu/en/a/view/french-town-changes-its-name-to-honour-gender-equality-11366

Social_Relationship_and_Structures-gende.feature: Local government actions, such as modifying a town's name, are used to publicly acknowledge systemic gender disparities, including wage gaps, occupational restrictions, and societal resistance to women’s presence in public spaces.
Social_Relationship_and_Structures-gende.original:
- Quoted text "Women are still paid less for their work than men, certain occupations are forbidden to them, and their place in the public space is not always well received by men."  
- Location paragraph 6===from https://www.themayor.eu/en/a/view/french-town-changes-its-name-to-honour-gender-equality-11366

Social_Relationship_and_Structures-gende.feature: The renaming initiative also serves as a form of protest against violence toward women, using symbolic municipal action to convey a broader social message.
Social_Relationship_and_Structures-gende.original:
- Quoted text "The mayor also wants to criticize not only the existing inequality between men and women but also the violence against women by changing the name."  
- Location paragraph 7===from https://www.themayor.eu/en/a/view/french-town-changes-its-name-to-honour-gender-equality-11366

Social_Relationship_and_Structures-gende.feature: The gender-inclusive name change is purely symbolic and not implemented in official administrative or geographic systems, such as street signs or postal addresses, due to procedural constraints.
Social_Relationship_and_Structures-gende.original:
- Quoted text "Nevertheless, it was also explained that the name change will be a symbolic gesture and won’t be reflected in the signs at the entrance of the city. Nor will there be an official change of postal address, as this would require going through many administrative procedures."  
- Location paragraph 8===from https://www.themayor.eu/en/a/view/french-town-changes-its-name-to-honour-gender-equality-11366

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Zero-p.feature: In French date formatting, numbers may be written with or without leading zeros.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Zero-p.original:
- Quoted text "numbers may be written with or without leading zero."
- Location paragraph 1===from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Date_and_time_notation_in_France

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Zero-p.feature: In France, days and months with numbers less than 10 must always be written with a leading zero in the date format.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Zero-p.original:
- Quoted text "Also, in the U.S., sometimes we’ll drop the zero for months and days under 10 and shorten the year (9/27/23) but in French, months and days smaller than 10 are always written with the 0. So it’s 27/09/2023."
- Location p2===from https://www.ouiinfrance.com/how-do-french-write-dates/

Geography_and_Customs-Population_and_Geo.feature: As of 2025, France has an estimated total population of about 68.6 million.
Geography_and_Customs-Population_and_Geo.original:
- Quoted text "As of 2025, the total population in France was estimated about 68.6 million."
- Location paragraph 4===from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/French_people

Geography_and_Customs-Population_and_Geo.feature: Metropolitan France has fluctuated in its population rank among European countries over time, being the most populous until the 19th century, then dropping to fifth by 1933, recovering to fourth in 1991, and projected to potentially surpass Germany again by 2050–2060.
Geography_and_Customs-Population_and_Geo.original:
- Quoted text "Until 1795 metropolitan France was the most populous country of Europe, ahead of Russia... Between 1933 and 1991, metropolitan France was the fifth most populous country of Europe... In 1991, metropolitan France recovered its rank as the fourth most populous country of Europe... around 2050 metropolitan France could again surpass the population of Germany..."
  - Location paragraph 2===from 
            https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Demographics_of_France

Geography_and_Customs-Population_and_Geo.feature: France's total land area, including overseas departments and territories (excluding Adélie Land), accounts for 0.45% of the total land area on Earth.
Geography_and_Customs-Population_and_Geo.original:
- Quoted text "France's total land area, with its overseas departments and territories (excluding Adélie Land), is 643,801 km2 (248,573 sq mi),[84] 0.45% of the total land area on Earth."
- Location p1===from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/France

Geography_and_Customs-Population_and_Geo.feature: The text does not provide any information about the percentage of land area in France or any related geographic proportions.
Geography_and_Customs-Population_and_Geo.original:
- Quoted text "..."
- Location none

> Note After reviewing all paragraphs, no statement in the provided text specifies a percentage or proportional value regarding France's land area. Therefore, no cultural rule can be extracted for this dimension based on the given requirements.===from https://www.britannica.com/place/France

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: When entering a shop in France, visitors should immediately greet the shopkeeper with eye contact and a spoken "Bonjour Madame" or "Bonjour Monsieur" before being acknowledged, as failing to do so is considered rude.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "As you walk into a boulangerie, patisserie, small boutique, pharmacy, or shop, you should always acknowledge the shopkeeper with eye contact and a spoken Bonjour Madame (women) or Bonjour Monsieur (men). Do this immediately before entering the store, and don’t wait for them to greet you."  
- Location p6===from https://www.wandererscompass.com/9-things-to-know-about-french-culture-before-you-visit/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: When leaving a shop, it is culturally expected to say goodbye using phrases such as "Au revoir," "Merci beaucoup," or "Bonne journée" as a sign of respect.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "As you depart, you can also throw in one or all of the following Aurevoir, Merci Beaucoup, Bonne Journee. (Goodbye, Thank you, and Have a good day.) It shows respect and is the norm culturally."  
- Location p6===from https://www.wandererscompass.com/9-things-to-know-about-french-culture-before-you-visit/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: Upon entering a restaurant, guests should make eye contact and greet the host/hostess, and continue to greet servers and staff who approach the table during the meal.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "Always make eye contact and greet the Host/Hostess upon entering. Once seated, greet your server and anyone else that comes to your table."  
- Location p7===from https://www.wandererscompass.com/9-things-to-know-about-french-culture-before-you-visit/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: Meals in France are meant to be slow and relaxing, often lasting several hours, with long breaks between courses due to food being freshly prepared.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "The average meal lasts hours." and "Meals, once ordered, come with long breaks between courses. Most French cuisine is made fresh and to be served hot."  
- Location p8, p8===from https://www.wandererscompass.com/9-things-to-know-about-french-culture-before-you-visit/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: The check is not brought automatically at the end of a meal; guests must explicitly request it by saying “L’addition s’il vous plaît,” as delivering it unasked is considered insulting.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "If you wait for the check to be delivered at the end of the meal, you are in for a very long wait. It is considered insulting to the guest to bring it without them asking."  
- Location p8===from https://www.wandererscompass.com/9-things-to-know-about-french-culture-before-you-visit/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: Asking for a doggie bag is frowned upon in traditional French dining settings because it may imply disrespect toward the chef’s effort to serve a fresh, properly portioned meal.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "It is frowned upon to ask for a doggie bag; it is considered disrespectful. The servings are rarely large and are prepared fresh at their peak."  
- Location p8===from https://www.wandererscompass.com/9-things-to-know-about-french-culture-before-you-visit/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: It is considered impolite to keep hands in the lap during meals; both hands should be visible on the table throughout the meal.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "Keeping your hands in your lap during a meal is not considered polite. Hands should be visible with both hands on the table."  
- Location p15===from https://www.wandererscompass.com/9-things-to-know-about-french-culture-before-you-visit/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: Shoppers should not touch produce in markets or merchandise in shops, as this is seen as inappropriate and may result in negative reactions from vendors.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "You might be tempted to touch the produce but DO NOT. That is the vendor’s job." and "At times, touching merchandise gets you snapped at or brings you nasty looks."  
- Location p11, p11===from https://www.wandererscompass.com/9-things-to-know-about-french-culture-before-you-visit/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: Many shops in France close for long lunch breaks (e.g., 12–2 pm), are closed on Sundays, and may shut down entirely during summer vacations, reflecting a cultural emphasis on work-life balance.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "Most shops and services are not open overnight or on Sundays. Life and work balance is taken seriously in France. Many shops still close for a long lunch from 12-200 pm." and "In the summer, especially in August, many restaurants and shops close for weeks at a time for an extended vacation."  
- Location p12, p12===from https://www.wandererscompass.com/9-things-to-know-about-french-culture-before-you-visit/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: Guests invited to a French home should bring a gift such as flowers, macaroons, chocolate, or champagne, but should avoid bringing wine since the host typically selects wine to pair with the meal.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "You must always come bearing a gift. Please DO NOT make it wine. Your host pairs the wine based on the menu."  
- Location p13===from https://www.wandererscompass.com/9-things-to-know-about-french-culture-before-you-visit/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: It is common and culturally accepted for well-behaved dogs to accompany their owners in restaurants, including upscale establishments, where they are provided water bowls and resting spaces.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "We had dinner at several upscale restaurants on a visit to Colmar, France. It wasn’t until the middle of our meal that we realized we had two tables near us, each with a dog. The dogs were given water bowls and something to lay on."  
- Location p14===from https://www.wandererscompass.com/9-things-to-know-about-french-culture-before-you-visit/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: Wearing sweatpants or workout attire in public is uncommon in France unless one is actively working out, as gym clothes are typically reserved for the gym or workout session.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "Wearing sweatpants or workout attire out and about (when not working out)... Gym clothes are generally reserved for the actual gym or workout session."
- Location paragraph 7===from https://www.ouiinfrance.com/strange-tourist-behavior-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: After a workout, it is common practice in France for people to shower and change into street clothes before leaving the gym, even if going straight home.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "Most of my fellow gym-goers would actually shower and get dressed in street clothes before leaving the gym, even if they were going straight home after."
- Location paragraph 7 (P.S.)===from https://www.ouiinfrance.com/strange-tourist-behavior-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: In France, mealtimes are observed more strictly than in the U.S., with dinner typically served between 7 p.m. and 10 p.m.; eating dinner before 7 p.m. is considered unusual.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "Being seated outside those times is less common. If you invite people over for a dinner party, 730 or 8 p.m. would be the norm and anything earlier would be a bit unusual."
- Location paragraph 13===from https://www.ouiinfrance.com/strange-tourist-behavior-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: Eating on the go is not a common daily habit in France; mealtime is generally treated as a dedicated activity rather than something done while walking or multitasking.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "Eating a sandwich while walking down the street, on the metro, or at your desk while multitasking is done but isn’t most people’s everyday norm."
- Location paragraph 1===from https://www.ouiinfrance.com/strange-tourist-behavior-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.feature: In France, it is customary for guests to arrive 15 to 20 minutes late for dinner parties as a way to avoid surprising the host during preparations, although punctuality is expected for restaurant reservations.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Daily life a.original:
- Quoted text "While in many countries this is considered rude, in France it’s an unspoken rule. Guests will always arrive a little late – lest they surprise their host in the middle of the preparations. Of course, this only applies to dinner parties and you should be punctual for restaurant reservations."  
- Location paragraph 2===from https://www.trafalgar.com/real-word/french-customs-and-traditions/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: In France, only biomedically-qualified professionals (such as doctors, dentists, midwives, and nurses) are legally allowed to diagnose or treat patients; all other forms of healing practiced by non-qualified individuals are formally considered illegal.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "Since 1804, and with various adjustments over the years, the law makes it illegal for anyone who is not a qualified medical practitioner to ‘treat or diagnose’."
- Location pIV.A===from https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC6181209/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: Non-biomedical healing systems, such as naturopathy, Traditional Chinese Medicine, and acupuncture, are considered illegitimate by the French state unless delivered by biomedically-trained professionals, thereby subordinating alternative practices to biomedical authority.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "In effect, this means the delivery of most alternative therapies, such as folk herbalism, Traditional Chinese Medicine, naturopathy, or acupuncture are formally illegal where practiced by non-doctors."
- Location pIV.A===from https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC6181209/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: The French state explicitly rejects terms like “complementary,” “alternative,” or “medicines” when referring to non-biomedical therapies because it views biomedicine as self-sufficient and considers alternatives to scientific rationale as dangerous.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "The state has explicitly rejected the label of ‘complementary’ (as biomedicine, it argues, does not need complementing), the label of ‘alternative’ (as an alternative to scientific rationale is deemed dangerous to the health system), or indeed of ‘medicines’, as ‘medicine’, it argues, is only biomedicine."
- Location pI===from https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC6181209/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: Doctors and pharmacists who are biomedically qualified are legally permitted to practice and sell alternative therapies (e.g., homeopathy, acupuncture, phytotherapy), making such practices legitimate only when embedded within conventional medical settings.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "It is relatively common, for example, for some doctors to provide acupuncture or homeopathy to patients... When practiced or prescribed by a doctor, treatment will also be partially refunded by the social security system."
- Location pIV.D.2===from https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC6181209/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: Only licensed pharmacists can legally sell medicinal plants or products; others are prohibited from selling or advising on such items if they imply therapeutic benefits, reinforcing state control over access to traditional remedies.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "Only qualified pharmacists can sell medicinal plants in raw form, or medicinal products based on plants... Anyone who provides advice on those plants without being a qualified pharmacist... could be guilty of exercice illégal de la pharmacie."
- Location pIV.B===from https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC6181209/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: Despite legal prohibitions, alternative healers operate openly and are easily accessible in France, indicating widespread societal acceptance and informal tolerance of these practices even though they exist in a precarious legal space.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "Despite the legal framework suggesting that only doctors should treat patients, alternative healers are as easy to find in France as elsewhere... Patients will have no problem locating them online, in the yellow pages... or indeed by walking through the streets."
- Location pV.A===from https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC6181209/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: During epidemics, religious practices in France shift from everyday observance to more intense, crisis-driven forms involving prophecies, superstitions, and heightened religious engagement.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "la religion du temps de peste ne pouvait être la religion de tous les jours"
  - Location p4===from https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/09639489.2020.1784860

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: In French cultural thought, personal health is prioritized over spiritual salvation, reflecting a secular approach where medical care takes precedence in matters of well-being.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "Le salut de l’homme est un trop grand mot pour moi. Je ne vais pas si loin. C’est sa santé qui m’intéresse, sa santé d’abord"
  - Location p2===from https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/09639489.2020.1784860

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: Despite ideological opposition between religion and medicine, individuals in French culture may passively accept medical treatment while maintaining religious faith, showing an ambiguous and complex integration of both systems.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "Il s’abandonna comme une chose à tous les traitements qu’on lui imposa, mais il ne lâcha plus le crucifix"
  - Location p4===from https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/09639489.2020.1784860

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: Until the mid-19th century in France, nursing was primarily carried out by nuns whose work was associated more with Christian charity than with a formal profession.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "Jusqu’à la moitié du XIXe siècle, les infirmières étaient toutes des religieuses et exerceraient une tâche plus associée à la charité chrétienne qu’à un véritable métier."
  - Location p5===from https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/09639489.2020.1784860

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: After the formal separation of hospital care from spiritual concerns in 1878, the surgeon in French literature came to be symbolically invested with sacred qualities, reflecting a transfer of reverence from religious to medical figures.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "while from 1878, the ‘laïcisation des hôpitaux’ leads to a formal separation of corporeal suffering from the suffering of the soul, the hospital is reconceived as a space in which the surgeon, robed in white, is imbued with sacred qualities."
  - Location p6===from https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/09639489.2020.1784860

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: In France, traditional and modern medicine are viewed as distinct systems, with "official medicine" (biomedicine) being legally dominant, while alternative practices—referred to as médecines parallèles, médecines douces, or la médecine libre—exist outside formal regulation and are often associated with natural, non-invasive, and holistic approaches.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "The more common term at least since the 1960s has been les medecines paralleles. It is a close equivalent to alternative medicine, except that the plural suggests multiple divergences from a unitary core... Sympathizers, however, are more likely to refer to les medecines douces... thought to be friendly to the body in the way that les technologies douces are friendly to the environment."
  - Location p287

- Rule Description Alternative medical practices in France, particularly those labeled médecines douces or naturelles, emphasize non-technological, noninvasive, and natural healing methods, positioning themselves as aligned with bodily and environmental harmony.
- ===from https://www.cambridge.org/core/services/aop-cambridge-core/content/view/F9A890EC86E184863AAEA1CB56BCAC2F/S0025727300065376a.pdf/alternative-medicine-in-modern-france.pdf

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.feature: Only biomedically trained professionals, such as medical doctors, midwives, dentists, and nurses, are legally allowed to diagnose or treat patients; all other forms of healing by non-qualified practitioners are formally illegal.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Diet and Hea.original:
- Quoted text "Since 1804, and with various adjustments over the years, the law makes it illegal for anyone who is not a qualified medical practitioner to ‘treat or diagnose’."
  - Location paragraph pIV.A

- Rule Description Alternative therapies may be practiced legally only when delivered by biomedically qualified professionals, allowing doctors and other licensed healthcare providers to incorporate practices like acupuncture or homeopathy into their services.

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Education an.feature: In French schools, students are required to learn at least two foreign languages, with the first typically being German or English.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Education an.original:
- Quoted text "In French schools, pupils are expected to learn at least two foreign languages, the first of which is typically German or English."  
- Location p3===from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Culture_of_France

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Education an.feature: Students can choose French as either a primary major or combine it with another major, reflecting flexibility in academic path selection.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Education an.original:
- Quoted text "French can be taken either as a primary major or as one of two majors, in consultation with the director of undergraduate studies."
- Location p2===from https://french.yale.edu/academics/undergraduate-program/major-french

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Education an.feature: Combining French with other humanities and social science fields is supported and exemplified through suggested complementary majors.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Education an.original:
- Quoted text "Appropriate majors to combine with French might include, but are not limited to, African American Studies, African Studies, English, Film and Media Studies, Global Affairs, History, History of Art, Humanities, Literature, Music, Philosophy, Political Science, Theater Studies, and Women’s, Gender, and Sexuality Studies."
- Location p2===from https://french.yale.edu/academics/undergraduate-program/major-french

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Education an.feature: French and Italian majors are required to study key historical periods (Medieval, Renaissance, Romantic, Modern), but otherwise have significant freedom to explore personal academic interests within the scope of French or Italian-related topics.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Education an.original:
- Quoted text "The major does have some structure in that you are required to cover the major historical divisions of your area of study—i.e. courses in the Medieval, Renaissance, Romantic, and Modern periods of France or Italy respectively—but beyond that you are allowed to explore your own interests."
- Location p2===from https://fit.princeton.edu/undergraduate/major/major-choices

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Education an.feature: The study of French and Italian combines language instruction with cultural education from introductory to advanced levels, providing students with both linguistic proficiency and cultural understanding.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Education an.original:
- Quoted text "Even in lower-level courses, the answer is 'both.' From the first 101 course through upper level literature classes, professors combine guidance in the written and spoken language as well as cultural matters."
- Location p3===from https://fit.princeton.edu/undergraduate/major/major-choices

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Education an.feature: Studying French and Italian enables students to understand foreign cultures deeply, allowing them to interpret literature, art, and ideas from the perspective of the creators and view the world through multiple cultural lenses.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Education an.original:
- Quoted text "By studying French and Italian, you are able to learn what authors really mean when they use certain words, descriptions, or turns of phrase. It is as if you are seeing the world through a new pair of eyes, a pair of eyes that has experienced a new life and can see things from many different points of view."
- Location p4===from https://fit.princeton.edu/undergraduate/major/major-choices

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Education an.feature: Students are encouraged to combine French and Italian studies with courses in other humanities disciplines such as art history, history, political science, sociology, and comparative literature.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Education an.original:
- Quoted text "Students are also encouraged to complement their courses in French and/or Italian with related and varied courses in other literatures, in art history, history, political science, sociology, comparative literature, or other humanities subjects."
- Location p1===from https://fit.princeton.edu/undergraduate/major/major-choices

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: When invited to eat at a family's home in France, it is expected that you make an effort to finish all the food on your plate, as leaving food may be interpreted as a sign that the food was not good or that you are wasting a gift.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "If invited by a familly, you should do your best to eat all what you have accepted in your plate. For two reasons. 1) it is like saying to your host that the food wasn’t good, 2) it is a waste, and food should not be wasted, people worked to get it and gave it to you as a gift."  
- Location p1===from https://www.quora.com/Is-it-rude-to-not-finish-your-food-in-France

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In a restaurant setting in France, there is no expectation to finish all the food on your plate, and individuals are free to leave food without offense.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "In a restaurant, do whatever you want."  
- Location p2===from https://www.quora.com/Is-it-rude-to-not-finish-your-food-in-France

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It is generally considered impolite to leave food on one's plate, especially when dining in someone’s home, as it shows a lack of appreciation for the effort put into preparing each course.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "It is generally frowned upon to leave food on a plate, particularly when in someone’s home. Each course of a meal tends to take time to make. Thus, one shows appreciation for the efforts of the person cooking through the enjoyment and completion of the meal."
- Location p14===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-etiquette

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It is no longer considered improper to take leftovers home in France, except possibly in high-end restaurants, as it was previously seen as a faux pas but has become more acceptable.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "It used to be a faux pas, not anymore (unless it’s a high end restaurant)."
- Location p7===from https://www.facebook.com/groups/RickStevesEurope/posts/1102078407174448/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French law requires restaurants to allow customers to take leftovers home, reflecting a legal stance against food waste.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "It’s been the law in France for years that they have to let you take leftovers home."
- Location p2===from https://www.facebook.com/groups/RickStevesEurope/posts/1102078407174448/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Due to smaller portion sizes in France compared to the US, diners often do not have leftovers after meals.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Doubt you’ll have leftovers because portions not big like in the states"
- Location p6===from https://www.facebook.com/groups/RickStevesEurope/posts/1102078407174448/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It is common and appreciated to give positive comments about the meal, especially if the host prepared it, as a way to show appreciation.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "In France, it's quite common to comment on the meal during dinner, and this is usually done in a positive way. If you find the dish delicious, don't hesitate to express it (especially if you know your host made it themselves)! This shows that you really appreciate what the host has prepared."  
- Location paragraph 57===from https://www.novexpat.com/french-culture/french-etiquette-and-table-manners

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Negative comments about the meal should be avoided during dinner unless one is very close to the host and can offer constructive feedback in an appropriate manner.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "However, it's best to avoid negative comments during the meal unless you're very close to the host and feel comfortable offering constructive feedback."  
- Location paragraph 57===from https://www.novexpat.com/french-culture/french-etiquette-and-table-manners

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: During formal or high-society dinners, it is better to remain discreet and refrain from commenting on the meal, even positively.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "During more formal or high-society dinners, it's better to remain a bit more discreet and avoid commenting on the meal."  
- Location paragraph 57===from https://www.novexpat.com/french-culture/french-etiquette-and-table-manners

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Compliments about food should be specific and sincere, avoiding exaggerated praise which may be seen as insincere.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Compliments are specific and sincere. Criticism, if necessary, is polite and measured."  
- Location p14  

- Rule Description Overly enthusiastic or exaggerated praise for food is viewed with skepticism and can appear insincere in French dining culture.  
- ===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/8/18/how-the-french-talk-about-food-expressions-rituals-and-respect

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In France, it is appropriate to give compliments to the chef after a meal, and one common way to do so is by saying "Mes compliments au chef" ("My compliments to the chef").
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Mes compliments au chef. (“My compliments to the chef.” )"
  - Location paragraph 16===from https://www.frenchpod101.com/blog/2020/05/28/the-best-compliments-in-french/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French people tend to be sparing with their compliments in general, including during meals, and when they do offer praise, it is typically sincere and not exaggerated.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The French are known to be sparing with their compliments, but they usually mean every single word when they do give one."
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://www.frenchpod101.com/blog/2020/05/28/the-best-compliments-in-french/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Offering a simple compliment is appropriate when praising the meal, but excessive praise should be avoided.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Do not shower the chef with compliments – a simple compliment will meet the taste of the chef."

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It is appropriate and encouraged to compliment the food during or after a meal in French dining culture.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Compliment the food 'C’était excellent'"

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: There is no strict rule requiring the use of the right hand for eating in France; instead, eating with hands is generally acceptable depending on the type of food and context.

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The acceptability of eating with hands depends on the setting, with casual venues like McDonald's being more permissive than upscale restaurants.

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Do not drop in unannounced on business partners; visits should only occur if expected, and even then, one must knock and wait to be invited in.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The French appreciate privacy. Do not 'drop in' on your potential business partners. If they are expecting you, knock on the door and wait for them to let you in."

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Managers should implement an open-door policy that allows team members to schedule one-on-one meetings to discuss issues or suggestions, fostering trust and openness in the work environment.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Implement an open-door policy where team members can schedule one-on-one meetings with you to discuss any issues or suggestions they may have. This approach fosters trust and openness, which are key to a collaborative work environment."

Social_Relationship_and_Structures-gende.feature: French men often offer unsolicited assistance to women, such as opening doors or helping with coats, which is interpreted as a cultural expression of galanterie (chivalry).
Social_Relationship_and_Structures-gende.original:
- Quoted text "French men are often quick to leap to a lady’s aid, whether it’s opening a door or helping her with her coat. Very importantly, this unsolicited (and sometimes surprising) assistance should be interpreted as an example of French galanterie."  
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://www.trafalgar.com/real-word/french-customs-and-traditions/

Social_Relationship_and_Structures-gende.feature: French business culture emphasizes a strong hierarchical structure where authority is respected, and decision-making is centralized among senior management.
Social_Relationship_and_Structures-gende.original:
- Quoted text "French business culture is characterised by a strong hierarchical structure and a meticulous approach to precision in business, reflecting a deep appreciation of order and authority within organisations."
  - Location paragraph 2

---===from https://www.business-solutions-atlantic-france.com/news/dos-and-donts-mastering-business-etiquette-in-france/

Social_Relationship_and_Structures-gende.feature: Subordinates are expected to refrain from interrupting managers during meetings, and communication follows formal protocols that reinforce hierarchical relationships.
Social_Relationship_and_Structures-gende.original:
- Quoted text "During meetings, it is unusual for subordinates to interrupt their managers, and decisions are expected to be discussed privately before being presented to the group."
  - Location paragraph 3

---===from https://www.business-solutions-atlantic-france.com/news/dos-and-donts-mastering-business-etiquette-in-france/

Social_Relationship_and_Structures-gende.feature: Final decisions in French companies are typically made by senior management, reflecting a top-down approach that underscores male-dominated leadership norms.
Social_Relationship_and_Structures-gende.original:
- Quoted text "In most French companies, roles and responsibilities are clearly defined... final decisions are often in the hands of senior management."
  - Location paragraph 3

---===from https://www.business-solutions-atlantic-france.com/news/dos-and-donts-mastering-business-etiquette-in-france/

Social_Relationship_and_Structures-gende.feature: French managers, particularly in traditional settings, expect their directives to be followed without question or justification, reinforcing authoritative and dominant leadership styles often associated with male dominance.
Social_Relationship_and_Structures-gende.original:
- Quoted text "French managers tend to place high importance on authority and expect their directives to be followed without the need for justification."
  - Location paragraph 7

---===from https://www.business-solutions-atlantic-france.com/news/dos-and-donts-mastering-business-etiquette-in-france/

Social_Relationship_and_Structures-gende.feature: The use of formal language (e.g., “vous”) and professional titles persists until explicitly invited to use first names, maintaining social distance and reinforcing hierarchical and potentially gendered power dynamics.

  - Location paragraph 3===from https://www.business-solutions-atlantic-france.com/news/dos-and-donts-mastering-business-etiquette-in-france/

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-co.feature: It is considered proper etiquette to keep a napkin on one’s lap throughout the meal in most dining situations, as a sign of good manners.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-co.original:
- Quoted text "It’s considered good manners to eat with your napkin on your lap in many places, but the French take this more seriously than most."  
  - Location p4===from https://frenchtogether.com/blog/french-table-manners

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-co.feature: Diners can use the placement of their fork, knife, and menu to silently signal their status (e.g., finished eating or taking a break) to restaurant staff, which is seen as a polite alternative to calling out.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-co.original:
- Quoted text "In a restaurant, you can use your menu and silverware to silently and thus politely communicate with your server."  
  - Location p6===from https://frenchtogether.com/blog/french-table-manners

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-co.feature: In France, participating in protests is seen as a civic duty not only to oppose government policies but also to demonstrate to fellow citizens—especially younger generations—that questioning official decisions is legitimate and necessary for societal change.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-co.original:
- Quoted text "The protest is not only to show the government that you disagree, but to show your fellow citizens – even the smallest ones – that official policies can and should be disagreed with. To provoke a change. To disrupt easy assumptions. You show yourself. You toss in your chips. You walk."  
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://europrospects.eu/the-french-strike-again-and-again-an-overview-of-french-collectivism/

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-co.feature: When one group faces a threat to their social benefits, other sectors often join the strike in solidarity, reflecting a cultural norm of collective defense beyond personal or sector-specific interests.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-co.original:
- Quoted text "railway workers protesting a new government measure that stripped them of the right to early retirement were joined by postal workers, schoolteachers, and many others."  
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://europrospects.eu/the-french-strike-again-and-again-an-overview-of-french-collectivism/

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-co.feature: French cultural identity takes precedence over religious, social, or political identities in public life, reinforced by secularism (laïcité), which promotes collective values over fragmented individual or group interests.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-co.original:
- Quoted text "French identity has arguably become prioritized before most other forms of identification, whether that be social, religious, or political identities."  
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://europrospects.eu/the-french-strike-again-and-again-an-overview-of-french-collectivism/

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-co.feature: The principle of "fraternity" supports collective activism by encouraging citizens to work toward the public interest rather than seeking recognition for isolated identity groups, thus preserving national unity.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-co.original:
- Quoted text "The bond of citizenship would be eroded if society were fragmented into a collection of identity groups seeking recognition rather than work[ing] towards the public interest."  
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://europrospects.eu/the-french-strike-again-and-again-an-overview-of-french-collectivism/

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-co.feature: Strikes in France are conducted with an understanding of “orderly disorder,” where disruption of public services is accepted as long as it follows clear organizational structures, advance notice, and maintenance of essential services.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-co.original:
- Quoted text "general strikes are called with the intention of disrupting public life mass transportation is shut down, schools are closed, mail service is suspended, and so on. But such actions are carried out within a well-defined frame."  
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://europrospects.eu/the-french-strike-again-and-again-an-overview-of-french-collectivism/

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-co.feature: French unions achieve success by maximizing the number of participants in strikes, making replacement of strikers difficult and increasing pressure on the government to mediate in favor of labor.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-co.original:
- Quoted text "French unions won strikes by increasing the number of strikers. This tactic made it harder for employers to replace strikers; it also encouraged government mediation, which in France was usually favorable to labor."  
  - Location paragraph 9===from https://europrospects.eu/the-french-strike-again-and-again-an-overview-of-french-collectivism/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-modes.feature: In France, dressing in chic and tailored outfits is expected as a sign of respect for oneself and others, especially in cities like Paris; casual clothing such as sweats or yoga pants should be avoided to blend in with local style norms.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-modes.original:
- Quoted text "Ditch the sweats and yoga pants, and opt for more chic and tailored outfits. The French view fashion as an expression of respect for both oneself and others, and a polished appearance is expected in most settings, from formal parties to everyday errands."
  - Location paragraph 18===from https://www.trafalgar.com/real-word/french-customs-and-traditions/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-modes.feature: Presenting oneself in clean, tasteful, and polished clothing is valued in France, as it reflects respect for oneself and others; overly casual or sloppy attire should be avoided, especially in formal or cultural settings.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-modes.original:
- Quoted text "The French often associate clean, tasteful dressing with respect – for oneself and for others."
  - Location paragraph 13===from https://welcome.fr/en/top-10-cultural-etiquette-tips-for-visitors-to-france/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-modes.feature: Shorts, sandals, athletic gear, and sports sneakers are considered inappropriate in nicer restaurants or cultural sites like churches; visitors should opt for neat and stylish clothing in such contexts.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-modes.original:
- Quoted text "Avoid overly casual or sloppy outfits – especially if you plan to enter nicer restaurants or visit cultural sites like churches."
  - Location paragraph 14===from https://welcome.fr/en/top-10-cultural-etiquette-tips-for-visitors-to-france/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-modes.feature: Athletic wear is generally acceptable only for actual sports activities; fashion-forward yet comfortable clothing such as well-fitting jeans, loafers, and scarves are preferred for daily wear.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-modes.original:
- Quoted text "Wearing athletic gear or sports sneakers is generally acceptable only for actual athletic activities, though fashion sneakers are growing in popularity."
  - Location paragraph 16===from https://welcome.fr/en/top-10-cultural-etiquette-tips-for-visitors-to-france/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-modes.feature: The French prioritize dressing well and with care, even for simple daily tasks like running errands, as a sign of self-respect rather than for vanity or to impress others.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-modes.original:
- Quoted text "Getting dressed well is seen as a mark of self-respect."
  - Location paragraph 13===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/5/7/10-everyday-french-habits-that-will-change-your-routine

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-modes.feature: The French typically avoid wearing pajama pants or gym wear in public, even for casual outings, reflecting a cultural preference for modest and put-together attire.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-modes.original:
- Quoted text "Even for a trip to the corner store, you’ll rarely see someone in pajama pants or gym wear."
  - Location paragraph 13===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/5/7/10-everyday-french-habits-that-will-change-your-routine

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-modes.feature: While not explicitly about "modesty," dressing well and maintaining a sophisticated appearance is important in French business meetings, including attention to personal grooming and accessories.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-modes.original:
- Quoted text "If you’re attending a face-to-face meeting with French counterparts, then be aware that appearances are important."
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://commisceo-global.com/articles/the-business-of-meetings-in-french-culture/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-modes.feature: In French business culture, individuals are expected to dress well and pay attention to personal effects such as briefcases, handbags, notebooks, and pens to make a strong professional impression.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-modes.original:
- Quoted text "In French culture, people tend to place value on good grooming and dressing well. This level of sophistication also extends to personal effects, such as briefcases, handbags, notebooks and pens."
  - Location paragraph 7

Note The text emphasizes "dressing well" and sophistication rather than modesty per se, but within the context of French cultural expectations for business settings, this constitutes the relevant cultural rule related to dress. No mention of religious, conservative, or body-covering aspects of modest dress is present.===from https://commisceo-global.com/articles/the-business-of-meetings-in-french-culture/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-modes.feature: In French business environments, individuals are expected to wear conservative and formal attire, with men wearing suits and ties and women opting for professional outfits such as skirt suits, pantsuits, or blouses with slim pants and a jacket.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-modes.original:
- Quoted text "Business settings require conservative attire. Formal attire should be adhered to even if it’s Friday. Men should wear a suit and tie. During winter, dark suits are the norm. Don’t loosen your tie, and don’t take off your jacket in an office. Women’s business attire can be a skirt suit, pantsuit, or a blouse with slim pants and a jacket."
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://excellentetiquette.com/business-etiquette-in-france/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-modes.feature: Jewelry and makeup are acceptable for women in professional settings, but they should avoid flashy or extravagant styles to maintain a modest appearance.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-modes.original:
- Quoted text "Makeup and jewelry are acceptable, but avoid flashiness."
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://excellentetiquette.com/business-etiquette-in-france/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-modes.feature: In less formal environments such as startups or social settings, dress codes are more relaxed, allowing informal clothing like sneakers and khakis.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-modes.original:
- Quoted text "Startups and social settings have a relaxed dress code. Informal attire like sneakers and khakis are acceptable."
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://excellentetiquette.com/business-etiquette-in-france/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-modes.feature: Women are expected to dress modestly during religious occasions as a sign of respect for religious traditions, with garments like the coiffe serving this purpose.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-modes.original:
- Quoted text "For women, modesty was key, and garments such as the coiffe were worn to signify respect for religious traditions."  
  - Location paragraph 3 (Cultural and Religious Significance of Traditional Clothing)===from https://www.outfiten.com/traditional-clothing-in-france/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-modes.feature: Women’s clothing during important events such as weddings or baptisms is designed with decorum and modesty, reflecting cultural expectations for formal behavior.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-modes.original:
- Quoted text "Similarly, women’s dresses and shawls were often designed with a sense of decorum, particularly for important events such as weddings or baptisms."  
  - Location paragraph 3 (Cultural and Religious Significance of Traditional Clothing)===from https://www.outfiten.com/traditional-clothing-in-france/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-educa.feature: The French education system is highly centralized, with the Ministry of National Education playing a dominant role in setting curriculum standards and educational policies, reflecting a historical tradition of centralized governance.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-educa.original:
- Quoted text "This centralization of education has persisted over the years, with the Ministry of National Education playing a dominant role in setting curriculum standards and educational policies."
  - Location p2===from https://www.tesolcourse.com/ia/cultural-influences-on-the-french-education-system/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-educa.feature: The French education system places strong emphasis on academic excellence, rigorous standards, and a structured curriculum as core cultural values.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-educa.original:
- Quoted text "The French education system is renowned for its emphasis on academic excellence, rigorous standards, and structured curriculum."
  - Location p1===from https://www.tesolcourse.com/ia/cultural-influences-on-the-french-education-system/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-educa.feature: French culture deeply respects intellectualism, with education emphasizing critical thinking, analysis, and debate as key components of learning.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-educa.original:
- Quoted text "France has a deep-rooted respect for intellectualism, with a strong emphasis on critical thinking, analysis, and debate."
  - Location p3===from https://www.tesolcourse.com/ia/cultural-influences-on-the-french-education-system/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-educa.feature: The French education system integrates arts, literature, and philosophy into the curriculum alongside traditional academic subjects to promote cultural enrichment and intellectual development.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-educa.original:
- Quoted text "Moreover, the French hold a high regard for the arts, literature, and philosophy, which are integrated into the curriculum alongside traditional academic subjects."
  - Location p3===from https://www.tesolcourse.com/ia/cultural-influences-on-the-french-education-system/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-educa.feature: In French classrooms, teachers are seen as authority figures responsible for transmitting knowledge, and direct instruction is prioritized in teaching methods.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-educa.original:
- Quoted text "French classrooms typically prioritize direct instruction, with teachers playing a central role in imparting knowledge and guiding student learning. This traditional approach is rooted in the belief that educators are authority figures responsible for transmitting information to students."
  - Location p4===from https://www.tesolcourse.com/ia/cultural-influences-on-the-french-education-system/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-educa.feature: The curriculum in France is structured around a core set of subjects including French language and literature, mathematics, history, geography, and sciences, aiming to develop well-rounded individuals.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-educa.original:
- Quoted text "Additionally, the curriculum in France is structured around a core set of subjects, including French language and literature, mathematics, history, geography, and the sciences."
  - Location p4===from https://www.tesolcourse.com/ia/cultural-influences-on-the-french-education-system/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-educa.feature: The French education system emphasizes higher education, with many students pursuing post-secondary studies at prestigious universities and grandes écoles.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-educa.original:
- Quoted text "Furthermore, the French education system places a premium on higher education, with a significant percentage of students pursuing post-secondary studies at prestigious universities and grandes écoles."
  - Location p5===from https://www.tesolcourse.com/ia/cultural-influences-on-the-french-education-system/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-educa.feature: French schools abroad must comply with the curriculum, educational objectives, and fundamental principles of the French education system, ensured through official approval by the Ministry of National Education and Youth.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-educa.original:
- Quoted text "Their compliance with the curriculum, educational objectives and fundamental principles of the French education system is ensured by its official approval, issued by the Ministry of National Education and Youth."  
  - Location p3===from https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/en/french-foreign-policy/francophony-and-the-french-language/france-s-commitment-to-the-french-language/learning-and-teaching-french/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-educa.feature: France supports bilingual education in foreign school systems where French is taught alongside other subjects such as science, history, math, and geography, aiming to increase the presence of French in international education systems.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-educa.original:
- Quoted text "Bilingual education includes one or several other subjects in addition to the French language, such as science, history, math and geography."  
  - Location p5===from https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/en/french-foreign-policy/francophony-and-the-french-language/france-s-commitment-to-the-french-language/learning-and-teaching-french/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-educa.feature: The LabelFrancÉducation is awarded to exceptional bilingual programs that provide enhanced French instruction and teach at least one non-language subject in French, aligned with local curricula.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-educa.original:
- Quoted text "LabelFrancÉducation, created in 2012, is granted by the Ministry for Europe and Foreign Affairs to outstanding bilingual programmes offering reinforced teaching of French and at least one non-language subject in French, in accordance with the local official curriculum."  
  - Location p6===from https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/en/french-foreign-policy/francophony-and-the-french-language/france-s-commitment-to-the-french-language/learning-and-teaching-french/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-educa.feature: French language certifications like DELF and DALF are internationally recognized, valid for life, and widely administered worldwide, serving as official qualifications for language proficiency.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-educa.original:
- Quoted text "Some of their certifications are equivalent to official degrees. This is the case with degrees in French language studies (DELF) and advanced French language degrees (DALF) which are both awarded by the Ministry of National Education, Youth and Sport and valid for life."  
  - Location p8===from https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/en/french-foreign-policy/francophony-and-the-french-language/france-s-commitment-to-the-french-language/learning-and-teaching-french/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-educa.feature: French vocational degrees (DFP) certify the ability to use French in professional contexts such as business, tourism, and hospitality, with levels ranging from beginner to advanced.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-educa.original:
- Quoted text "French vocational degrees (DFP) were designed and developed by Chamber of Commerce and Industry of Paris île-de-France and recognize the ability to work in French. They recognize the command of French in business, international relations, tourism, hospitality, with levels ranging from A1 (beginner) to C1 (advanced)."  
  - Location p9===from https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/en/french-foreign-policy/francophony-and-the-french-language/france-s-commitment-to-the-french-language/learning-and-teaching-french/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-educa.feature: Instituts Français promote the French language globally through language education, teacher training platforms, and support for higher education in France via Campus France.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-educa.original:
- Quoted text "Instituts Français contribute to promoting and spreading the use of the French language abroad and supports the cultural cooperation and action network by proposing French language education..."  
  - Location p10===from https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/en/french-foreign-policy/francophony-and-the-french-language/france-s-commitment-to-the-french-language/learning-and-teaching-french/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-educa.feature: Alliances Françaises operate in 131 countries and are key partners in spreading the French language and promoting cultural exchanges, welcoming over 500,000 students annually.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-educa.original:
- Quoted text "The 832 Alliances Françaises, whose network complements that of Instituts Français, are working in 131 countries and are important partners when it comes to disseminating our language. They welcome more than 500,000 students a year and also help to promote French culture and cultural exchanges."  
  - Location p11===from https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/en/french-foreign-policy/francophony-and-the-french-language/france-s-commitment-to-the-french-language/learning-and-teaching-french/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-dirty.feature: The French often use vulgar or euphemistic expressions as alternatives to literal or polite language, particularly in informal contexts.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-dirty.original:
- Quoted text "Travelers to France beware! These expressions are not for the faint-hearted and are provided here so you can know if you’re accidentally saying the wrong thing, or if you’re being talked to inappropriately."
  - Location p1===from https://matadornetwork.com/life/17-dirtiest-french-expressions-not-use/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-dirty.feature: Certain French expressions involving sexual or bodily references are considered inappropriate for sensitive audiences and should be used cautiously to avoid offense.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-dirty.original:
- Quoted text "These expressions are not for the faint-hearted and are provided here so you can know if you’re accidentally saying the wrong thing, or if you’re being talked to inappropriately."
  - Location p1===from https://matadornetwork.com/life/17-dirtiest-french-expressions-not-use/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-polit.feature: The French engage in open and frank discussions about politics, including during social gatherings like long lunches and dinner parties, and view such debates as intellectually acceptable and common.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-polit.original:
- Quoted text "While foreigners may shy away from discussing politics, money or religion, the French love frank, intellectual debates – and nothing is off the agenda."  
  - Location paragraph 13===from https://www.trafalgar.com/real-word/french-customs-and-traditions/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-polit.feature: In France, political criticism is culturally expressed through organized, large-scale public protests and strikes rather than through private dissent or individualized critique, with such actions being seen as legitimate and constructive forms of civic engagement.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-polit.original:
- Quoted text "The protest is not only to show the government that you disagree, but to show your fellow citizens – even the smallest ones – that official policies can and should be disagreed with. To provoke a change. To disrupt easy assumptions. You show yourself. You toss in your chips. You walk."
  - Location paragraph 2

--- 

No other characteristics related to “political criticism” are explicitly stated in the text. The discussion centers on protest as a form of political expression, not on verbal, media-based, or institutional criticism of political figures or ideologies outside the context of collective action.===from https://europrospects.eu/the-french-strike-again-and-again-an-overview-of-french-collectivism/
