- Quoted text "Saying 'hello' before asking for something is considered a basic rule. Failing to respect this rule is perceived as impolite. For example, not greeting a salesperson before making a request is seen as rude."  
  - Location paragraph 8===from https://cultures.fr/en/post/articles/the-cultural-example-that-characterizes-french-society

Social_Relationship_and_Structures-gende.feature: The use of formal language ("vous") is required when speaking to strangers, superiors, or in formal settings, reflecting adherence to social structure and expectations.
Social_Relationship_and_Structures-gende.original:
- Quoted text "The formal address is used to speak to a stranger, a superior, or in a formal setting. This linguistic subtlety reflects the French social structure and gives a meaning to relationships."  
  - Location paragraph 9===from https://cultures.fr/en/post/articles/the-cultural-example-that-characterizes-french-society

Social_Relationship_and_Structures-gende.feature: Individuals are expected to show deference to authority figures and respect hierarchical positions in both social and professional contexts.
Social_Relationship_and_Structures-gende.original:
- Quoted text "This hierarchy is decisive in interpersonal and professional relationships, structuring interactions and valuing respect for social positions."  
  - Location paragraph 13===from https://cultures.fr/en/post/articles/the-cultural-example-that-characterizes-french-society

Social_Relationship_and_Structures-gende.feature: Discussing personal finances, such as salary, or displaying wealth openly is socially discouraged and considered impolite.
Social_Relationship_and_Structures-gende.original:
- Quoted text "It is generally considered impolite to ask someone about their salary or to openly discuss one’s own remuneration. Similarly, outward signs of wealth are not well perceived."  
  - Location paragraph 15===from https://cultures.fr/en/post/articles/the-cultural-example-that-characterizes-french-society

Social_Relationship_and_Structures-gende.feature: There is growing support for gender-inclusive language reforms in France, particularly among women and non-binary individuals, who are more likely to use inclusive writing practices such as abbreviated or full gendered pairs (e.g., using both masculine and feminine forms) on digital platforms.
Social_Relationship_and_Structures-gende.original:
- Quoted text "A very recent quantitative study on the matter shows that while people rarely use double constraints (called “abbreviated pairs and full pairs”, meaning with either complete words of including truncations with typographic items like parenthesis, hyphens, slashes, etc.) on Twitter, Reddit, and YouTube, those using it are more often women or non-binary people (Flesch & de Beaumont, 2023 72 & 75)."  
  - Location paragraph 18  

- Rule Description Younger female students show increasing interest in inclusive writing forms, including new gender expressions like the pronoun iel, and are shifting away from traditional pseudo-generic masculine phrasing in favor of gender-neutral or inclusive alternatives.  
- ===from https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-031-91231-3_6

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-po.feature: French organizations prefer a hierarchical structure, where employees depend heavily on leaders for constant direction and guidance.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-po.original:
- Quoted text "France has a power distance score of 68, which is high and indicates a preference of hierarchical structure within an organization (Hofstede Insights, n.d.). Employees have a high level of dependency on their leaders for constant direction..."
  - Location p2===from https://sites.psu.edu/global/2020/04/20/french-contradiction-of-scores-in-power-distance-and-individualism/

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-po.feature: French managers express concern about losing control over employees when working remotely, reflecting the challenges of maintaining authority in decentralized work settings.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-po.original:
- Quoted text "Micromanaging employees from a distance is a cause for great concern and is stressed as fear of 'losing control over their employees' (Forbes France, 2019)."
  - Location p2===from https://sites.psu.edu/global/2020/04/20/french-contradiction-of-scores-in-power-distance-and-individualism/

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-po.feature: The text does not provide any specific cultural rules or characteristics related to France’s Power Distance index.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-po.original:
None

(Note While the text defines the Power Distance Index (PDI) in general terms, it does not link this dimension to France with any specific description, value, or behavioral rule. Therefore, no extractable cultural rules about France's power distance are present.)===from http://www.internationalbusinesscenter.org/geert-hofstede/hofstede_france.shtml

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-po.feature: France has a relatively high power distance, indicating that there is an acceptance of unequal power distribution between superiors and subordinates in organizations and institutions.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-po.original:
- Quoted text "France 68"
  - Location p3

(Note The number "68" listed under the PDI column for France in the table indicates its score on the Power Distance Index. According to the scale provided in the text, scores from 61–80 fall into the category of higher power distance, implying societal acceptance of unequal power distribution.)===from https://clearlycultural.com/geert-hofstede-cultural-dimensions/power-distance-index/

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.feature: In French culture, individualism is defined as the pursuit of one’s own material interests and pleasure, often summarized by the slogan "Everyone for themselves," which contrasts with altruism and solidarity.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.original:
- Quoted text "Individualism is a completely different attitude, which involves always seeking what maximises one’s own pleasure or material interest. The slogan of the individualist would be 'Everyone for themselves'."
  - Location paragraph 14===from https://link.springer.com/article/10.1057/s41253-020-00139-1

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.feature: Individualistic attitudes in France are opposed to altruism and weaken social relationships, as egoistic individuals prioritize self-interest over concern for others.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.original:
- Quoted text "In contrast, the utilitarian and egoistic individualist is opposed to altruism and solidarity."
  - Location paragraph 14===from https://link.springer.com/article/10.1057/s41253-020-00139-1

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.feature: Individualistic people in France tend to be disengaged from public life, showing little interest in politics and lower levels of political participation.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.original:
- Quoted text "One can hypothesise that a large number of individualists are depoliticised or at least not very interested in current events."
  - Location paragraph 20===from https://link.springer.com/article/10.1057/s41253-020-00139-1

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.feature: Individualism in France is associated with materialistic values, where individuals prioritize economic interests and security over qualitative or social goals.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.original:
- Quoted text "Individualistic people are rather materialistic, putting their own personal interests ahead of any other consideration."
  - Location paragraph 18===from https://link.springer.com/article/10.1057/s41253-020-00139-1

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.feature: French individualism is defined in relation to social coexistence, suggesting that individuality is understood within the context of societal interaction.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.original:
- Quoted text "These films open up a discussion of the way French culture defines individuality and its relationship to social coexistence."  
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://handbook.monash.edu/2020/units/ATS3249

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.feature: The cultural development of French individualism has historical roots in the monarchical court society of the 17th century, which established cultural parameters influencing later Republican national culture.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.original:
- Quoted text "Written texts (literary, philosophical, critical) are used to explore the historical roots of contemporary French culture in the court society of monarchy, notably in the 17th century as it established the cultural parameters within which French individualism developed and later shaped the creation of a Republican national culture."  
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://handbook.monash.edu/2020/units/ATS3249

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.feature: Personal transformation and self-liberation must precede societal change; individuals must first revolutionize their own lives before broader social emancipation can occur.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.original:
- Quoted text "Ce qui importe pour qu’une révolution soit durable, c’est qu’elle soit d’abord intérieure … Nos socialistes, voir nos anarchistes, sont pour la plupart, tournés vers le dehors et demeurent moralement des hommes peu supérieurs à la moyenne."  
  - Location paragraph 166===from https://www.thetedkarchive.com/library/carl-tobias-frayne-individualist-anarchism-in-france-and-its-legacy

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.feature: The individual, not class identity or economic status, is the central unit of revolutionary action; all people regardless of social position are potential agents of change.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.original:
- Quoted text "‘Les classes économiques ne nous intéressent que fort peu … une seule chose nous importe, c’est la valeur intrinsèque de l’individu’."  
  - Location paragraph 242===from https://www.thetedkarchive.com/library/carl-tobias-frayne-individualist-anarchism-in-france-and-its-legacy

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.feature: The most important form of revolution is internal—changing one’s mindset, behaviors, and ways of living—rather than relying on external mass movements or economic restructuring.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.original:
- Quoted text "Avant d’organiser la grande Révolution, il faut en faire une autre sans laquelle celle-ci sera frappée de stérilité et d’impuissance, c’est la révolution des cerveaux."  
  - Location paragraph 167===from https://www.thetedkarchive.com/library/carl-tobias-frayne-individualist-anarchism-in-france-and-its-legacy

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.feature: Individualist anarchism is not merely an extreme version of mainstream anarchism but represents a separate political tradition centered on personal autonomy and existential revolt.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.original:
- Quoted text "Individualist anarchism should thus be considered a political tradition in its own right – one that is much more complex and diverse than historians and other scholars of anarchism have generally acknowledged."  
  - Location paragraph 194===from https://www.thetedkarchive.com/library/carl-tobias-frayne-individualist-anarchism-in-france-and-its-legacy

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.feature: Individual acts of rebellion are seen as more authentic and effective than collective efforts like syndicates or unions, which are viewed as compromising true anarchist principles.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.original:
- Quoted text "‘Les plus belles pages de l’histoire révolutionnaire n’ont été inspirées que par l’acte individuel ; il n’y a rien à attendre des foules’."  
  - Location paragraph 225===from https://www.thetedkarchive.com/library/carl-tobias-frayne-individualist-anarchism-in-france-and-its-legacy

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.feature: What defines a person’s value is their level of awareness and resistance to domination, not their economic class; the key distinction is between the conscious and the ignorant.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.original:
- Quoted text "Individualists did not draw a fundamental distinction between the bourgeoisie and the proletariat, but between the “abrutis”, “crétins”, “avilis” and the “conscients”, “raisonnables”, “libres”."  
  - Location paragraph 240===from https://www.thetedkarchive.com/library/carl-tobias-frayne-individualist-anarchism-in-france-and-its-legacy

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-un.feature: French society places a high value on stability, security, and predictability in both personal and professional life to minimize exposure to uncertainty.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-un.original:
- Quoted text "Most French people value stability, security, and predictability both in their personal and professional lives."  
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://www.knbbs.com/understanding-french-culture-an-introduction-to-uncertainty-avoidant-societies/

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-un.feature: To avoid risks and incorrect decisions, French individuals tend to follow established rules and procedures rather than deviate from them.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-un.original:
- Quoted text "They tend to stick to established rules and procedures to avoid taking risks or making the wrong decisions."  
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://www.knbbs.com/understanding-french-culture-an-introduction-to-uncertainty-avoidant-societies/

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-un.feature: The French legal system is rigid and strictly adheres to legal codes, while the educational system emphasizes rote learning and standardized exams, reflecting a cultural resistance to ambiguity.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-un.original:
- Quoted text "This approach can be seen in the country’s legal system, which is known for its rigidity and adherence to legal codes. It is also reflected in the French educational system, which is based on rote learning and standardized exams."  
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://www.knbbs.com/understanding-french-culture-an-introduction-to-uncertainty-avoidant-societies/

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-un.feature: French business culture emphasizes hierarchy, formality, and protocol, with decisions requiring consultation among appropriate authorities before changes are made.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-un.original:
- Quoted text "French business culture is characterized by a strong emphasis on hierarchy, formality, and protocol. It is considered rude to take risks or make sudden changes without consulting the appropriate authorities."  
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://www.knbbs.com/understanding-french-culture-an-introduction-to-uncertainty-avoidant-societies/

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-un.feature: Business meetings and negotiations in France are typically lengthy and involve multiple stakeholders, each with defined roles, to ensure thorough planning and reduce uncertainty.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-un.original:
- Quoted text "Meetings and negotiations are often lengthy and involve multiple stakeholders, each with a specific role and responsibility."  
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://www.knbbs.com/understanding-french-culture-an-introduction-to-uncertainty-avoidant-societies/

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-un.feature: Leaders and managers are expected to have a clear, well-articulated vision, and there is little acceptance of improvisation or unplanned innovation.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-un.original:
- Quoted text "Leaders and managers are expected to have a clear-cut vision for their organization and be able to articulate it to their subordinates. There is little room for improvisation or innovation unless it is carefully planned and executed."  
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://www.knbbs.com/understanding-french-culture-an-introduction-to-uncertainty-avoidant-societies/

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-un.feature: French society has a low tolerance for ambiguity and uncertainty, leading to the establishment of a rule-oriented culture that relies on laws, rules, regulations, and controls to minimize uncertainty.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-un.original:
- Quoted text "Based on our studies and data, the large majority of predominantly Catholic countries (those with Uncertainty Avoidance as their highest ranking Dimension) have a low tolerance for ambiguity. This creates a highly rule-oriented society that institutes laws, rules, regulations, and controls in order to reduce the amount of uncertainty within the population."
  - Location paragraph 5===from http://www.internationalbusinesscenter.org/geert-hofstede/hofstede_france.shtml

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-un.feature: In cultures like France where Uncertainty Avoidance is high, there is a strong preference for structure and predictability, resulting in societal reliance on formalized procedures to manage unstructured situations.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-un.original:
- Quoted text "A High Uncertainty Avoidance ranking indicates the country has a low tolerance for uncertainty and ambiguity. This creates a rule-oriented society that institutes laws, rules, regulations, and controls in order to reduce the amount of uncertainty."
  - Location paragraph 9===from http://www.internationalbusinesscenter.org/geert-hofstede/hofstede_france.shtml

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-un.feature: French society demonstrates a strong preference for rules, regulations, and structured systems to create predictability and reduce uncertainty.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-un.original:
- Quoted text "France falls into the classic uncertainty-avoidant category, which means that its people have a strong need for rules, regulations, and structures to provide stability and predictability."  
  - Location p3===from https://www.nalug.net/exploring-the-nuances-of-france-as-a-classic-uncertainty-avoidant-culture/

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-un.feature: French people tend to be uncomfortable with change and prefer maintaining existing conditions, reflecting a cultural aversion to uncertainty.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-un.original:
- Quoted text "French people are often uncomfortable with change and tend to resist it, preferring to maintain the status quo."  
  - Location p4===from https://www.nalug.net/exploring-the-nuances-of-france-as-a-classic-uncertainty-avoidant-culture/

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-un.feature: France enforces highly protective labor laws that restrict employer actions such as layoffs, requiring specific justifications and procedures to ensure job security.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-un.original:
- Quoted text "Employers must follow strict guidelines when firing employees, and layoffs are only allowed in very specific circumstances."  
  - Location p4===from https://www.nalug.net/exploring-the-nuances-of-france-as-a-classic-uncertainty-avoidant-culture/

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-un.feature: Business meetings in France follow rigid formats with defined agendas and speaking protocols, reflecting a cultural emphasis on order and predictability.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-un.original:
- Quoted text "Meetings tend to be highly structured and follow a specific agenda, with clear guidelines about who can speak when and what topics are up for discussion."  
  - Location p5===from https://www.nalug.net/exploring-the-nuances-of-france-as-a-classic-uncertainty-avoidant-culture/

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-un.feature: The French bureaucratic system is characterized by complexity and inflexibility, illustrating a societal reliance on formal procedures to manage uncertainty.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-un.original:
- Quoted text "This need for structure is evident in many aspects of French life, including the country’s bureaucracy, which is known for its complexity and rigidity."  
  - Location p3===from https://www.nalug.net/exploring-the-nuances-of-france-as-a-classic-uncertainty-avoidant-culture/

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-lo.feature: Individuals in long-term oriented cultures value persistence and sustained effort toward goals.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-lo.original:
- Quoted text "Below are some characteristics of the two opposing sides of this dimension Long term orientation -persistance"
  - Location paragraph 3

- Rule Description Social relationships are ordered by status, and individuals are expected to observe hierarchical order.  
- ===from https://clearlycultural.com/geert-hofstede-cultural-dimensions/long-term-orientation/

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-lo.feature: A high Long-Term Orientation indicates that a society values long-term commitments and respects tradition, which supports a strong work ethic with expectations of long-term rewards from current efforts; however, business development may take longer, especially for outsiders.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-lo.original:
- Quoted text "High Long-Term Orientation ranking indicates the country prescribes to the values of long-term commitments and respect for tradition. This is thought to support a strong work ethic where long-term rewards are expected as a result of today's hard work. However, business may take longer to develop in this society, particularly for an 'outsider'."
  - Location paragraph 6 (p6)===from http://www.internationalbusinesscenter.org/geert-hofstede/hofstede_france.shtml

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-lo.feature: A low Long-Term Orientation indicates that a society does not emphasize long-term, traditional orientation, allowing for more rapid change since traditions and long-term commitments do not hinder progress.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-lo.original:
- Quoted text "A Low Long-Term Orientation ranking indicates the country does not reinforce the concept of long-term, traditional orientation. In this culture, change can occur more rapidly as long-term traditions and commitments do not become impediments to change."
  - Location paragraph 6 (p6)===from http://www.internationalbusinesscenter.org/geert-hofstede/hofstede_france.shtml

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.feature: In French culture, indulgence is characterized by a tendency to excuse or forgive others' faults, reflecting a lenient and understanding attitude toward human imperfections.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.original:
- Quoted text "Facilité à excuser, à pardonner."  
  - Location p1===from https://dictionnaire.lerobert.com/en/definition/indulgence

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.feature: Within the Catholic religious context, indulgence refers to the remission of punishment for sins granted by the Church, indicating a culturally embedded spiritual practice involving forgiveness under specific conditions.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.original:
- Quoted text "Religion catholique Remise des peines méritées par les péchés, accordée par l'Église dans une circonstance particulière."  
  - Location p2===from https://dictionnaire.lerobert.com/en/definition/indulgence

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.feature: French cultural discourse shows that people may display varying degrees of indulgence when judging behaviors, such as showing leniency toward sexist humor or judicial offenses, suggesting contextual acceptance of certain transgressions.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.original:
- Quoted text "En raison de son caractère ambigu, l'humour sexiste bénéficie d'une forte indulgence."  
  - Location p3===from https://dictionnaire.lerobert.com/en/definition/indulgence

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.feature: It is a recognized social practice in France to explicitly ask for indulgence, particularly in formal environments like courts or public speeches, acknowledging one’s shortcomings and seeking宽容 from others.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-in.original:
- Quoted text "Le jeune homme requiert juste l'indulgence du tribunal, pour raisons professionnelles."  
  - Location p4===from https://dictionnaire.lerobert.com/en/definition/indulgence

Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.feature: Discussing religion in France is often considered taboo and can provoke strong emotional reactions, similar to discussions about politics.
Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.original:
- Quoted text "Talking about religion in France can be a surprisingly delicate affair, often considered quite taboo. Much like politics, it tends to ignite passionate discussions and deeply felt reactions."  
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://guidetourism.net/world/france/religion-in-france/

Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.feature: Catholicism has historically played a central role in shaping France’s politics, culture, and social structures.
Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.original:
- Quoted text "The Catholic Church has undeniably cast a long shadow over France’s history, profoundly shaping its politics, culture, and social fabric."  
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://guidetourism.net/world/france/religion-in-france/

Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.feature: France is constitutionally defined as a secular republic, with a strict separation between religious institutions and the state, ensuring state neutrality in religious matters.
Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.original:
- Quoted text "Laïcité, enshrined in the 1905 law and reaffirmed in the 1958 Constitution, defines France as an indivisible, secular, democratic, and social republic. It establishes a strict separation between church and state, prohibiting religious influence in government and public institutions and ensuring state neutrality regarding religious affairs."  
  - Location paragraph 13===from https://guidetourism.net/world/france/religion-in-france/

Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.feature: In public schools, students are not allowed to wear visible religious symbols such as hijabs, kippahs, or large crosses, in accordance with the principle of laïcité.
Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.original:
- Quoted text "In public schools, laïcité imposes restrictions on religious expression. Since 2004, students have been prohibited from wearing 'conspicuous' religious symbols, such as hijabs, kippahs, or large crosses, sparking ongoing debates about the balance between personal freedom and secular unity."  
  - Location paragraph 13===from https://guidetourism.net/world/france/religion-in-france/

Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.feature: Only civil marriage ceremonies conducted at town halls are legally recognized in France, even if followed by a religious ceremony.
Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.original:
- Quoted text "For instance, civil ceremonies at town halls are the only legally recognized form of marriage, even if religious ceremonies follow."  
  - Location paragraph 13===from https://guidetourism.net/world/france/religion-in-france/

Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.feature: The French government must remain neutral in religious matters and cannot favor one religion over another.
Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.original:
- Quoted text "Laïcité is the French term for secularism. It’s the principle that the government should be neutral in matters of religion. In France, this means that the government cannot favour one religion over another, and religious institutions cannot interfere in government affairs."  
  - Location p10===from https://www.frenchclass.in/blog/religion-in-france/

Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.feature: Religious institutions are prohibited from interfering in government affairs as part of the secular framework.
Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.original:
- Quoted text "Laïcité is the French term for secularism. It’s the principle that the government should be neutral in matters of religion. In France, this means that the government cannot favour one religion over another, and religious institutions cannot interfere in government affairs."  
  - Location p10===from https://www.frenchclass.in/blog/religion-in-france/

Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.feature: Religious symbols are not allowed in public schools to maintain a neutral educational environment.
Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.original:
- Quoted text "Secularism, the separation of the Church and the State, influences education by keeping religious teachings out of public schools. This ensures a neutral learning environment for all students."  
  - Location p11===from https://www.frenchclass.in/blog/religion-in-france/

Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.feature: Public servants are restricted from wearing religious symbols due to secular policies.
Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.original:
- Quoted text "Another controversy involves the wearing of religious symbols by public servants."  
  - Location p13===from https://www.frenchclass.in/blog/religion-in-france/

Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.feature: The wearing of full-face Islamic veils such as the burqa and niqab is banned in public spaces.
Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.original:
- Quoted text "One major issue is the ban on Islamic veils, such as the burqa and niqab, in public spaces."  
  - Location p13===from https://www.frenchclass.in/blog/religion-in-france/

Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.feature: The display of religious symbols in public places is limited to ensure a neutral environment for all citizens.
Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.original:
- Quoted text "Secularism also limits the display of religious symbols in public places, aiming to create a neutral environment for all citizens."  
  - Location p11===from https://www.frenchclass.in/blog/religion-in-france/

Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.feature: A majority of French people identify as agnostic or non-believers, reflecting a significant decline in religious belief.
Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.original:
- Quoted text "Indeed, according to a survey conducted in 2023, more than half of the French considered themselves agnostic or non-believers."  
  - Location paragraph 1===from https://www.statista.com/topics/7963/religion-in-france/

Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.feature: France has a historic predominantly Christian Catholic tradition, despite declining religiosity.
Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.original:
- Quoted text "France, a nation built around the principle of freedom of worship, is also a country with a historic predominantly Christian Catholic tradition..."  
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://www.statista.com/topics/7963/religion-in-france/

Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.feature: Religious practice is generally low among Catholics, Muslims, and Jews in France.
Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.original:
- Quoted text "But as is the case with Catholics, the practice of religious traditions is far from being assiduous among Muslims, and the same is true among Jews, too."  
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://www.statista.com/topics/7963/religion-in-france/

Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.feature: The number of Catholic baptisms and religious marriages has been consistently decreasing.
Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.original:
- Quoted text "For instance, the number of baptisms is constantly decreasing, as well as Catholic religious marriages."  
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://www.statista.com/topics/7963/religion-in-france/

Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.feature: The 1905 law separating Church and State established secularism as a foundational constitutional value in France, ensuring state neutrality in religious matters.
Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.original:
- Quoted text "It is considered the founding text of secularism, the principle that establishes the neutrality of the State in religious matters in France."  
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://www.statista.com/topics/7963/religion-in-france/

Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.feature: A 2004 law prohibits students from wearing conspicuous religious symbols in schools, a measure supported by public opinion.
Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.original:
- Quoted text "In March 2004, the French government passed a law prohibiting students from wearing conspicuous religious symbols at school, which the public opinion approved."  
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://www.statista.com/topics/7963/religion-in-france/

Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.feature: The meaning and application of secularism remain controversial, particularly regarding proposed restrictions on religious expression such as banning Muslim girls under 15 from wearing the veil in public spaces.
Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.original:
- Quoted text "However, in recent days, Gabriel Attal, ex-Prime Minister of Emmanuel Macron, has stated his intention to pass a law prohibiting Muslim girls under 15 years old from wearing the veil in public spaces. This measure was called out for its anti-secular nature by leftist political personalities."  
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://www.statista.com/topics/7963/religion-in-france/

Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.feature: There has been an increase in anti-Semitic and Islamophobic acts in France, linked to international events in the Middle East.
Values_and_Beliefs-religion-religion.original:
- Quoted text "In recent years, many tensions have developed around religion in French society, with Islamophobic and anti-Semitic acts on the rise, fueled by the current international context in the Middle East."  
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://www.statista.com/topics/7963/religion-in-france/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-infor.feature: The use of "tu" instead of "vous" is a key feature of informal French, indicating familiarity or closeness with the person being addressed.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-infor.original:
- Quoted text "Use of “tu” The familiar form of address indicates closeness or familiarity with the person."
  - Location paragraph 9===from https://www.ccfs-sorbonne.fr/en/formal-and-informal-french/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-infor.feature: Informal French includes the use of colloquial expressions and slang that do not follow strict grammatical rules, commonly used in casual communication.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-infor.original:
- Quoted text "Colloquialisms and slang Incorporation of everyday expressions and slang that may not adhere to strict grammatical rules."
  - Location paragraph 10===from https://www.ccfs-sorbonne.fr/en/formal-and-informal-french/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-infor.feature: Informal French often uses shorter sentences and frequent contractions to make conversation more natural and fluid.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-infor.original:
- Quoted text "Simplified structures Shorter sentences and frequent contractions that make conversation flow more naturally."
  - Location paragraph 10===from https://www.ccfs-sorbonne.fr/en/formal-and-informal-french/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-infor.feature: Informal French is appropriate in social gatherings, casual meetings, and digital communication such as texting or online chats.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-infor.original:
- Quoted text "Social Gatherings Engage in casual conversations with friends, family, or peers. Texting or Online Chats Informal communication often employs slang and abbreviations that enhance relatability. Casual Meetings In relaxed environments, such as cafés or bars, feel free to adopt a more informal tone with acquaintances."
  - Location paragraph 12===from https://www.ccfs-sorbonne.fr/en/formal-and-informal-french/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-infor.feature: In informal French, the word "ne" is omitted in negative constructions, while the rest of the negation (e.g., "pas", "jamais", "rien") remains.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-infor.original:
- Quoted text "Note ne disappears in the informal"
  - Location p1===from https://linguim.com/en/fr/formal-vs-informal.html

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-infor.feature: In informal French, questions do not require inversion of the verb and subject; instead, the normal word order is used.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-infor.original:
- Quoted text "In informal French, there is no inversion F Vous venez ce soir? (informal)"
  - Location p2===from https://linguim.com/en/fr/formal-vs-informal.html

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-infor.feature: In informal French, the formal pronouns "ceci" or "cela" are replaced with the informal "ça".
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-infor.original:
- Quoted text "When indefinite demonstrative pronouns like ceci or cela (this or that/ formal) are replaced by ça ( this/informal)"
  - Location p3===from https://linguim.com/en/fr/formal-vs-informal.html

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-infor.feature: In informal French, compound tenses (e.g., "va manger") are used instead of simple tenses (e.g., "mangera").
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-infor.original:
- Quoted text "Simple tenses are used for formal French whereas compound tenses are used in informal French"
  - Location p4===from https://linguim.com/en/fr/formal-vs-informal.html

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-compl.feature: French compliments are typically understated and brief, avoiding exaggerated or overly enthusiastic praise to maintain sincerity and cultural appropriateness.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-compl.original:
- Quoted text "French compliments are often understated. Gushing praise like 'OMG I LOVED IT SO MUCH!' or 'You’re amazing!' might be normal in American English but can come off as exaggerated or fake in French."  
  - Location p4===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/8/8/how-to-compliment-someone-in-french-without-making-it-awkward

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-compl.feature: Compliments are more meaningful and appreciated when they are based on observable achievements or efforts, rather than given freely or prematurely.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-compl.original:
- Quoted text "French people tend to see compliments as meaningful when they’re earned. Telling someone they’re 'so talented' when you’ve just met them might feel premature."  
  - Location p5===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/8/8/how-to-compliment-someone-in-french-without-making-it-awkward

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-compl.feature: Compliments about physical appearance, especially from someone not well-known, can be interpreted as flirtatious or inappropriate due to cultural sensitivity around context and tone.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-compl.original:
- Quoted text "Compliments about physical appearance, especially if given too freely or to someone you don’t know well, might be interpreted as flirtation."  
  - Location p6===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/8/8/how-to-compliment-someone-in-french-without-making-it-awkward

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-compl.feature: The formal “vous” should be used when giving compliments to strangers or in professional environments, while “tu” is reserved for friends, peers, or younger individuals.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-compl.original:
- Quoted text "Use the formal 'vous' with strangers or in professional settings. 'Tu' is for friends, peers, or young people."  
  - Location p7===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/8/8/how-to-compliment-someone-in-french-without-making-it-awkward

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-compl.feature: In workplace settings, compliments should focus on skills, performance, or professional qualities rather than personal appearance, except in rare neutral cases.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-compl.original:
- Quoted text "Keep it polished and non-personal in the workplace. Focus on skills, results, and communication... Avoid compliments on appearance at work, unless it’s something neutral like 'J’aime bien votre style.'"  
  - Location p10===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/8/8/how-to-compliment-someone-in-french-without-making-it-awkward

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-compl.feature: When receiving a compliment, French speakers typically respond with modesty or slight deflection rather than accepting it confidently or boastfully.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-compl.original:
- Quoted text "Unlike in English, where we might respond with 'Thanks! I know, right?' or 'Oh no, not really,' the French typically respond more modestly—or even deflect a little."  
  - Location p11===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/8/8/how-to-compliment-someone-in-french-without-making-it-awkward

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-cultu.feature: It is customary in France to greet people with "Bonjour" during the day or "Bonsoir" in the evening when entering a public place or starting a conversation, as failure to do so may be considered impolite.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-cultu.original:
- Quoted text "In France, it is common to greet people with a “Bonjour” (in the morning or during the day) or a “Bonsoir” (in the evening) when entering a public place or starting a conversation. Failure to do so may be perceived as rude."
  - Location p6===from https://www.ccfs-sorbonne.fr/en/french-courtesy-and-social-rules-examples-of-cultural-specificities/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-cultu.feature: In initial interactions or professional settings, French people typically use formal titles (e.g., Sir, Madam) along with surnames as a sign of respect.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-cultu.original:
- Quoted text "The French are often formal when speaking to someone for the first time or in a professional context. The use of titles (Sir, Madam, Miss) and last names is common, especially in a professional setting."
  - Location p7===from https://www.ccfs-sorbonne.fr/en/french-courtesy-and-social-rules-examples-of-cultural-specificities/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-cultu.feature: Expressions such as "please," "thank you," and "excuse me" are routinely used in France, and omitting "thank you" after receiving a service or gift is socially disapproved.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-cultu.original:
- Quoted text "Phrases like 'please' (please in case of privacy), 'thank you' and 'excuse me' are used regularly. Saying 'thank you' is essential after receiving a service or gift, and not doing so can be frowned upon."
  - Location p8===from https://www.ccfs-sorbonne.fr/en/french-courtesy-and-social-rules-examples-of-cultural-specificities/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-cultu.feature: Arriving on time for appointments or meetings, particularly in professional or academic contexts, is seen as a sign of respect; if late, it is polite to notify others in advance.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-cultu.original:
- Quoted text "Being on time is a sign of respect towards others in France. It is important to arrive on time to an appointment or meeting, especially in a professional or academic setting. When/if late, it is polite to notify in advance."
  - Location p9===from https://www.ccfs-sorbonne.fr/en/french-courtesy-and-social-rules-examples-of-cultural-specificities/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-cultu.feature: French people commonly greet or bid farewell to one another by kissing on the cheeks, with two kisses being the general standard, although the number may vary by region.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-cultu.original:
- Quoted text "When they meet or take their leave, French people tend to kiss each other on the cheeks. The number of kisses may vary from region to region, but two is generally the standard."
  - Location p10===from https://www.ccfs-sorbonne.fr/en/french-courtesy-and-social-rules-examples-of-cultural-specificities/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-cultu.feature: During meals, it is expected that all guests wait until everyone has been served before beginning to eat, as part of demonstrating politeness.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-cultu.original:
- Quoted text "Waiting until everyone is served before starting to eat is an important rule, as is the courtesy of thanking the host at the end of the meal."
  - Location p12===from https://www.ccfs-sorbonne.fr/en/french-courtesy-and-social-rules-examples-of-cultural-specificities/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-cultu.feature: It is courteous to thank the host at the end of a meal as a sign of appreciation.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-cultu.original:
- Quoted text "Waiting until everyone is served before starting to eat is an important rule, as is the courtesy of thanking the host at the end of the meal."
  - Location p12===from https://www.ccfs-sorbonne.fr/en/french-courtesy-and-social-rules-examples-of-cultural-specificities/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-cultu.feature: Dressing neatly is considered a sign of respect toward others in social and professional interactions.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-cultu.original:
- Quoted text "French people are attentive to their appearance and that of others. Dressing neatly is a sign of respect for the people you meet."
  - Location p13===from https://www.ccfs-sorbonne.fr/en/french-courtesy-and-social-rules-examples-of-cultural-specificities/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-cultu.feature: In public transportation, it is polite to offer one’s seat to elderly individuals, pregnant women, or people with disabilities.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-cultu.original:
- Quoted text "On public transport, it is polite to give up your seat to elderly people, pregnant women or people with disabilities."
  - Location p15===from https://www.ccfs-sorbonne.fr/en/french-courtesy-and-social-rules-examples-of-cultural-specificities/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-cultu.feature: Observing and respecting queues in public settings is considered a polite and socially expected behavior.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-cultu.original:
- Quoted text "Queues are also respected."
  - Location p15===from https://www.ccfs-sorbonne.fr/en/french-courtesy-and-social-rules-examples-of-cultural-specificities/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-insul.feature: French insults are often used playfully among friends but should be avoided in formal settings or with people one does not know well, as they can be perceived as rude or offensive.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-insul.original:
- Quoted text "Use it sparingly with friends in a playful context, but avoid it in formal settings or with people you don’t know well—it can be rude."  
  - Location p1===from https://www.tandem.net/en/blog/french-insults

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-insul.feature: Many French insults are considered inappropriate when directed at strangers or used in polite company due to their offensive or vulgar nature.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-insul.original:
- Quoted text "Definitely avoid using it in polite company or French people you don't know too well, as it’s far from charming."  
  - Location p23===from https://www.tandem.net/en/blog/french-insults

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-insul.feature: The appropriateness of using French insults depends heavily on the relationship between individuals and the context, such as whether the situation is a lighthearted exchange among close friends.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-insul.original:
- Quoted text "While filled with beautiful French words, this is a light jab that works best in playful roasting sessions among friends."  
  - Location p28===from https://www.tandem.net/en/blog/french-insults

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-insul.feature: The most offensive French insults, especially those involving vulgarity or personal attacks, should only be used in extreme anger or heated arguments and are best avoided in real conversation due to potential serious consequences.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-insul.original:
- Quoted text "It’s extremely direct, vulgar, and aggressive, so it should only be used in the most heated arguments—if at all. Save this one for learning purposes rather than real-world use!"  
  - Location p34===from https://www.tandem.net/en/blog/french-insults

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-insul.feature: Insults criticizing someone’s physical appearance or involving family members (e.g., “yo mama” jokes) are considered particularly insulting and should be restricted to joking among close friends.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-insul.original:
- Quoted text "This insult takes the form of a 'yo mama' joke... While not the most vulgar, it’s still cheeky and insulting... works best in playful roasting sessions among friends."  
  - Location p28===from https://www.tandem.net/en/blog/french-insults

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-insul.feature: Some French insults are framed humorously or creatively (e.g., comparing someone to absurd imagery), making them suitable for playful teasing without excessive aggression.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-insul.original:
- Quoted text "This common French phrase literally means 'go cook yourself an egg,' which is the equivalent of 'get lost' or 'buzz off.' It’s a humorous, light insult that’s perfect for telling someone to stop bothering you without being too aggressive."  
  - Location p24===from https://www.tandem.net/en/blog/french-insults

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-sensi.feature: Avoid asking personal questions about age, sexual orientation, family, or children unless there is a well-established friendship, as the French value privacy.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-sensi.original:
- Quoted text "Avoid asking personal questions relating to one’s age, sexual orientation, family or children unless you have a well-established friendship. The French value privacy."  
  - Location paragraph 1 (under "Don'ts")===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-do-s-and-don-ts

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-sensi.feature: Asking about someone’s salary or financial situation is considered taboo and highly inappropriate, even among close acquaintances; such topics should only be discussed if the other person chooses to disclose them.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-sensi.original:
- Quoted text "Inquiring about one’s salary and finances is taboo. To do so is considered highly inappropriate, regardless of how close the relationship is between those conversing. Allow for your French counterpart to reveal this information if they wish."  
  - Location paragraph 2 (under "Don'ts")===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-do-s-and-don-ts

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-sensi.feature: It can be considered rude to reveal one’s own high salary due to social perceptions of the upper class, even if asked.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-sensi.original:
- Quoted text "In some contexts, it is also considered rude to reveal your salary if it is significantly high due to social perceptions of the upper class (see Economic and Geographic Distinctions in Core Concepts)."  
  - Location paragraph 2 (under "Don'ts")===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-do-s-and-don-ts

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-sensi.feature: Foreigners should avoid making negative comments or criticisms about the French nation or identity, as this may cause offense despite the French themselves being critical of their country.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-sensi.original:
- Quoted text "French people take great pride in their nation and language. Although the French tend to be quite critical, negative comments or criticisms about the French nation or identity from foreigners may offend your French counterpart."  
  - Location paragraph 4 (under "Don'ts")===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-do-s-and-don-ts

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-sensi.feature: Discussing salary and compensation is considered a sensitive topic among colleagues in France, as many prefer to avoid such conversations to prevent jealousy, offense, or feelings of injustice.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-sensi.original:
- Quoted text "The question of remuneration is often difficult to discuss between colleagues. It is a very sensitive subject that the French do not like to discuss."  
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://francaiseasy.com/en/7222-2/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-sensi.feature: Political discussions are generally avoided in professional settings in France to maintain harmonious working relationships, as most people prefer not to disclose their political opinions to colleagues.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-sensi.original:
- Quoted text "Discussions on the subject of politics are very much avoided in France, especially when it comes to exchanges between office colleagues."  
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://francaiseasy.com/en/7222-2/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-sensi.feature: Religion is a poorly tolerated topic in French culture, particularly in workplace contexts, due to the country's secular values, even though individuals have the right to express religious beliefs in the private sector.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-sensi.original:
- Quoted text "The issue of religion is not a very tolerated topic in French culture, especially among colleagues. As a reminder, France has made the option of secularism. As a result, there is no state religion."  
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://francaiseasy.com/en/7222-2/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-sensi.feature: While sexuality may be discussed openly between strangers, it is considered a delicate and difficult subject to talk about within families or couples in French culture.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-sensi.original:
- Quoted text "Although the French talk openly about sexuality between strangers, when it comes to the family circle, this subject becomes delicate. Even within a couple, it is a difficult question to discuss because of its sensitivity."  
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://francaiseasy.com/en/7222-2/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-sensi.feature: Topics such as death, illness, divorce, and personal relationships are commonly avoided in French culture and are considered part of the broader set of taboo subjects.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-sensi.original:
- Quoted text "On the other hand, if you want to learn more about French culture, you should know that there are many other subjects that are avoided and are part of the taboo subjects. These include death, illness, divorce and relationships."  
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://francaiseasy.com/en/7222-2/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-sensi.feature: Discussing someone’s occupation is considered inappropriate in casual conversation, as French people view their job as separate from their identity and personal life.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-sensi.original:
- Quoted text "As an icebreaker, the subject is taboo in France."
  - Location p8===from https://snippetsofparis.com/taboos/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-sensi.feature: Sharing details about one’s personal life, such as relationships or family matters, is generally avoided, especially in professional settings or with acquaintances.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-sensi.original:
- Quoted text "French people rarely talk about their dates or their personal life even with close friends, except maybe bringing it up in passing."
  - Location p9===from https://snippetsofparis.com/taboos/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-sensi.feature: Talking about religion is discouraged in France due to the legal principle of laicité (separation of church and state), and people are generally uncomfortable discussing religious topics.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-sensi.original:
- Quoted text "Either way, French people are not comfortable talking about religion, so it is a conversational topic best to be avoided."
  - Location p11===from https://snippetsofparis.com/taboos/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-sensi.feature: Conversations about race are highly sensitive and avoided in France, partly because the law prohibits collecting racial data, making informed discussion difficult.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-sensi.original:
- Quoted text "Beyond not talking about it, French law bans the collection of data based on race and religion, meaning that there are no statistics available to breakdown the population of the country in this manner."
  - Location p12===from https://snippetsofparis.com/taboos/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-sensi.feature: Discussing financial matters such as income, property value, or luxury purchases is considered inappropriate and socially unacceptable in France.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-sensi.original:
- Quoted text "And with that speaking about money, how much one earns, how much one’s house costs, etc. all remains highly sensitive."
  - Location p13===from https://snippetsofparis.com/taboos/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-sensi.feature: Political discussions are risky and best avoided, even with people one knows well, due to strong and divisive opinions across the political spectrum.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-sensi.original:
- Quoted text "So you are taking a risk if you bring up politics with someone you don’t know very well, or even if you do know the person well."
  - Location p14===from https://snippetsofparis.com/taboos/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-stere.feature: The perception that French people are rude stems from cultural differences in communication; they may appear reserved or less expressive, but this does not indicate arrogance or lack of friendliness.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-stere.original:
- Quoted text "Most French people find the overt expression of emotions and enthusiasm as insincere and even stupid. However, it doesn’t imply that they don’t feel happy or passionate."
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://www.frenchclass.in/blog/common-stereotypes-about-french-people/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-stere.feature: French people tend to express their opinions openly and directly, which can be misinterpreted as criticism or rudeness by those from cultures that prioritize politeness over honesty.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-stere.original:
- Quoted text "Unlike some cultures that prioritise politeness and avoid confrontation, French people are more likely to express their opinions openly, even if they are negative. This directness can sometimes be misinterpreted as criticism or judgement, which might lead to hostility!"
  - Location paragraph 10===from https://www.frenchclass.in/blog/common-stereotypes-about-french-people/

Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-stere.feature: It is considered impolite to begin a conversation in English without first offering a greeting in French, as this is seen as presumptuous and disrespectful.
Values_and_Beliefs-Do's and Don'ts-stere.original:
- Quoted text "Do not directly open conversations in English with a waiter or shopkeeper without even saying a simple greeting in French, as most French people consider it rude and presumptuous."
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://www.frenchclass.in/blog/common-stereotypes-about-french-people/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: France enforces speed limits using automated cameras and radar systems that photograph vehicles exceeding the speed limit, and drivers must pay fines if caught.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "France has a system of automated cameras and radar that will snap a picture of your car if you’re driving too fast! These radars (radars) are signalés (indicated) with road-side signs, so keep your eyes open … or you might get flashé (the term the French use for getting snapped by the radars) and have to pay une amende (a fine)."
  - Location p4===from https://blogs.transparent.com/french/french-culture-driving-in-france/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: As of June of the year mentioned in the text, the speed limit on many French roads was reduced from 90 km/h to 80 km/h, which has been a subject of public controversy.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "As of June of this year, the speed limit on many French roads has been lowered to 80 km/h (down from 90). It’s been a bit of a national scandal with many French people complaining about the new, stricter driving laws."
  - Location p5===from https://blogs.transparent.com/french/french-culture-driving-in-france/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Drivers should use the fast lane only for passing and must move back to the right afterward; passing on the right is not allowed.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "do not drive along mindlessly in the fast lane. Use it only to pass and then promptly move back over out of the way. Equally important, do not do what Americans do and pass another car on the right. They just don’t do that here in France (or in other European countries as far as I know)."
  - Location p6===from https://blogs.transparent.com/french/french-culture-driving-in-france/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Vehicles coming from the right have priority at intersections, reflecting a cultural norm of fairness and consideration in driving behavior.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Priorité à droite (Priority to the right) This rule gives priority to vehicles coming from the right, showing the importance of fairness and consideration in French driving culture."
  - Location paragraph 11===from https://blog.albert-learning.com/2025/01/30/french-road-signs/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Certain streets are designated as one-way, requiring vehicles to travel in a single direction only.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Sens unique – One-way Cette rue est en sens unique. (This street is one-way.)"
  - Location paragraph 10===from https://blog.albert-learning.com/2025/01/30/french-road-signs/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: In France, vehicles drive on the right side of the road and have the steering wheel positioned on the left.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "In France, we drive on the right and the steering wheel is on the left."  
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://www.ohlalafrenchcourse.com/en/blog/article/how-to-drive-in-france-car-and-driving-vocabulary

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: All passengers in a vehicle must wear seatbelts.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "It is compulsory to wear a seatbelt for all passengers."  
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://www.ohlalafrenchcourse.com/en/blog/article/how-to-drive-in-france-car-and-driving-vocabulary

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Motorcyclists are required by law to wear helmets.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "For motorcyclists, wearing a helmet is mandatory."  
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://www.ohlalafrenchcourse.com/en/blog/article/how-to-drive-in-france-car-and-driving-vocabulary

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Drivers are not allowed to make phone calls using handheld devices unless a hands-free kit is used.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "It is also forbidden to make phone calls while driving unless you use a hands-free kit."  
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://www.ohlalafrenchcourse.com/en/blog/article/how-to-drive-in-france-car-and-driving-vocabulary

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: The speed limits in France vary depending on the area 50 km/h in towns, 90 km/h (or 80 km/h in some areas) outside urban zones, and 130 km/h on highways (reduced to 110 km/h in rainy conditions).
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "In France, the speed limit for light vehicles is  50 km/h in town / 90 km/h (80 in some places) outside the city / 130 km/h on the highway (110 km/h if it rains)"  
  - Location paragraph 9===from https://www.ohlalafrenchcourse.com/en/blog/article/how-to-drive-in-france-car-and-driving-vocabulary

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: France has various types of roads including communal, departmental, national, restricted-access, European, and freeways, with freeways requiring toll payments.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "In France, one can drive on communal roads, departmental roads, national roads, roads with restricted access, European roads and on freeways. Freeways in France have tolls so that drivers can pay for their journey."  
  - Location paragraph 10===from https://www.ohlalafrenchcourse.com/en/blog/article/how-to-drive-in-france-car-and-driving-vocabulary

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Failing to comply with traffic regulations constitutes an infraction and may result in fines.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "If you don't respect one of these regulations in France, you commit an infraction, and you can be fined."  
  - Location paragraph 11===from https://www.ohlalafrenchcourse.com/en/blog/article/how-to-drive-in-france-car-and-driving-vocabulary

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: In France, vehicles must drive on the right side of the road.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Cars in France drive on the right."
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://thegoodlifefrance.com/driving-in-france-be-aware-of-the-rules/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: All passengers in a vehicle must wear seat belts while traveling in France.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "All passengers must wear seat-belts."
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://thegoodlifefrance.com/driving-in-france-be-aware-of-the-rules/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Children under the age of 10 are not permitted to sit in the front seats of a vehicle, with the exception of babies up to 9 months old who are using rear-facing child seats.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Children under the age of 10 are not allowed in front seats (except babies up to 9 months with rear facing child seats)."
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://thegoodlifefrance.com/driving-in-france-be-aware-of-the-rules/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Drivers must stop at zebra crossings when pedestrians are present, as this is now legally enforced.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "You must stop at Zebra crossings – this is now enforced by law (it didn’t used to be!)."
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://thegoodlifefrance.com/driving-in-france-be-aware-of-the-rules/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Exceeding the speed limit can result in immediate fines that must be paid in cash, and fines are known to be very expensive.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Don’t be tempted to exceed the speed limit you could be fined on the spot. Fines are very expensive and you are required to pay in cash!"
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://thegoodlifefrance.com/driving-in-france-be-aware-of-the-rules/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: It is illegal to use a mobile phone while driving, and drivers can be fined if caught doing so.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "You will be fined if you are caught using a mobile phone while driving."
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://thegoodlifefrance.com/driving-in-france-be-aware-of-the-rules/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Vehicles set up for left-side driving must have headlamp adjusters applied to ensure proper lighting direction when driving on the right.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "You will need to apply headlamp adjusters to your car headlamps if your car is set up for driving on the left."
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://thegoodlifefrance.com/driving-in-france-be-aware-of-the-rules/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Foreign-registered vehicles must display a sticker indicating the country of origin, regardless of what is shown on the license plate; this also applies to trailers or caravans being towed.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "If you are driving a foreign registered vehicle, a sticker showing the country of origin, must be attached to the vehicle regardless of what is on the number plate and, if you’re towing a trailer or caravan that must also have a country of origin sticker."
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://thegoodlifefrance.com/driving-in-france-be-aware-of-the-rules/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Possession of a radar detector is considered a serious crime and can result in a fine of €2000 or more.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Posession of a radar detector is a serious crime – you will be fined €2000 or more."
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://thegoodlifefrance.com/driving-in-france-be-aware-of-the-rules/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: In some cities in France, drivers are required to display a French Clean Air Sticker on their vehicle.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "In some cities you will need to have French Clean Air Stickers showing"
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://thegoodlifefrance.com/driving-in-france-be-aware-of-the-rules/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Drivers must carry and be able to present their driving licence, insurance certificate, and vehicle registration documents during roadside checks.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Driving licence, insurance certificate and vehicle registration documents must be shown at any roadside controls – make sure you carry these documents in the car with you."
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://thegoodlifefrance.com/driving-in-france-be-aware-of-the-rules/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: In the absence of signage, vehicles coming from the right have priority at intersections, parking lot exits, old roundabouts, and residential areas.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "In the absence of signage, any vehicle coming from the right has priority. This rule, unique in Europe, applies even in unmarked roundabouts and in most urban intersections."
  - Location paragraph 16===from https://francepeages.com/blog/guide-french-road-signs

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: A yellow diamond sign indicates a priority road where the driver has the right of way, but must still watch for intersections and changes in priority.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Yellow diamond indicating a priority route" and "You have priority"
  - Location paragraph 15===from https://francepeages.com/blog/guide-french-road-signs

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: A crossed yellow diamond sign indicates the end of a priority road, meaning the driver no longer has automatic right of way and standard right-of-way rules apply.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Crossed yellow diamond indicating end of priority road" and "No more automatic priority"
  - Location paragraph 17===from https://francepeages.com/blog/guide-french-road-signs

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: A red octagon STOP sign requires a complete stop, even if there is no traffic, and drivers must yield to all other vehicles.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Red octagon" and "Complete stop required" with practical tip "Respect the stop even without traffic"
  - Location paragraph 14===from https://francepeages.com/blog/guide-french-road-signs

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: An inverted triangle (Yield) sign requires drivers to give way, slowing down and observing, but they do not need to stop if the road is clear.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Inverted triangle" and "Give way without stopping if road is clear" with practical tip "Slow down and observe"
  - Location paragraph 15===from https://francepeages.com/blog/guide-french-road-signs

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Direction signs use specific colors—blue for highways, green for national roads, white for departmental roads, and yellow for temporary diversions—to indicate road type and associated rules.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "The French directional system uses a strict color code allowing immediate identification of road type and associated services." Followed by "Blue Color", "Green Color", "White Color", "Yellow Color"
  - Location paragraph 18===from https://francepeages.com/blog/guide-french-road-signs

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Prohibition signs, marked by a red circle, are strictly enforced with automated ticketing, and violations result in fines such as €135 for no entry or wrong-way driving.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "French prohibition signs are particularly strictly enforced, with an automated ticketing system expanding rapidly." and "Penalty €135 fine"
  - Location paragraph 20===from https://francepeages.com/blog/guide-french-road-signs

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Obligation signs, identified by a blue background and white border, require specific behaviors such as following a mandatory direction or using a reserved lane, and failure to comply results in fines.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Obligation signs, recognizable by their blue background and white border, impose specific behaviors on drivers. Their non-compliance constitutes an infraction..."
  - Location paragraph 22===from https://francepeages.com/blog/guide-french-road-signs

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Triangular warning signs alert drivers to upcoming dangers such as weather conditions, road configuration risks, or special situations like roadworks and wildlife.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Triangular warning signs alert about upcoming dangers. France uses many specific signs related to its geography and climate particularities that should be well known."
  - Location paragraph 24===from https://francepeages.com/blog/guide-french-road-signs

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: The sign "Sortie" indicates an exit and is commonly found in metros, train stations, airports, shopping malls, and public buildings to guide people out.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "You’ll see this at every metro, train station, airport, shopping mall, and public building. It's crucial to know this word when finding your way out."
  - Location paragraph 9===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/5/29/french-signs-youll-see-everywhereand-what-they-actually-mean

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: The sign "Correspondance" is used in metros and train stations to indicate a transfer point between different lines or routes.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Used mainly in metros and train stations, this sign helps you navigate from one line to another."
  - Location paragraph 10===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/5/29/french-signs-youll-see-everywhereand-what-they-actually-mean

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: These signs indicate restricted access and are used to prohibit entry to certain areas such as one-way streets or private rooms.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Whether it’s a one-way street or a restricted door, these signs tell you where not to go."
  - Location paragraph 11===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/5/29/french-signs-youll-see-everywhereand-what-they-actually-mean

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: The "Ralentir" sign serves as a cautionary signal in areas like residential zones, near schools, or shared pedestrian spaces, instructing drivers to reduce speed.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "This is more than a traffic command. You may see it in residential areas, near schools, or even in shared pedestrian zones. It signals caution."
  - Location paragraph 12===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/5/29/french-signs-youll-see-everywhereand-what-they-actually-mean

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: This sign indicates that passengers must validate their tickets upon boarding buses or entering train stations, typically using designated machines, to avoid fines.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "In many train stations or buses, you’ll see machines marked Validez votre billet. Not validating can lead to hefty fines—even if you bought a valid ticket."
  - Location paragraph 13===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/5/29/french-signs-youll-see-everywhereand-what-they-actually-mean

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: The phrase "Retard prévu" appears on display boards or announcements to inform travelers of anticipated delays in train or flight schedules.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Useful when traveling—particularly by train or flight. You might see a display board showing 'Retard prévu 15 min.' That’s your heads-up."
  - Location paragraph 15===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/5/29/french-signs-youll-see-everywhereand-what-they-actually-mean

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: In transportation settings, "Voie" refers to the track in train stations, while "Quai" denotes the platform, often used in metros or smaller stations; travelers should verify the number to reach the correct location.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Voie (track) is usually used in train stations, while quai (platform) is common in metros or smaller stations. Always double-check the number so you’re not waiting on the wrong side."
  - Location paragraph 16===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/5/29/french-signs-youll-see-everywhereand-what-they-actually-mean

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: This sign prohibits parking in specific areas, which may be permanent or temporary depending on conditions such as market hours or street cleaning schedules.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
