- Quoted text "This one appears frequently, especially in cities with narrow streets. It might be permanent or temporary. Look for accompanying dates/times—it could mean no parking during market hours or street cleaning."
  - Location paragraph 19===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/5/29/french-signs-youll-see-everywhereand-what-they-actually-mean

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: The "Sortie de camions" sign marks an area designated for trucks exiting, often near warehouses or shops with regular deliveries, indicating potential heavy traffic or loading zones.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "You’ll find this near warehouses or shops with regular deliveries. If you park there, your car might get towed. The presence of this sign often means heavy traffic or loading zones—use caution when walking or cycling."
  - Location paragraph 21===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/5/29/french-signs-youll-see-everywhereand-what-they-actually-mean

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: This sign designates car-free streets, commonly found in old towns, tourist areas, and commercial districts, promoting safer and more enjoyable walking environments.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Indicates car-free streets. Common in old towns, tourist areas, and commercial districts. These zones are often lively with performers, open-air cafés, and markets."
  - Location paragraph 23===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/5/29/french-signs-youll-see-everywhereand-what-they-actually-mean

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: This sign marks parking spots reserved for specific users such as residents, delivery vehicles, or disabled drivers, and misuse can result in fines.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "These spots might be for residents, delivery vehicles, or disabled drivers. Misusing them can lead to fines. Look for accompanying icons (wheelchairs, loading symbols) or text clarifying who can use the space."
  - Location paragraph 24===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/5/29/french-signs-youll-see-everywhereand-what-they-actually-mean

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: At a French stop sign, drivers must come to a complete stop with wheels fully stopped just before the bold solid white line painted across the road.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "At a French Stop sign, your vehicle must come to a total stop (wheels should stop turning) just before the solid white line."
  - Location p6===from https://mafrenchlife.com/french-road-signs/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Failing to completely stop at a stop sign in France results in a fine of €135 and the withdrawal of four points from the driver’s license.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "The fine for not completely stopping at a stop sign is €135 along with four points withdrawal on your French driver’s license."
  - Location p6===from https://mafrenchlife.com/french-road-signs/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: French traffic signs primarily use symbols rather than words to convey their meaning, unlike in the United States.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Compared to the United States, traffic signs in France use symbols rather than words to convey their message."
  - Location p2===from https://mafrenchlife.com/french-road-signs/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Speed limits in France are displayed in kilometers per hour (km/h) due to the country's use of the metric system.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Speed limits in France are displayed in kilometers per hour (km/h) because France uses the metric system."
  - Location p5===from https://mafrenchlife.com/french-road-signs/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: When a speed limit sign is placed beneath the entrance sign of a city or village, the speed limit applies to the entire city or village.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "When French speed limit signs are located underneath the entrance sign of a city or a village, the speed limit applies to the whole city or village."
  - Location p5===from https://mafrenchlife.com/french-road-signs/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: In the absence of traffic signs, vehicles entering from the right have priority at intersections.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "When there is no road sign, traffic entering the roadway from the right always has priority (priorité à droite)."
  - Location p10===from https://mafrenchlife.com/french-road-signs/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: The "Route prioritaire" sign indicates a priority road where drivers have right-of-way over traffic coming from both the right and left.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Route prioritaire This is a priority road. You have priority over traffic coming from your right and from your left."
  - Location p10===from https://mafrenchlife.com/french-road-signs/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Temporary road signs in France have a yellow background, differing from permanent warning signs which are triangular with red borders.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "French temporary road signs have a yellow background."
  - Location p14===from https://mafrenchlife.com/french-road-signs/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: A zone sign marks the beginning of a regulated area that typically covers multiple streets, and rules apply throughout the zone until an “end of zone” sign is posted.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "A zone usually includes multiple streets." and "You know you’re exiting a restricted zone when you see one of the following road signs."
  - Location p13, p14===from https://mafrenchlife.com/french-road-signs/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: In designated mountainous regions, winter tires are mandatory from November 1st to March 31st, as indicated by specific signage.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Winter road equipments are mandatory in 48 French departments with mountain areas... Winter law is enforced from November 1st to March 31st."
  - Location p13===from https://mafrenchlife.com/french-road-signs/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: In a "Zone de rencontre," pedestrians may walk on the road, bicycles can travel in both directions, and motor vehicles must not exceed 20 km/h.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "A meeting zone (zone de rencontre) is meant to be a shared space open to everyone. Pedestrians can walk on the road, bikes can go in both directions and motor vehicles cannot go over 20 km/h (around 12mph)."
  - Location p13===from https://mafrenchlife.com/french-road-signs/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Freeway signs in France are blue, whereas in the United States they are green.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "French freeway signs are blue whereas they’re green in the United States."
  - Location p12===from https://mafrenchlife.com/french-road-signs/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Radar enforcement zones may be indicated by signs showing the speed limit at the top, but radars are not required to be signaled by law.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "By law, radars don’t have to be indicated so don’t assume that no sign means no radar." and "The latest radar signs don’t have any text but they show the speed limit at the top of the sign."
  - Location p12===from https://mafrenchlife.com/french-road-signs/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Non-motorized personal mobility device users must use bicycle lanes or paths when available in urban areas.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "in urban areas, non-motorised personal mobility device drivers must use bicycle lanes or paths."
  - Location paragraph 7

- Rule Description When roads are bordered on both sides by bicycle lanes, non-motorized personal mobility device users must use the right-hand lane in the direction of traffic.
- ===from https://www.lexology.com/library/detail.aspx?g=b1670176-0ba5-4e1f-bcae-22be20f81c8d

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Drivers in France are legally required to stop for pedestrians at pedestrian crossings.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Despite what you might sometimes witness on French roads, it IS obligatory for cars to stop for pedestrians at pedestrian crossings."
  - Location paragraph 1===from https://anglophone-direct.com/stopping-pedestrian-crossings-france/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Radar systems with motion detectors are installed at crossings to monitor whether drivers stop for pedestrians, and violations can be confirmed via video review.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Radars with motion detectors are being installed all over France which will activate when a pedestrian wants to cross the road and an approaching vehicle doesn’t stop. The driver will lose 4 points and be fined 135€ if the police municipal find him or her at fault when reviewing the video."
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://anglophone-direct.com/stopping-pedestrian-crossings-france/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Drivers must yield to pedestrians who show a clear intention to cross (e.g., an obvious step forward or hand gesture), unless there is a designated crossing within 50 meters.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Since 2011 drivers and riders are also required to give way to pedestrians crossing a road elsewhere – 'If a pedestrian or cyclist “shows a clear intention to cross” (described as “an ostensible step forward or a hand gesture”) drivers will be required to stop for them. The only exception is where there is a designated pedestrian crossing less than 50m away.'"
  - Location paragraph 3 (comment by jfdi66)===from https://anglophone-direct.com/stopping-pedestrian-crossings-france/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Drivers must yield to vehicles coming from the right at intersections unless a road sign indicates otherwise.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "The “priority to the right” rule applies unless there is another road sign that gives you priority."
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://www.europe-consommateurs.eu/en/travelling-motor-vehicles/motor-vehicles/driving-in-france.html

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: The speed limit on two-way national and departmental roads may be reduced to 80 km/h in certain French departments; drivers must check road signs for the exact limit.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Some French departments have lowered the speed limit on two-way national and departmental roads from 90 km/h to 80 km/h. Approximatively 400 000 km of roads are concerned. Check the road signs to know the exact speed limit."
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://www.europe-consommateurs.eu/en/travelling-motor-vehicles/motor-vehicles/driving-in-france.html

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: In designated "security buffer zones" before pedestrian crossings, drivers must yield to pedestrians who show an intention to cross; failure to comply results in a fine.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "French cities now have the opportunity to establish 'security buffer zones' in front of pedestrian crossings... failure to comply with the new markings or not yielding to pedestrians clearly showing the intention to cross will result in a fixed fine of 35 euros."
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://www.europe-consommateurs.eu/en/travelling-motor-vehicles/motor-vehicles/driving-in-france.html

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Refusing to give way to a pedestrian who is crossing or intends to cross at a marked crosswalk results in a fine of 135 euros, loss of 6 points on the driver’s licence, and possible license suspension.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Since September 2018, refusal to give way to a pedestrian who crosses or shows an intention to cross on a marked pedestrian crosswalk is subject to a fine of 135 euros, a withdrawal of 6 points on the drivers licence, and a license suspension of up to 3 years."
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://www.europe-consommateurs.eu/en/travelling-motor-vehicles/motor-vehicles/driving-in-france.html

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Lane splitting by motorcycles or bikes between stopped or slow-moving cars is being tested as legal in 21 specified French departments from August 2021 to August 2024.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "From August 2021 until August 2024, the French government will test a new law allowing lane splitting in 21 French departments..."
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://www.europe-consommateurs.eu/en/travelling-motor-vehicles/motor-vehicles/driving-in-france.html

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: All vehicle occupants, including those in rear seats, must wear seat belts; failure to do so can result in a 150 € fine.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Safety belts are compulsory for all the occupants of the vehicle that is to say for both front- and rear-seat passengers... In the event of a police check, there will be a fine of 150 € for anyone not wearing a safety belt."
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://www.europe-consommateurs.eu/en/travelling-motor-vehicles/motor-vehicles/driving-in-france.html

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Children under 10 years old must sit in the rear seat and use a seat belt or approved child seat; they are not allowed in the front seat.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Children must be at least 10 years old to sit on the front seat. Under the age of 10, children must be seated in the rear and, as would be the case in the front, use a seat belt or an approved child seat."
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://www.europe-consommateurs.eu/en/travelling-motor-vehicles/motor-vehicles/driving-in-france.html

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Drivers are prohibited from using mobile phones, earphones, or Bluetooth kits while driving; violation can lead to a fine of up to 135 € and loss of 3 points on the driver’s licence.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Mobile telephones may not be used while driving, nor should earphones or Bluetooth kits. In the case of a police check, you may be fined up to 135 € and the loss of 3 points (if you have a French driver’s licence)."
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://www.europe-consommateurs.eu/en/travelling-motor-vehicles/motor-vehicles/driving-in-france.html

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Riders of two-wheeled vehicles with engine sizes exceeding 125 cm³ must wear retro-reflective equipment; failure results in a 68 € fine and loss of 2 points on the driver’s licence.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Since the 1st of January 2013, all users of two-wheeled vehicles for which the engine size exceeds 125 cm3 have to wear specific clothes including retro-reflective equipment (sanction fine of 68 € and loss of 2 points if you have a French driver’s license)."
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://www.europe-consommateurs.eu/en/travelling-motor-vehicles/motor-vehicles/driving-in-france.html

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Vehicles must carry a warning triangle and a fluorescent safety vest for use in case of breakdown or accident; failing to do so can result in a 135 € fine.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Your car has to be equipped with a warning triangle and a fluorescent safety vest for a better visibility in case of breakdown or accident. Note The non-respect of the obligation to have a warning triangle and a reflecting jacket can be fined 135€."
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://www.europe-consommateurs.eu/en/travelling-motor-vehicles/motor-vehicles/driving-in-france.html

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: The legal blood alcohol limit for drivers in France is 0.5 g/l; exceeding this limit can lead to fines, imprisonment, and license seizure.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "France has very strict rules concerning drink-driving; the legal blood alcohol limit is 0,5g/l of blood. If during a police check, your level of alcohol is found at between 0,5 and 0,8 g, you may be fined up to 135 €. If the level exceeds 0,8g/l, the punishment incurred is 2 years in prison and a maximum fine of 4.500 € can be applicable."
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://www.europe-consommateurs.eu/en/travelling-motor-vehicles/motor-vehicles/driving-in-france.html

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Police have the authority to test for drugs, and any trace of illegal drugs can result in penalties including up to 2 years in prison and a 4,500 € fine.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "The police also have the power to search for drugs. The smallest trace of illegal drugs can result in punishment. If banned narcotics are detected, the penalty could include 2 years in prison and a 4.500 € fine."
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://www.europe-consommateurs.eu/en/travelling-motor-vehicles/motor-vehicles/driving-in-france.html

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: If a driver exceeds the legal alcohol limit and drugs are detected, the penalty can include up to 3 years in prison and a 9,000 € fine.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "If the blood alcohol level exceeds the legal limit, and the presence of drugs is detected, the penalty could include 3 years in prison and a 9.000€ fine."
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://www.europe-consommateurs.eu/en/travelling-motor-vehicles/motor-vehicles/driving-in-france.html

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Exceeding the legal alcohol limit may result in the immediate seizure of both the driver’s licence and the vehicle.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "In any case, if the 0,5g/l limit is expired, the driving licence may be seized (up to 3 years) as well as the vehicle."
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://www.europe-consommateurs.eu/en/travelling-motor-vehicles/motor-vehicles/driving-in-france.html

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Drivers must possess a single-use, unused, and immediately available breathalyser; failure to carry one may result in an 11 € fine (though not yet enforced).
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Every driver of a motorized land vehicle, must possess a single-use, unused and immediately available breathalyser ('éthylotest'). A fine of €11 is foreseen to any driver not carrying a breathalyser, but the fine has not yet been applied."
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://www.europe-consommateurs.eu/en/travelling-motor-vehicles/motor-vehicles/driving-in-france.html

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Parking in French cities typically requires payment via ticket machines, smartphone apps, or parking discs ("zones bleues"); free parking times vary by location.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Parking ticket machines ('horodateurs') are common throughout France... In more and more cities, you can use a smartphone parking app... Some cities also operate with disc-parking or 'zones bleues' where you will have to display a parking disc or clock disc showing your time of arrival."
  - Location paragraph 8===from https://www.europe-consommateurs.eu/en/travelling-motor-vehicles/motor-vehicles/driving-in-france.html

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Illegally parked vehicles may receive a post-parking fee (FPS) instead of a fixed fine; the amount varies by commune and must be paid within 3 months or contested online.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "In France there is the post-parking fee (FPS) which replaces the €17 fine for unpaid or insufficiently paid parking. The amount of the FPS varies from one commune to another. It must be paid within 3 months, or you can contest your fine via the government website if a telepayment number appears in the fine received."
  - Location paragraph 8===from https://www.europe-consommateurs.eu/en/travelling-motor-vehicles/motor-vehicles/driving-in-france.html

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Starting October 1, 2024, SUVs over 1.6 metric tons (or 2 tons for electric models) are subject to higher hourly parking rates in Paris, except for residents, disabled individuals, and holders of a mobility inclusion-parking card.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Since October 1st 2024, SUV owners are required to pay 18 euros an hour to park in the 1st to the 11th arrondissements and 12 euros an hour in the 12th to the 20th arrondissements... This tax affects cars, with hybrid or combustion engines, that weigh over 1.6 metric tons. Electric SUVs are also charged if they weigh over 2 tons. Paris residents, individuals with disabilities (reduced mobility), and those holding a mobility inclusion-parking card are exempt from this tax."
  - Location paragraph 8===from https://www.europe-consommateurs.eu/en/travelling-motor-vehicles/motor-vehicles/driving-in-france.html

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Motorcycles, tricycles, and quads registered in France must display a registration plate of the standardized size 210x130 millimetres; noncompliance results in a 135 € fine.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Since July 1st 2017, a new plate size has become compulsory for motor vehicles with two or three wheels and for quads... Users of such vehicles who are found to have nonconforming, illegible, removable or improperly positioned plates, will be fined 135€."
  - Location paragraph 9===from https://www.europe-consommateurs.eu/en/travelling-motor-vehicles/motor-vehicles/driving-in-france.html

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: All vehicles registered in France must transition to the new SIV system with standardized plates (format 2 letters – 3 numbers – 2 letters); full implementation was required before December 31, 2020.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "by 2021, all vehicles registered in France, regardless of their type, will be registered in the new Vehicle Registration System (SIV)... All registration plates should be changed prior to December 31st, 2020."
  - Location paragraph 9===from https://www.europe-consommateurs.eu/en/travelling-motor-vehicles/motor-vehicles/driving-in-france.html

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Visitors may drive in France with a valid license from their home country, and new drivers are on a probationary license for three years (or two years with accompanied driving), during which stricter rules apply.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Visitors can drive in France using a valid licence from their home country. Learning to drive begins from age 17. New drivers remain on a probationary licence for three years (two with accompanied driving), during which stricter limits apply."
  - Location p2===from https://franceforfamilies.com/rules-of-the-road/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Drivers must carry a valid driver’s license, vehicle registration papers, proof of insurance, a reflective safety vest, a warning triangle, and headlamp beam deflectors if driving a right-hand-drive vehicle.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Valid driving licence, Vehicle registration papers, Proof of insurance, Reflective safety vest and warning triangle, Headlamp beam deflectors (for right-hand-drive cars)"
  - Location p3===from https://franceforfamilies.com/rules-of-the-road/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: All passengers must wear seat belts; children under 10 must use an approved child restraint appropriate to their size and weight, and may sit in the front only with proper restraint and disabled airbag when necessary.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Seat belts are compulsory for all passengers. Children under 10 must travel in an approved seat suited to their size and weight. Children may sit in the front seat only with the correct restraint and if the airbag is disabled when required."
  - Location p4===from https://franceforfamilies.com/rules-of-the-road/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: The general speed limits in France are 50 km/h in urban areas (with many now at 30 km/h), 80 km/h on single carriageways (some allow 90 km/h), 110 km/h on dual carriageways (reduced in wet weather), 130 km/h on motorways (110 km/h in rain), and 50 km/h on the Paris Périphérique.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Urban areas 50 km/h... Single carriageways 80 km/h... Dual carriageways 110 km/h... Motorways 130 km/h... Paris Périphérique 50 km/h"
  - Location p5===from https://franceforfamilies.com/rules-of-the-road/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: The legal blood alcohol limit is 0.5 g/L (0.05%) for most drivers, but 0.2 g/L for new drivers; driving under the influence of drugs is a serious criminal offense.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Standard blood alcohol limit 0.5 g/L (0.05%). For new drivers 0.2 g/L. Driving under the influence of drugs is a serious criminal offence."
  - Location p6===from https://franceforfamilies.com/rules-of-the-road/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Using a handheld mobile phone while driving is strictly prohibited, and even hands-free devices must not distract the driver; texting or browsing while driving carries severe penalties.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Using a handheld phone while driving is strictly prohibited. Even hands-free devices must not distract the driver. Texting or browsing while driving carries severe penalties."
  - Location p7===from https://franceforfamilies.com/rules-of-the-road/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Drivers must drive on the right and overtake on the left; the “priorité à droite” rule applies where signposted, meaning vehicles approaching from the right have priority unless otherwise indicated, especially in central Paris roundabouts and rural minor roads.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Drive on the right and overtake on the left. 'Priorité à droite' (priority from the right) still applies at some junctions... officially the rule no longer applies unless clearly signposted... In central Paris you will find that the rule is very much still practiced on roundabouts... on minor roads priorité à droite is still assumed."
  - Location p8===from https://franceforfamilies.com/rules-of-the-road/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Vehicles already on a roundabout usually have priority over those entering.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "At roundabouts, vehicles already on the circle usually have priority."
  - Location p8===from https://franceforfamilies.com/rules-of-the-road/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Controlled lane-splitting for motorcycles is authorized in certain departments under strict safety conditions and subject to local signage.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Controlled lane-splitting for motorcycles is authorised in certain departments under strict safety conditions — check local signage before attempting it."
  - Location p9===from https://franceforfamilies.com/rules-of-the-road/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Low Emission Zones (ZCR) restrict older, more polluting vehicles, requiring a Crit’Air sticker; 30 km/h zones are expanding in major towns; headlights must be used at night, in fog, mist, or poor visibility during the day; and drivers must stop at zebra crossings as it is legally enforced.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Low Emission Zones (ZCR) restrict older, more polluting vehicles — a Crit’Air sticker is required. 30 km/h zones are expanding in major towns. Headlights must of course be used at night, but also in fog, mist or poor visibility during the day. You must stop at Zebra crossings – this is now enforced by law."
  - Location p10===from https://franceforfamilies.com/rules-of-the-road/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Drivers must remain courteous, provide requested documents, and follow police instructions; fines are payable electronically, and officers can verify insurance digitally.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Always remain courteous, provide requested documents, and follow instructions. Fines are now payable electronically; officers can verify insurance digitally."
  - Location p11===from https://franceforfamilies.com/rules-of-the-road/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: French driving culture emphasizes an intuitive, rhythmic flow rather than strict adherence to formal rules, especially in navigating urban and rural roads.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "French driving culture is less about rules and more about rhythm—understand how locals navigate Paris streets, rural roads, and toll highways with confidence and charm."  
  - Location p1===from https://girlsfrance.com/blog/tag/french-driving-culture/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: In Paris, drivers do not strictly follow lane boundaries; instead, they actively create gaps and move fluidly between lanes without waiting for perfect openings.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "It’s the lack of clear lane discipline. Drivers don’t wait for perfect gaps—they create them."  
  - Location p3===from https://girlsfrance.com/blog/tag/french-driving-culture/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: French drivers approach roundabouts dynamically, engaging with them as part of a flowing motion rather than avoiding or yielding rigidly.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Roundabouts aren’t avoided; they’re danced through."  
  - Location p3===from https://girlsfrance.com/blog/tag/french-driving-culture/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: French drivers rarely use horns even when someone delays movement at a green light, relying instead on silent cues like stares.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "And if you’re slow to move at a green light? You’ll hear no honks. Just a long, silent stare."  
  - Location p3===from https://girlsfrance.com/blog/tag/french-driving-culture/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: A key aspect of French road etiquette is yielding to vehicles approaching from the right, particularly at intersections without signals.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "French road etiquette means you yield to the right..."  
  - Location p3===from https://girlsfrance.com/blog/tag/french-driving-culture/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Cutting off another driver is avoided unless eye contact has been established, indicating mutual understanding between drivers.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "...never cut someone off without eye contact..."  
  - Location p3===from https://girlsfrance.com/blog/tag/french-driving-culture/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Even in long lines, French drivers maintain space between vehicles at toll booths rather than tailgating.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "and always leave space at toll booths—even if the line is long."  
  - Location p3===from https://girlsfrance.com/blog/tag/french-driving-culture/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: On rural roads, flashing headlights does not signal permission to proceed but serves as a warning to proceed cautiously.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "On rural roads, flashing headlights don’t mean 'go ahead.' They mean 'I see you, proceed with caution.'"  
  - Location p3===from https://girlsfrance.com/blog/tag/french-driving-culture/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Most French drivers choose small, efficient vehicles like the Citroën C3 or Renault Clio due to urban practicality, not financial constraints.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Most French drivers own compact cars—think Citroën C3 or Renault Clio—not because they can’t afford more, but because they know bigger isn’t better in Paris or Lyon."  
  - Location p4===from https://girlsfrance.com/blog/tag/french-driving-culture/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: French drivers prefer perpendicular parking over parallel because it is faster to execute.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "They park perpendicular, not parallel, because it’s faster."  
  - Location p4===from https://girlsfrance.com/blog/tag/french-driving-culture/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: French drivers typically do not use cruise control on highways, preferring to adjust speed intuitively based on driving conditions.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "They don’t use cruise control on highways—they drive by feel."  
  - Location p4===from https://girlsfrance.com/blog/tag/french-driving-culture/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Many local drivers still use paper maps instead of GPS, believing that the best routes are learned informally rather than through digital navigation.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Locals still use paper maps. Why? Because the best routes aren’t in the app—they’re whispered over café tables."  
  - Location p4===from https://girlsfrance.com/blog/tag/french-driving-culture/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Driving in France is taken very seriously and is considered almost like a national sport.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "The French take driving very seriously. In fact, driving in France is almost a national sport."  
  - Location p2===from https://blogs.transparent.com/french/french-culture-driving-in-france/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Most cars in France come with manual transmission, although automatic options are available for rental.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "While most cars come standard with une boîte de vitesse manuelle you can get des voitures de location avec boîte de vitesse automatique."  
  - Location p3===from https://blogs.transparent.com/french/french-culture-driving-in-france/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: A valid driver’s license is required to rent a car in France.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Of course, pour louer une voiture, you will need a valid permis de conduire."  
  - Location p3===from https://blogs.transparent.com/french/french-culture-driving-in-france/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Rental cars must be returned with a full tank of fuel to avoid additional charges.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "When your adventures are through and you want to return your voiture de location to the agence (the rental agency), you will need to faire le plein to avoid paying extra pour l’essence."  
  - Location p3===from https://blogs.transparent.com/french/french-culture-driving-in-france/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Many vehicles in France use diesel fuel (gazole), so drivers must ensure they use the correct type of fuel.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Many voitures in France use le gazole (or gazoil) so make sure you know and use the right kind of essence."  
  - Location p3===from https://blogs.transparent.com/french/french-culture-driving-in-france/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: France uses automated cameras and radar systems to detect speeding, and drivers are warned by roadside signs about their presence.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "France has a system of automated cameras and radar that will snap a picture of your car if you’re driving too fast! These radars (radars) are signalés (indicated) with road-side signs, so keep your eyes open … or you might get flashé (the term the French use for getting snapped by the radars) and have to pay une amende (a fine)."  
  - Location p5===from https://blogs.transparent.com/french/french-culture-driving-in-france/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: As of June of the year mentioned in the text, the speed limit on many French roads was reduced from 90 km/h to 80 km/h.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "As of June of this year, the speed limit on many French roads has been lowered to 80 km/h (down from 90)."  
  - Location p5===from https://blogs.transparent.com/french/french-culture-driving-in-france/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Passing another vehicle on the right is not done in France and is considered improper driving behavior.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Equally important, do not do what Americans do and pass another car on the right. They just don’t do that here in France (or in other European countries as far as I know)."  
  - Location p7===from https://blogs.transparent.com/french/french-culture-driving-in-france/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: The fast lane should only be used for passing other vehicles, after which drivers should move back to the right to allow others to pass.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Use it only to pass and then promptly move back over out of the way."  
  - Location p7===from https://blogs.transparent.com/french/french-culture-driving-in-france/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Parking on the street is only permitted in designated areas, and unauthorized parking on convenient corners is discouraged.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Parking in France is not as challenging as in some other European cities. However, you should avoid leaving your car on a convenient corner parking is only allowed in designated areas on the street or in parking lots."  
  - Location p1

---

- Rule Description Street parking may alternate sides of the road based on the date—odd-numbered days allow parking on one side, even-numbered days on the other, known as “stationnement alterné semi-mensuel.”  
- ===from https://french-trip.com/info/transport-in-france/france-by-car/parking-in-france/

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: In many towns, parking is allowed on one side of the street (odd-numbered houses) during the first half of the month and on the opposite side (even-numbered houses) during the second half, known as stationnement alterné semi-mensuel.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "In many towns, parking is permitted on one side of the street (the side with odd-numbered houses) for the first half of the month and on the ‘even’ side for the second half of the month."
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://www.justlanded.com/english/France/Articles/Travel-Leisure/Parking

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Some areas implement weekly or daily alternating parking rules, indicated by signs specifying “Côté du Stationnement – Jours Pairs” (even days) or “Jours Impairs” (odd days).
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Parking may also alternate weekly or daily; parking on alternate days is indicated by a sign stating ‘Côté du Stationnement – Jours Pairs’ (even) or ‘Jours Impairs’ (odd)."
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://www.justlanded.com/english/France/Articles/Travel-Leisure/Parking

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: In Paris, parking may be prohibited on certain sides of streets at specific times, such as during street cleaning hours.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "In Paris, signs may indicate that parking is forbidden on one side of the street at certain times (e.g. for street cleaning)."
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://www.justlanded.com/english/France/Articles/Travel-Leisure/Parking

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: On-street parking is not allowed in many central streets of Paris and other cities.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "On-street parking is forbidden in many streets in the centre of Paris and other cities."
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://www.justlanded.com/english/France/Articles/Travel-Leisure/Parking

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Parking is banned on main access routes in Paris designated as red routes (axe rouge).
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Parking is forbidden in Paris on main access routes, designated as red routes (axe rouge)."
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://www.justlanded.com/english/France/Articles/Travel-Leisure/Parking

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: The phrase “Stationnement interdit” or a “P” with a line through it indicates that parking is strictly forbidden.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "‘Stationnement interdit’ means parking is forbidden and may be accompanied by the sign of a ‘P’ with a line through it."
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://www.justlanded.com/english/France/Articles/Travel-Leisure/Parking

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Vehicles parked in obstructive locations like taxi ranks or in front of private garages may be towed away, as indicated by a “Stationnement gênant” sign showing a tow truck.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "No parking may be indicated by a ‘Stationnement gênant’ sign with a picture of a lorry towing away a vehicle (if you park in a taxi rank or in front of a private garage, you’re likely to find your car towed away...)"
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://www.justlanded.com/english/France/Articles/Travel-Leisure/Parking

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Yellow kerb markings are used to indicate areas where parking is not permitted.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "No parking may be indicated by a ‘Stationnement gênant’ sign with a picture of a lorry towing away a vehicle [...] or by yellow kerb markings."
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://www.justlanded.com/english/France/Articles/Travel-Leisure/Parking

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: It is illegal to park in front of a fire hydrant anywhere in France.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "It’s forbidden to park in front of a fire hydrant."
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://www.justlanded.com/english/France/Articles/Travel-Leisure/Parking

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: In Paris, it is illegal to leave a car parked on the same public road spot for more than 24 hours.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "In Paris, it’s illegal to leave a car in the same spot on a public road for more than 24 hours."
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://www.justlanded.com/english/France/Articles/Travel-Leisure/Parking

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Parking a caravan on roads is completely prohibited at all times in Paris and some other cities.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Parking a caravan on roads is forbidden at any time in Paris and some other towns and cities..."
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://www.justlanded.com/english/France/Articles/Travel-Leisure/Parking

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Overnight parking in lay-bys is not allowed anywhere in France, though short stops for rest are permitted if drivers are drowsy.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "...overnight parking in a lay-by isn’t permitted anywhere in France, although you can stop for a rest if you’re falling asleep at the wheel."
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://www.justlanded.com/english/France/Articles/Travel-Leisure/Parking

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: On roads outside town limits, drivers must pull off the road entirely when stopping.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "On roads outside town limits, you must pull off the road to stop."
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://www.justlanded.com/english/France/Articles/Travel-Leisure/Parking

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: In blue zones (zone bleue), free parking is allowed for one hour between 0900–1200 and 1400/1430–1900 on weekdays, with no restrictions outside these hours or on Sundays and holidays.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Here you can park free for one hour between 09.00 and 12.00 and from 14.00 or 14.30 until 19.00 from Mondays to Saturdays, with no limit outside these hours or on Sundays and public holidays."
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://www.justlanded.com/english/France/Articles/Travel-Leisure/Parking

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Drivers must display a parking disc (disque de contrôle/stationnement) in the windshield when parking in blue zones to show arrival time.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "You must display a parking disc (disque de contrôle/stationnement) in your windscreen."
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://www.justlanded.com/english/France/Articles/Travel-Leisure/Parking

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Exceeding the allowed parking time in a blue zone can result in a fine.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "If you overstay your free time, you can be fined."
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://www.justlanded.com/english/France/Articles/Travel-Leisure/Parking

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Where signs indicate “Horodateur” or “Stationnement payant,” drivers must obtain a ticket from a machine and display it visibly behind the windshield.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "If a parking sign has the word ‘Horodateur’ beneath it or there’s a ‘Stationnement payant’ sign, perhaps with ‘Payant’ also marked on the road, it means that you must obtain a ticket from a nearby machine."
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://www.justlanded.com/english/France/Articles/Travel-Leisure/Parking

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Paid parking typically applies from 0900 to 1900, excluding lunchtime (1200–1400), with hourly rates ranging from €0.65 to €1, higher at stations.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Parking must usually be paid for between 09.00 and 19.00, although it’s free from 12.00 to 14.00 [...] The cost is around €0.65 to €1 per hour (more at railway stations)."
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://www.justlanded.com/english/France/Articles/Travel-Leisure/Parking

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Parking ticket machines usually accept coins (5c to €2) and sometimes banknotes and cards.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Machines usually accept 5 cent, 10 cent, 20 cent, 50 cent, €1 and €2 coins."
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://www.justlanded.com/english/France/Articles/Travel-Leisure/Parking

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: In most car parks, drivers must pay before retrieving their vehicle, either at a cashier or machine, and cannot pay at the exit.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "You must pay before collecting your car, either at a cash desk (caisse) or in a machine and cannot pay at the exit."
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://www.justlanded.com/english/France/Articles/Travel-Leisure/Parking

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: After payment in a car park, drivers usually have about 15 minutes to reach the exit and leave.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "After paying, you usually have around 15 minutes to find the exit, where you insert your ticket in a machine and hope the barrier rises."
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://www.justlanded.com/english/France/Articles/Travel-Leisure/Parking

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Local residents can obtain reduced parking fees by getting a permit from the town hall and displaying it on the right side of the windshield.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "In most cities, local residents can pay reduced parking fees by obtaining a permit from the local town hall. This must be affixed to the right-hand side of your windscreen."
  - Location paragraph 8===from https://www.justlanded.com/english/France/Articles/Travel-Leisure/Parking

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Subscription cards for ticket machines are available to residents and commuters in most cities to reduce parking costs.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Subscription cards for ticket machines are also available for residents and commuters in most cities."
  - Location paragraph 8===from https://www.justlanded.com/english/France/Articles/Travel-Leisure/Parking

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Disabled drivers are entitled to free or reserved parking in most towns, shopping centers, and airports, provided they display an official disabled badge (macaron) in the windshield.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Disabled motorists are provided with free or reserved parking in most towns, shopping centres and at airports, but they must display an official disabled motorist’s badge (macaron) inside their windscreen."
  - Location paragraph 8===from https://www.justlanded.com/english/France/Articles/Travel-Leisure/Parking

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Disabled drivers can obtain a carte européenne de stationnement, which grants them parking privileges across Europe.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Disabled drivers can also obtain a European parking card (carte européenne de stationnement) entitling them to disabled parking privileges throughout Europe."
  - Location paragraph 8===from https://www.justlanded.com/english/France/Articles/Travel-Leisure/Parking

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Fines for illegal parking range from €35 to €135 depending on severity, increasing to €75–€375 if unpaid after three months.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Fines for illegal parking are €35, €68 or €135, which increase to €75, €180 and €375 respectively if they aren’t paid within three months."
  - Location paragraph 9===from https://www.justlanded.com/english/France/Articles/Travel-Leisure/Parking

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Not paying or overstaying in a legal parking spot incurs a €11 fine, rising to €33 if unpaid after three months.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Throughout France you’re fined around €11 for not paying or for overstaying your time in a legal parking spot, which increases to €33 if the fine isn’t paid within three months."
  - Location paragraph 9===from https://www.justlanded.com/english/France/Articles/Travel-Leisure/Parking

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Parking fines can be paid using a fiscal stamp (timbre fiscal) purchased from a tobacconist or online since January 2006.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Parking fines can often be paid by buying a fiscal stamp (timbre fiscal) from a tobacconist’s [...] Since January 2006, it has been possible to pay them online..."
  - Location paragraph 9===from https://www.justlanded.com/english/France/Articles/Travel-Leisure/Parking

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Drivers may arrange a payment schedule instead of paying a large fine in a single lump sum.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "You can usually agree a payment schedule for a large fine, rather than pay it in a lump sum."
  - Location paragraph 9===from https://www.justlanded.com/english/France/Articles/Travel-Leisure/Parking

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: If a vehicle receives a ticket (papillon) and is not moved within one hour, a second ticket may be issued; after two hours, the car may be clamped or towed.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "If your car is given a ticket (papillon) and isn’t moved within an hour, it will be given a second ticket and after two hours a wheel clamp may be fitted or it may be towed way."
  - Location paragraph 10===from https://www.justlanded.com/english/France/Articles/Travel-Leisure/Parking

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: In addition to fines (€35–€135), drivers must pay release and daily storage fees to retrieve a towed vehicle; unclaimed vehicles may be sold after 10–45 days.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "In addition to a parking fine of between €35 and €135 you must also pay a fee to release your car from a pound (or to have a clamp removed), plus a daily storage charge. However, if you don’t collect your car within 10 to 45 days it may be sold..."
  - Location paragraph 10===from https://www.justlanded.com/english/France/Articles/Travel-Leisure/Parking

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: In urban areas of France, parking is only permitted in white-marked parking spaces.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Parking is strict in urban areas and only permitted in white parking spaces."
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://www.car-parking.eu/france

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: On-street parking is time-limited, whereas parking in car parks is unlimited.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Parking is limited on street and unlimited in car parks."
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://www.car-parking.eu/france

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Parking fees in car parks are higher than those for on-street parking.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "The rates in car parks are higher than on the street."
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://www.car-parking.eu/france

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Parking is not allowed in no-parking zones or during restricted hours, and violating these rules may lead to fines or towing.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Be aware of any parking restrictions in the area where you're parked, such as no-parking zones or restrictions for certain times of day. Violating these restrictions can result in fines or even towing."
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://www.car-parking.eu/france

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: White lines delineate spaces where paid parking is required.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "White lines paid parking."
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://www.car-parking.eu/france

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Only commercial and official vehicles may park in areas marked by yellow lines; however, passenger drop-off and pick-up are still permitted.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Yellow lines commercial and official vehicles only. Drop off or pick up passengers is still allowed."
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://www.car-parking.eu/france

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Parking is prohibited along AXES ROUGES (red routes) in central Paris.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Parking is forbidden in the centre of Paris along AXES ROUGES (red routes)."
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://www.car-parking.eu/france

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: In blue zones, parking is free for one hour during paid parking hours, provided a parking disc (disque de contrôle/stationnement) is displayed in the windshield; outside of paid hours, parking is unrestricted.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Parking is free for 1 hour in the blue zones during paid parking hours and unrestricted in all other hours. For parking here you must display a parking disc (disque de contrôle/stationnement) in your windscreen."
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://www.car-parking.eu/france

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: Disabled drivers may park without payment in spaces reserved for card holders and in paid parking areas.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "Without payment you may park at spaces reserved for card holders only and on paid parking places."
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://www.car-parking.eu/france

Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.feature: In many areas, disabled drivers may exceed the time limit in locations where parking is free but normally restricted by time.
Regulation_and_Policy-Transportation Rul.original:
- Quoted text "In many areas, you may exceed the time limit on a road where parking is free but is restricted by time."
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://www.car-parking.eu/france

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Date O.feature: In French, the standard order for writing or saying a date is day (in numbers) followed by month (in letters) and then year (in numbers).
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Date O.original:
- Quoted text "To say the date in French, we usually use the following order day (in numbers) + month (in letters) + years (in numbers)."
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://francais.lingolia.com/en/vocabulary/numbers-dates-time/dates-days-months

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Date O.feature: The definite article "le" is used before the complete date expression in French.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Date O.original:
- Quoted text "To say the complete date, we use the article le."
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://francais.lingolia.com/en/vocabulary/numbers-dates-time/dates-days-months

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Date O.feature: When including the day of the week in a date expression, it follows the article "le" and comes before the numerical day and month.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Date O.original:
- Quoted text "The day of the week comes after le and before the date."
  - Location paragraph 8===from https://francais.lingolia.com/en/vocabulary/numbers-dates-time/dates-days-months

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Date O.feature: The preposition "en" or the phrase "au mois de" is used to introduce months, and "en" is always used to introduce years.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Date O.original:
- Quoted text "We introduce the months with the preposition en or the phrase au mois de." and "The year is always introduced by the preposition en."
  - Location paragraphs 9 and 10===from https://francais.lingolia.com/en/vocabulary/numbers-dates-time/dates-days-months

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Date O.feature: In French, dates are always written in the order of day, then month, then year, both in numerical and word form. The month never comes first, and the day can be written with or without a leading zero.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Date O.original:
- Quoted text "French always writes dates in day / month / year order, both in words and numbers. The month never goes first. You can write the day with or without a leading zero."
  - Location paragraph 23===from https://lingopie.com/blog/date-and-time-in-french/

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Date O.feature: When saying a full date in French, the structure is fixed start with "le", followed by the weekday (if included), then the day of the month, the month, and finally the year. The weekday must come right after "le" and before the number if used.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Date O.original:
- Quoted text "When you say a full date in French, you stack the pieces in one fixed order... You start with le, then the day of the month, then the month, and finally the year. If you want to include the weekday, it sits right after le, before the number."
  - Location paragraph 10===from https://lingopie.com/blog/date-and-time-in-french/

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Date O.feature: In French dates, the first day of the month is expressed as "le premier" instead of "le un", while all other days use regular cardinal numbers.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Date O.original:
- Quoted text "The only exception is the first day of the month, which becomes le premier. Every other day uses the standard number. You place the number directly after le."
  - Location paragraph 18===from https://lingopie.com/blog/date-and-time-in-french/

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Date O.feature: In French, the date is expressed in the order of day (in numbers), followed by month (in letters), and then year (in numbers).
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Date O.original:
- Quoted text "To say the date in French, we usually use the following order ☞  day (in numbers) + month (in letters) + years (in numbers)."
  - Location p3===from https://pressbooks.pub/introductiontofrench1/chapter/9-dates/

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Date O.feature: The article "le" is used before stating the complete date in French.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Date O.original:
- Quoted text "To say the complete date, we use the article le."
  - Location p4===from https://pressbooks.pub/introductiontofrench1/chapter/9-dates/

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Date O.feature: The day of the week is placed after "le" and before the date when stating the full date.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Date O.original:
- Quoted text "The day of the week comes after le and before the date."
  - Location p5===from https://pressbooks.pub/introductiontofrench1/chapter/9-dates/

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Date O.feature: In French, days of the week and months are written in lowercase, unlike in English.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Date O.original:
- Quoted text "In contrast to English, days and months are not capitalised in French, they are written with a lowercase letter."
  - Location p2===from https://pressbooks.pub/introductiontofrench1/chapter/9-dates/

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Separa.feature: In French, a space—preferably a nonbreaking space to prevent pagination issues—is used before and after most punctuation marks.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Separa.original:
- Quoted text "French uses a space, ideally a nonbreaking space to avoid pagination issues, before and after most punctuation."  
  - Location paragraph 1===from https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/globalization/internationalization/punctuation-separators

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Separa.feature: In the French cultural context, a comma is used as the decimal separator (radix character), and a space is used to separate groups of thousands in large numbers.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Separa.original:
- Quoted text "Many other countries use a comma instead [to indicate the decimal place]."  
  - Location p2  

  - Quoted text "Table 1-3 shows some commonly used numeric formats."  
  - Location p2  

  - Quoted text "French 4 294 967 295,000"  
  - Location p3 (Table 1-3)===from https://docs.oracle.com/cd/E19455-01/806-0169/overview-9/index.html

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Separa.feature: The French cultural locale (fr-FR) uses the narrow no-break space (U+202F) as the thousands separator in number formatting, particularly for currency grouping.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Separa.original:
- Quoted text "The French locale now uses narrow no-break space U+202F is [sic] several places as the numeric grouping separator, in many short unit patterns, and in the locale display name patterns."
  - Location paragraph 14===from https://haacked.com/archive/2020/05/17/french-thousand-separator-mystery/

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Separa.feature: The Unicode Consortium updated the French locale to use U+202F (narrow no-break space) instead of U+00A0 (no-break space) for the numeric grouping separator, effective around October 2018.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Separa.original:
- Quoted text "It turns out that sometime in October 2018, the Unicode Consortium changed the thousands separator character for the French locale."
  - Location paragraph 13===from https://haacked.com/archive/2020/05/17/french-thousand-separator-mystery/

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Separa.feature: In most European countries, a comma is used as the decimal separator to distinguish the integer part from the decimal part of a number.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Separa.original:
- Quoted text "In most European countries, a comma is used to separate the integral part of a number from the decimal part."
  - Location p10===from https://www.languageediting.com/number-formatting-europe-vs-us/

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Separa.feature: In most European countries, either a dot or a thin space is used as the thousands separator when writing large numbers, with digit groups separated every three places.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Separa.original:
- Quoted text "When writing large numbers (tens of thousands or more), in most European countries either a dot or a thin space is used to separate groups of three digits—counting from both the left and the right of the decimal separator."
  - Location p17===from https://www.languageediting.com/number-formatting-europe-vs-us/

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Separa.feature: A comma is generally not used as a thousands separator in most European countries because it would cause confusion with its primary use as the decimal separator.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Separa.original:
- Quoted text "Whether a dot or a space is used differs by country, but in most European countries a comma is generally not used for this purpose. That would be confusing, because the comma is the most commonly used decimal separator in Europe."
  - Location p18===from https://www.languageediting.com/number-formatting-europe-vs-us/

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Separa.feature: The International System of Units (SI) accepts either a comma or a dot (point on the line) as the decimal marker, depending on customary usage in the context.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Separa.original:
- Quoted text "In the SI System, the decimal marker is either the comma or the dot, to be more precise, the point on the line. 'The decimal marker chosen should be that which is customary in the context concerned.'"
  - Location p16===from https://www.languageediting.com/number-formatting-europe-vs-us/

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Separa.feature: According to the International System of Units, large numbers can be grouped into sets of three digits using a thin space for readability; commas or dots must not be used for digit grouping.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Separa.original:
- Quoted text "According to the International System of Units, to facilitate reading, numbers with many digits (usually, at least five before or after the decimal marker) can be divided in groups of three digits by inserting a thin space. No periods or commas should be used to group digits."
  - Location p20===from https://www.languageediting.com/number-formatting-europe-vs-us/

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Year F.feature: The year is written in full without apostrophes and follows the day and month in a day-month-year order.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Year F.original:
- Quoted text "Never use apostrophes for years write 2024, not '24"
  - Location paragraph 8===from https://lecon.ai/blog/writing-dates-in-french-formats-pitfalls-examples

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Year F.feature: In numeric formats, the year appears last in the sequence day/month/year, and can be separated by slashes, periods, or hyphens depending on context.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Year F.original:
- Quoted text "When writing dates numerically, French uses day/month/year 15/03/2024 or 15.03.2024. For official documents, use the format 15-03-2024 with hyphens."
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://lecon.ai/blog/writing-dates-in-french-formats-pitfalls-examples

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Year F.feature: When writing out full dates, the year follows the month without any punctuation or commas.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Year F.original:
- Quoted text "Complete dates include the article le before the day le 15 mars 2024. Month names are never capitalized unless they start a sentence."
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://lecon.ai/blog/writing-dates-in-french-formats-pitfalls-examples

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Year F.feature: The preposition "en" is used when referring to a specific year in a sentence.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Year F.original:
- Quoted text "Years use en en 2024 (in 2024)."
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://lecon.ai/blog/writing-dates-in-french-formats-pitfalls-examples

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Year F.feature: The year is written after the day and month in French date notation, following a day-month-year structure.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Year F.original:
- Quoted text "The preferred structure is always day, month, and then the year."
  - Location p7===from https://frenchassistant.com/how-to-write-date-in-french/

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Year F.feature: Including the year in a date is important for clarity, especially in formal writing or when scheduling events.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Year F.original:
- Quoted text "The year is crucial for clarity, especially in formal writing or when scheduling events."
  - Location p7===from https://frenchassistant.com/how-to-write-date-in-french/

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Year F.feature: In formal writing, the date should include the article "le" followed by the day, spelled-out month, and year.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Year F.original:
- Quoted text "To officially write a date in French, it’s important to include the article 'le.' For example, you would write it as 'le 14 octobre 2024.'"
  - Location p13===from https://frenchassistant.com/how-to-write-date-in-french/

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Year F.feature: The year in French date format is typically written in full as four digits (YYYY), though it can be shortened to the last two digits in informal contexts, similar to usage in the U.S.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Year F.original:
- Quoted text "People sometimes shorten the year to the last two digits like we do in the U.S."  
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://www.ouiinfrance.com/how-do-french-write-dates/

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Year F.feature: When pronouncing the year in French, such as 2023, it is said as "deux-mille-vingt-trois" (two thousand twenty-three), not broken into "vingt vingt-trois" (twenty twenty-three).
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Year F.original:
- Quoted text "When saying the year 2023, it’s typically said deux-mille-vingt-trois (which is two thousand twenty three. You do not say vingt vingt-trois (20, 23)."  
  - Location paragraph 8===from https://www.ouiinfrance.com/how-do-french-write-dates/

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Month.feature: French month names are not capitalized unless they appear at the beginning of a sentence, unlike in English.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Month.original:
- Quoted text "The French months of the year do NOT start with a capital letter as in English (unless they are at the beginning of a sentence)."
  - Location p7===from https://www.woodwardfrench.com/lesson/months-of-the-year-in-french/

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Month.feature: The preposition "en" is used to indicate that an event occurs during a specific month.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Month.original:
- Quoted text "If you want to say IN a certain month, you use the french word EN followed by the month."
  - Location p14===from https://www.woodwardfrench.com/lesson/months-of-the-year-in-french/

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Month.feature: The month "August" can be spelled either "août" (traditional) or "aout" (rectified spelling from 1990), with the latter now considered standard in school materials since 2016.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Month.original:
- Quoted text "août = orthographe traditionnelle – traditional spelling aout = orthographe rectifiée de 1990 – rectified spelling as of 1990 The proposed change was upgraded from optional to standard and for use in school books by the Académie française in 2016."
  - Location p12–p13===from https://www.woodwardfrench.com/lesson/months-of-the-year-in-french/

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Month.feature: In French, the names of months are not capitalized, unlike in English.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Month.original:
- Quoted text "Unlike in English, months of the year in French are not capitalized."
  - Location p6===from https://www.transtle.com/french/french-a1/months-of-the-year-in-french/

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Month.feature: To state the current month, the impersonal expression "c’est" is used followed directly by the month name.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Month.original:
- Quoted text "To simply state what month it is, use the impersonal expression c’est (it is) followed directly by the month."
  - Location p7===from https://www.transtle.com/french/french-a1/months-of-the-year-in-french/

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Month.feature: When indicating that an event occurs in a particular month, the preposition "en" is used before the month name.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Month.original:
- Quoted text "When indicating that an event occurs or will occur in a certain month, use the preposition en (in) before the month."
  - Location p8===from https://www.transtle.com/french/french-a1/months-of-the-year-in-french/

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Month.feature: When referring to a specific date (a particular day within a month), the definite article "le" is used before the day number, not "en".
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Month.original:
- Quoted text "When you refer to a specific date (a particular day within a month), you must use the definite article le (the) before the number of the day, not 'en'."
  - Location p9===from https://www.transtle.com/french/french-a1/months-of-the-year-in-french/

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Month.feature: In French, the names of months are not capitalized unless they appear at the beginning of a sentence.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Month.original:
- Quoted text "Months in French are not capitalized unless they appear at the beginning of a sentence"  
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://fiveable.me/french-i/unit-5/months-year-date-expressions/study-guide/2TGGnViWYPScva7F

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Month.feature: When expressing dates in French, the order is day, month, year, which differs from the American English format.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Month.original:
- Quoted text "When writing the date, the order in French is day, month, year"  
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://fiveable.me/french-i/unit-5/months-year-date-expressions/study-guide/2TGGnViWYPScva7F

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Month.feature: The preposition "le" is used before the cardinal number when referring to a specific date, regardless of the month's gender.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Month.original:
- Quoted text "In French, the preposition 'le' is used before the cardinal number when expressing a specific date"  
  - Location paragraph 3  
  - Quoted text "The preposition 'le' is always used regardless of the gender of the month"  
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://fiveable.me/french-i/unit-5/months-year-date-expressions/study-guide/2TGGnViWYPScva7F

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Month.feature: The ordinal form "1er" is used specifically for the first day of the month, while cardinal numbers are used for all other days.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Month.original:
- Quoted text "Ordinal numbers (e.g., 1er, 2ème) are used only for the first day of the month"  
  - Location paragraph 5  
  - Quoted text "Example 'le 1er mai' means 'on May 1st'"  
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://fiveable.me/french-i/unit-5/months-year-date-expressions/study-guide/2TGGnViWYPScva7F

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Month.feature: The preposition "en" is used before months and seasons when referring to a general time period, without specifying a particular date.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Month.original:
- Quoted text "The preposition 'en' is used before months when no specific date is mentioned"  
  - Location paragraph 6  
  - Quoted text "'En' is also used before the names of seasons"  
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://fiveable.me/french-i/unit-5/months-year-date-expressions/study-guide/2TGGnViWYPScva7F

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Month.feature: The preposition "au" is used before masculine singular months when emphasizing a specific event or time period within that month.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Month.original:
- Quoted text "The preposition 'au' is used before masculine singular months when referring to a specific event or time period"  
  - Location paragraph 7  
  - Quoted text "'Au' is used to emphasize a specific month or time frame"  
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://fiveable.me/french-i/unit-5/months-year-date-expressions/study-guide/2TGGnViWYPScva7F

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Natura.feature: In French, days of the week and months of the year are written in lowercase letters, not capitalized.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Natura.original:
- Quoted text "In contrast to English, days and months are not capitalised in French, they are written with a lowercase letter."
  - Location p2===from https://francais.lingolia.com/en/vocabulary/numbers-dates-time/dates-days-months
