Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Natura.feature: French uses cardinal numbers to express dates, except for the first day of the month, where the ordinal number "le premier" is used.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Natura.original:
- Quoted text "In French, we use cardinal numbers to talk about the date. The exception to this is the first of the month, here we use the ordinal number le premier."
  - Location p2===from https://francais.lingolia.com/en/vocabulary/numbers-dates-time/dates-days-months

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Natura.feature: The standard date format in French follows the order day (in numbers), then month (in letters), then year (in numbers).
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Natura.original:
- Quoted text "To say the date in French, we usually use the following order day (in numbers) + month (in letters) + years (in numbers)."
  - Location p4===from https://francais.lingolia.com/en/vocabulary/numbers-dates-time/dates-days-months

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Natura.feature: The definite article "le" is used when stating the full date in French.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Natura.original:
- Quoted text "To say the complete date, we use the article le."
  - Location p5===from https://francais.lingolia.com/en/vocabulary/numbers-dates-time/dates-days-months

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Natura.feature: When including the day of the week in a date, it comes after "le" and before the numerical date.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Natura.original:
- Quoted text "The day of the week comes after le and before the date."
  - Location p6===from https://francais.lingolia.com/en/vocabulary/numbers-dates-time/dates-days-months

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Natura.feature: The prepositions "en" or the phrase "au mois de" are used to introduce months in French.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Natura.original:
- Quoted text "We introduce the months with the preposition en or the phrase au mois de."
  - Location p7===from https://francais.lingolia.com/en/vocabulary/numbers-dates-time/dates-days-months

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Natura.feature: The preposition "en" is always used to introduce the year in French.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Natura.original:
- Quoted text "The year is always introduced by the preposition en."
  - Location p9===from https://francais.lingolia.com/en/vocabulary/numbers-dates-time/dates-days-months

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Calend.feature: In French date notation, the day comes before the month and the year.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Calend.original:
- Quoted text "Dates in French are written with the day preceding the month and the year..."  
  - Location p1===from https://cards.algoreducation.com/en/content/R_wPrlYx/french-date-time-guide

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Calend.feature: The names of days and months in French are not capitalized unless they appear at the beginning of a sentence.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Calend.original:
- Quoted text "The names of days and months are not capitalized unless they start a sentence."  
  - Location p1===from https://cards.algoreducation.com/en/content/R_wPrlYx/french-date-time-guide

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Calend.feature: The first day of a month is expressed as 'le premier' instead of 'le 1'.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Calend.original:
- Quoted text "The first day of the month is referred to as 'le premier' instead of 'le 1.'"  
  - Location p3===from https://cards.algoreducation.com/en/content/R_wPrlYx/french-date-time-guide

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Calend.feature: When articulating dates in French, the day of the week (if used) comes first, followed by the numerical day, then the month, and optionally the year after 'de l’année'.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Calend.original:
- Quoted text "Articulating dates in French follows a specific sequence. The day of the week is mentioned first if needed, followed by the numerical day and then the month. The year is included after 'de l’année' when relevant."  
  - Location p3===from https://cards.algoreducation.com/en/content/R_wPrlYx/french-date-time-guide

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Calend.feature: In France, dates are written in the order of day, month, then year, without commas or other separators.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Calend.original:
- Quoted text "Unlike the Month, Day, Year trinity of American dates, French starts with the day, then the month, and then the year. We write all three in a row, without commas or any other separator."
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://www.frenchpod101.com/blog/2019/12/20/dates-in-french/

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Calend.feature: In formal contexts, the word "le" is used when stating the date, as part of the structure "Nous sommes le + day + month + year."
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Calend.original:
- Quoted text "In formal situations, giving dates in French can be done one of the following two ways Nous sommes + day of the week + le + day’s number () + month + year. Nous sommes + le +  + month + year."
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://www.frenchpod101.com/blog/2019/12/20/dates-in-french/

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Calend.feature: In informal situations, dates can be expressed using "C’est" or "On est" followed by the day of the week, "le," and then the date.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Calend.original:
- Quoted text "In informal situations, expressing dates in French will look like this C’est + day of the week + le +  + month + year. On est + day of the week + le +  + month + year."
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://www.frenchpod101.com/blog/2019/12/20/dates-in-french/

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Calend.feature: When writing dates on formal documents or letters, the format includes the day of the week, followed by "le," the date, month, and year.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Calend.original:
- Quoted text "To write dates in French on formal documents or letters, we use the following structure Day of the week + le +  + month + year."
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://www.frenchpod101.com/blog/2019/12/20/dates-in-french/

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Calend.feature: A condensed numerical format for dates is used, structured as DD/MM/YY, reflecting the day/month/year order.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Calend.original:
- Quoted text "It looks like this  DD/MM/YY"
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://www.frenchpod101.com/blog/2019/12/20/dates-in-french/

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Calend.feature: In French, cardinal numbers are used for most days of the month, except for the first day, which uses the ordinal "premier."
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Calend.original:
- Quoted text "In French, all days use regular numbers, except for the first day of the month. Le premier mai 'The first of May' Le deux mai 'The second of May'"
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://www.frenchpod101.com/blog/2019/12/20/dates-in-french/

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Calend.feature: The French names of the days of the week and months are taught as foundational elements when introducing the calendar in French class.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Calend.original:
- Quoted text "Begin by introducing the French names of the days of the week and the months."
  - Location p2===from https://www.thefrenchnook.ca/2023/08/teaching-calendar-in-french-class.html

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Calend.feature: Each season is associated with specific months, weather changes, activities, and holidays in the context of teaching the French calendar.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Calend.original:
- Quoted text "Explain the unique characteristics of each season and the corresponding months. Engage students in discussions about weather changes, typical activities, and holidays associated with each season."
  - Location p3===from https://www.thefrenchnook.ca/2023/08/teaching-calendar-in-french-class.html

Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Calend.feature: Significant cultural dates and celebrations in French-speaking countries, such as national holidays and regional festivals, are included in calendar instruction to deepen cultural understanding.
Regulation_and_Policy-Date Format-Calend.original:
- Quoted text "Introduce significant dates and celebrations that hold cultural importance in French-speaking countries. Highlight national holidays, regional festivals, and other events observed throughout the year. Discuss the traditions associated with each celebration to deepen cultural understanding."
  - Location p6===from https://www.thefrenchnook.ca/2023/08/teaching-calendar-in-french-class.html

Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-M.feature: France officially adopted the metric system after the French Revolution, replacing the inconsistent and regionally variable pre-revolutionary measurement system.
Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-M.original:
- Quoted text "France used a system of measures that had many of the characteristics of the modern Imperial System of units but with no unified system... During the revolutionary era and motivated in part by the inhomogeneity of the old system, France switched to the first version of the metric system."
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://everything.explained.today/Old_weights_and_measures_(France)/

Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-M.feature: The metric system was legally established in 1795 with defined units for length, area, volume, and mass based on decimal principles and natural standards.
Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-M.original:
- Quoted text "The metric system of measure was first given a legal basis in 1795 by the French Revolutionary government. Article 5 of the law of 18 Germinal, Year III (7 April 1795) defined five units of measure."
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://everything.explained.today/Old_weights_and_measures_(France)/

Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-M.feature: Between 1812 and 1837, France used "mesures usuelles," where traditional unit names were restored but redefined in terms of metric units (e.g., the livre was set to exactly 500 g).
Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-M.original:
- Quoted text "Between 1812 and 1837, the country used the mesures usuelles – traditional names were restored, but the corresponding quantities were based on metric units for example, the livre (pound) became exactly 500 g."
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://everything.explained.today/Old_weights_and_measures_(France)/

Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-M.feature: As of 1 May 1840, the metric system was reinstated as the sole legal system of measurement in France, ending the use of mesures usuelles in official contexts.
Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-M.original:
- Quoted text "La loi du 4 juillet 1837 (the law of 4 July 1837) of the July Monarchy effectively revoked the use of mesures usuelles by reaffirming the laws of measurement of 1795 and 1799 to be used from 1 May 1840."
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://everything.explained.today/Old_weights_and_measures_(France)/

Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-M.feature: In 1875, France led the establishment of the Treaty of the Metre, creating international institutions to standardize measurements and placing metric standards under global cooperation.
Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-M.original:
- Quoted text "The conference met in 1875 and concluded with the signing of the Treaty of the Metre. The principal agreements under the treaty were A three-tier organization would be put into place to provide political (CGPM), scientific (CIPM) and secretarial (BIPM) support for coordinating calibrations of national standards against an international standard."
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://everything.explained.today/Old_weights_and_measures_(France)/

Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-M.feature: In 1977, France, in compliance with EEC Directive 71/354/EEC, discontinued the use of traditional units like the livre and stère in favor of standardized International System of Units (SI).
Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-M.original:
- Quoted text "In 1977, these units, along with the French stère and the French livre (and amongst others, the German German Pfund) were proscribed by EEC Directive 71/354/EEC which required EU member states to standardize on the International System of Units (SI) and therefore to use the watt and its multiples."
  - Location paragraph 8===from https://everything.explained.today/Old_weights_and_measures_(France)/

Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-M.feature: The French measurement system evolved from a chaotic and non-uniform set of units into a standardized, universal system based on natural phenomena to ensure objectivity and global applicability.
Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-M.original:
- Quoted text "Until the 18th century there was no unified measurement system. In spite of the attempts of Charlemagne and many kings after him, aiming to reduce the number of existing measurements, France was one of the most inventive and most chaotic countries in this area."
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://metrologie-francaise.lne.fr/en/metrology/history-units

Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-M.feature: French cultural values in measurement emphasize universality and neutrality, rejecting standards tied to national pride or arbitrary human conventions.
Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-M.original:
- Quoted text "Their intention was to produce an invariable measure by comparison with a standard borrowed from a natural phenomenon, the universal standard that Condorcet had dreamed of as far back as 1775, which would not be based on any national vanity and which could be used by all foreign nations."
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://metrologie-francaise.lne.fr/en/metrology/history-units

Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-M.feature: The French measurement system prioritizes definitions based on immutable natural phenomena rather than physical artifacts to ensure long-term stability and precision.
Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-M.original:
- Quoted text "On 14 August 1960, the metre was redefined as being equal to 1 650 763,73 times the wavelength of orange radiation from the krypton 86 atom in vacuum. This definition, based on a physical phenomenon, marked the return to a natural, reproducible standard, permanent and invariable..."
  - Location paragraph 10===from https://metrologie-francaise.lne.fr/en/metrology/history-units

Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-M.feature: The French measurement system incorporates decimalization to simplify conversions and calculations in everyday and scientific use.
Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-M.original:
- Quoted text "Decimalisation also brought a real revolution in the calculation of areas and volumes. Conversion from a multiple to a sub-multiple unit in area, and vice versa, simply consists of moving the decimal point two places, or three places for volume."
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://metrologie-francaise.lne.fr/en/metrology/history-units

Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-M.feature: Modern French metrology is built on defining units through fixed fundamental constants of physics, ensuring coherence, precision, and international consistency.
Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-M.original:
- Quoted text "The basic principle of the revision of the SI is to base it not on the units themselves as it previously was, but on 7 constants of physics this is the paradigm shift of 2018."
  - Location paragraph 12===from https://metrologie-francaise.lne.fr/en/metrology/history-units

Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-M.feature: The primary system used for weights and measures in French is the metric system, which includes units for area, length, volume, weight, and speed using standardized metric terms.
Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-M.original:
- Quoted text "This page contains a list of vocabulary for weights and measures covering both the metric and imperial systems."
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://www.frenchlearner.com/vocabulary/measurement/

Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-M.feature: Although the metric system is primary, French vocabulary also includes terms for imperial units, indicating recognition and use of the imperial system alongside metric units.
Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-M.original:
- Quoted text "This page contains a list of vocabulary for weights and measures covering both the metric and imperial systems."
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://www.frenchlearner.com/vocabulary/measurement/

Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-M.feature: Specific French terms are used for metric units across categories such as area (e.g., hectare, square meter), length (e.g., meter, kilometer), volume (e.g., liter, cubic meter), and weight (e.g., gram, kilogram).
Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-M.original:
- Quoted text "hectare / un hectare", "square centimeter / un centimètre carré", "kilometer / un kilomètre", "liter / un litre", "gram / un gramme", "kilogram / un kilogramme"
  - Location paragraphs 3–6===from https://www.frenchlearner.com/vocabulary/measurement/

Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-M.feature: French includes direct translations or equivalents for imperial units such as mile, yard, foot, gallon, pound, and ounce, showing integration of these units into the language’s measurement vocabulary.
Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-M.original:
- Quoted text "mile / un mile", "yard / un yard (une verge)", "foot / un pied", "gallon / un gallon", "pound / une livre", "ounce / une once"
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://www.frenchlearner.com/vocabulary/measurement/

Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-M.feature: Prior to the adoption of the metric system in 1799, France used a traditional, non-decimal system of measurement that was well-defined but varied regionally.
Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-M.original:
- Quoted text "In France, before the decimalised metric system of 1799, a well-defined old system existed, however with some local variants."
  - Location p1===from https://en-academic.com/dic.nsf/enwiki/1238406

Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-M.feature: Traditional French units such as the "lieue" had different values depending on the region, indicating localized measurement practices.
Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-M.original:
- Quoted text "For instance, the 'lieue' could vary from 3.268 km in Beauce to 5.849 km in Provence."
  - Location p1===from https://en-academic.com/dic.nsf/enwiki/1238406

Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-M.feature: Between 1812 and 1839, traditional French units were maintained in a modified form compatible with the metric system, known as "mesures usuelles".
Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-M.original:
- Quoted text "Between 1812 and 1839, many of the traditional units continued in 'metrified' adaptations as the 'mesures usuelles'."
  - Location p2===from https://en-academic.com/dic.nsf/enwiki/1238406

Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-M.feature: The 1799 French law defined the metre using traditional French units, linking the new decimal system to the older system for continuity.
Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-M.original:
- Quoted text "The French law for the definitive metre of 1799 states that one decimal metre is exactly 443.296 French lines, or 3 French feet, 0 French inches and 11.296 French lines."
  - Location p3===from https://en-academic.com/dic.nsf/enwiki/1238406

Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-M.feature: The kilogram was legally defined in 1799 as the weight of one cubic decimetre of distilled water at 4 degrees Celsius, its point of maximum density.
Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-M.original:
- Quoted text "The kilogramme is, in addition, defined as the weight of 1 dm³ of distilled water at 4 degrees centigrade, i.e. at maximum density."
  - Location p5===from https://en-academic.com/dic.nsf/enwiki/1238406

Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-L.feature: French uses specific diacritical marks (acute, grave, circumflex, cedilla, and trema) that are essential for correct pronunciation and meaning; these must be preserved during localization to avoid semantic errors.
Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-L.original:
- Quoted text "l'accent aigu (acute accent) – é, l'accent grave (grave accent) – à, è, ù, la cédille (cedilla) – ç, l'accent circonflexe (circumflex) – â, ê, î, ô, û, l'accent tréma (trema) – ë, ï, ü"
  - Location p8===from https://lingohub.com/blog/french-localization-language-peculiarities-and-challenges

Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-L.feature: In French, a non-breaking space is required before certain punctuation marks such as colon, semicolon, question mark, exclamation point, and guillemets.
Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-L.original:
- Quoted text "The required space before certain punctuation marks colon (), quotation mark («»), semicolon (;), question mark (?), and exclamation point (!)."
  - Location p10===from https://lingohub.com/blog/french-localization-language-peculiarities-and-challenges

Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-L.feature: A non-breaking space must be used between the numerical value and the currency symbol in French localization.
Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-L.original:
- Quoted text "The required space in currencies (between number and currency sign.) Example 10 $= 10 $"
  - Location p11===from https://lingohub.com/blog/french-localization-language-peculiarities-and-challenges

Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-L.feature: In French, a non-breaking space is used as a thousands separator in large numbers instead of a comma or period.
Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-L.original:
- Quoted text "Space as a thousand separators. Example 1 000 000 = 1 000 000"
  - Location p12===from https://lingohub.com/blog/french-localization-language-peculiarities-and-challenges

Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-L.feature: French requires grammatical gender agreement, where nouns and adjectives have distinct masculine and feminine forms that must be correctly applied based on the referent.
Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-L.original:
- Quoted text "In contrast to English, where adjectives are not inflected for gender, in French, most adjectives are placed after the noun and inflected, as well as nouns; for example, the word 'student' will be - 'un étudiant' - masculine and une étudiante - feminine form."
  - Location p13===from https://lingohub.com/blog/french-localization-language-peculiarities-and-challenges

Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-L.feature: French distinguishes between formal ("vous") and informal ("tu") second-person pronouns, which affect tone and reflect social relationships such as professionalism or intimacy.
Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-L.original:
- Quoted text "Vous, used in formal communication, addresses one person or group of people with whom you have a formal or professional relationship; Tu is used in informal communication with friends, family members, etc."
  - Location p15===from https://lingohub.com/blog/french-localization-language-peculiarities-and-challenges

Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-L.feature: Different greetings and farewells are used depending on whether the communication is formal (e.g., "Bonjour", "Au revoir") or informal (e.g., "Salut", "À plus").
Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-L.original:
- Quoted text "Greeting 'Bonjour' and farewell 'Au revoir' in a formal tone; Greeting 'Salut' and farewell 'À plus' in an informal tone."
  - Location p16===from https://lingohub.com/blog/french-localization-language-peculiarities-and-challenges

Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-L.feature: Certain French idiomatic expressions like "déjà vu", "rendez-vous", "avant-garde", and "excusez-moi" are widely recognized and should often remain unchanged in translation, requiring only correct transliteration.
Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-L.original:
- Quoted text "For example, déjà vu, rendez-vous, avant-garde, and excusez-moi do not need a counterpart, only correct transliteration."
  - Location p18===from https://lingohub.com/blog/french-localization-language-peculiarities-and-challenges

Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-L.feature: French localization requires the use of guillemets (« ») for quotations instead of standard quotation marks (" ").
Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-L.original:
- Quoted text "Use the (« ») guillemets instead of ("”);"
  - Location p19===from https://lingohub.com/blog/french-localization-language-peculiarities-and-challenges

Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-L.feature: In French, days of the week and months are written in lowercase unless they appear at the beginning of a sentence.
Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-L.original:
- Quoted text "Unlike English, the days of the week and months are not capitalized unless at the beginning of a sentence."
  - Location p19===from https://lingohub.com/blog/french-localization-language-peculiarities-and-challenges

Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-L.feature: French uses a comma as the decimal separator rather than a period (e.g., 1,5 instead of 1.5).
Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-L.original:
- Quoted text "In French, the decimal separator is a comma - 1,5."
  - Location p19===from https://lingohub.com/blog/french-localization-language-peculiarities-and-challenges

Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-L.feature: The standard date format in French is day-month-year using two-digit components separated by slashes (e.g., 31/12/2024).
Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-L.original:
- Quoted text "The date format is DD/MM/YYYY, i.e. 31/12/2024."
  - Location p19===from https://lingohub.com/blog/french-localization-language-peculiarities-and-challenges

Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-L.feature: The 24-hour clock is more commonly used in French-speaking regions than the AM/PM time format.
Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-L.original:
- Quoted text "AM/PM format is less common than the 24-hour clock."
  - Location p19===from https://lingohub.com/blog/french-localization-language-peculiarities-and-challenges

Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-L.feature: Canadian French preserves verbs, expressions, and accents from 17th and 18th century France due to historical isolation.
Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-L.original:
- Quoted text "Due to its isolation from Europe, Canadian French has managed to retain French verbs, expressions, and accents that date back to 17th and 18th century France."  
  - Location paragraph 14===from https://into23.com/blog/reasons-why-culture-is-important-to-localization-french/

Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-L.feature: Canadian French maintains certain vowel sounds from elite French-speaking classes of the past, influenced by geographic and linguistic isolation after 1763.
Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-L.original:
- Quoted text "After France ceded Canada to Britain in 1763, the French-speaking community became more isolated, allowing certain phonetic sounds from the elite French-speaking classes to remain."  
  - Location paragraph 15===from https://into23.com/blog/reasons-why-culture-is-important-to-localization-french/

Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-L.feature: Due to proximity to English-speaking regions and contact with Indigenous populations, Canadian French adopts more English words and terms from Indigenous languages, such as carcajou and atoca.
Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-L.original:
- Quoted text "As the French-speaking parts of Canada are near the English-speaking parts of Canada and the United States, they adopt more words from the English language. Further, some words are even adopted from the indigenous population of Canada, such as carcajou (wolverine) and atoca (cranberry)."  
  - Location paragraph 16===from https://into23.com/blog/reasons-why-culture-is-important-to-localization-french/

Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-L.feature: In Canadian French, the informal form of address tu is used more commonly than the formal vous, reflecting a less formal communication style.
Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-L.original:
- Quoted text "Canadian French is less formal. Canadian French uses more informal means of address. The informal tu (you) is used more often than the formal vous."  
  - Location paragraph 17===from https://into23.com/blog/reasons-why-culture-is-important-to-localization-french/

Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-L.feature: Reflecting the prevalence of Catholicism in French-speaking Canada, religious vocabulary is more commonly used, particularly in profanity, compared to secular France.
Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-L.original:
- Quoted text "Canadian French uses more religious vocabulary, especially when swearing. Catholicism is the most practised religion in the French-speaking regions of Canada, whereas France is more secular."  
  - Location paragraph 18===from https://into23.com/blog/reasons-why-culture-is-important-to-localization-french/

Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-L.feature: Words can have drastically different meanings across French variants; for example, gosses means "children" in France but refers to "testicles" in Canadian French, making regional accuracy critical in marketing.
Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-L.original:
- Quoted text "For example, if you were promoting an eCommerce business that sells items for children, the word gosses in France is a playful word for child; however, in Canadian French, the word means testicles!"  
  - Location paragraph 20===from https://into23.com/blog/reasons-why-culture-is-important-to-localization-french/

Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-L.feature: Using informal tones or Canadian-specific idioms when targeting France can make a brand appear culturally unaware and reduce product appeal.
Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-L.original:
- Quoted text "The same goes if you wanted to reach the market in France but used informal tones or Canadian idioms and slang in your approach; it would make your strategy appear tone-deaf and make your product less attractive to the local market in France."  
  - Location paragraph 20===from https://into23.com/blog/reasons-why-culture-is-important-to-localization-french/

Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-L.feature: French localization includes regions beyond mainland France due to the historical reach of the French Colonial Empire, which established French language and culture in overseas territories and former colonies.
Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-L.original:
- Quoted text "According to the European Parliament’s Committee on Regional Development, the territory of the French Republic not only consists of Metropolitan France (includes Corsica) as many people believe, but also consists of five overseas regions, five overseas communities, and two special territories as well."  
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://www.languageconnections.com/blog/how-french-localization-covers-more-than-just-france/

Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-L.feature: The spread of French through colonization led to the development of localized language forms, including pidgins and creoles, which now require specific localization efforts.
Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-L.original:
- Quoted text "The French Colonial Empire rose to the global stage in the early 16th century and began colonizing the world due to economic and commercial competition with neighboring European nations such as Great Britain."  
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://www.languageconnections.com/blog/how-french-localization-covers-more-than-just-france/

Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-L.feature: Approximately 25 creole languages are based on colonial French, with over 15 million speakers globally, necessitating tailored localization and translation services.
Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-L.original:
- Quoted text "Due to the large variety of creole languages, there are now over 15 million speakers of some form of French-based creole languages across the globe, requiring effective localization and translation services."  
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://www.languageconnections.com/blog/how-french-localization-covers-more-than-just-france/

Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-L.feature: Successful French localization requires adapting to specific linguistic variations in different target markets, including countries where French is an official or administrative language.
Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-L.original:
- Quoted text "Whether your business target is a French-speaking population in Singapore or a country that uses French as their official language like Vietnam, using professional business translation services to accommodate the specific linguistic variations of your target markets is of the utmost importance when choosing to do business abroad."  
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://www.languageconnections.com/blog/how-french-localization-covers-more-than-just-france/

Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-L.feature: French localization must go beyond translation by adapting content to reflect local customs, cultural expectations, and consumer behaviors in different French-speaking regions.
Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-L.original:
- Quoted text "Most French people expect an e-commerce site to be not only translated into their language but also to be adapted to French customs and consuming habits."  
  - Location paragraph 18===from https://localazy.com/blog/french-as-your-bridge-for-more-business-opportunities

Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-L.feature: Content must be significantly adapted to meet the distinct cultural and linguistic expectations of different French-speaking audiences, such as those in France, Québec, Algeria, Congo, and other francophone regions.
Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-L.original:
- Quoted text "It is easy to see that you will have to adapt your content significantly if you want to attract the attention of the French-speaking audience in France, Algeria, Congo, or Québec, to list just some examples of totally different markets."  
  - Location paragraph 20===from https://localazy.com/blog/french-as-your-bridge-for-more-business-opportunities

Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-L.feature: Effective localization requires deep understanding of region-specific idioms and expressions that lack direct English equivalents, necessitating culturally informed adaptation rather than literal translation.
Regulation_and_Policy-Measurement Unit-L.original:
- Quoted text "But idioms are harder to unlock... expressions like 'faire la grasse matinée' or 'lâcher la grape' don't have an exact equivalent in English. Finding a comparable phrase takes knowledge of the local intricacies and context, and that's why French localization adjusted to the different francophone regions is so important."  
  - Location paragraph 17===from https://localazy.com/blog/french-as-your-bridge-for-more-business-opportunities

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: The French legal system is characterized by a dual court hierarchy—one for judicial matters (civil and criminal) and one for administrative matters—reflecting a strict separation between private and public law, with each hierarchy having its own specialized courts and procedures.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "There are two main court hierarchies a judicial one for civil and criminal cases, where Cour de cassation is the highest instance (juridictions judiciaires), and one hierarchy dealing with administrative law, headed by Conseil d’Etat (juridictions administratives)."
  - Location p3

- Rule Description Norm production in France relies heavily on codified laws, with approximately 77 effective codes containing thousands of legislative and regulatory articles, forming a highly structured and centralized regulatory framework.
- ===from https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-031-27745-0_15

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: The French legal system is based on a codified civil law framework, with laws organized into comprehensive legal codes that serve as the primary source of law.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "France’s legal system is based on civil law and follows a structured hierarchy of laws."
  - Location paragraph 1===from https://life-in-france.net/2025/02/26/main-laws-of-france-key-legal-frameworks/

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: The Constitution of the Fifth Republic (1958) is the supreme law of France, forming the foundational legal authority to which all other laws must conform.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "The Constitution of the Fifth Republic, adopted on October 4, 1958, is the supreme law of France."
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://life-in-france.net/2025/02/26/main-laws-of-france-key-legal-frameworks/

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: The French Civil Code (Code Civil), established in 1804, provides a unified and comprehensive set of rules governing private legal matters such as family, property, contracts, and obligations.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "The French Civil Code, also known as the Napoleonic Code, was enacted on March 21, 1804, under Emperor Napoleon Bonaparte. It is one of the most influential legal texts in history, shaping the legal systems of many countries around the world. The Code Civil establishes the rules governing private law, including family law, property law, contracts, and obligations."
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://life-in-france.net/2025/02/26/main-laws-of-france-key-legal-frameworks/

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: The Penal Code (Code Pénal) serves as the central legal framework defining criminal offenses, classifications of crimes, and corresponding penalties in France.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "The French Penal Code (Code Pénal) is the primary legal framework governing criminal offenses, penalties, and judicial procedures in France."
  - Location paragraph 9===from https://life-in-france.net/2025/02/26/main-laws-of-france-key-legal-frameworks/

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: French criminal law formally classifies offenses into three categories—crimes (serious), délits (moderate), and infractions (minor)—each with defined penalties.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "French law classifies criminal offenses into three categories 1. Crimes (Les Crimes) – Serious Offenses; 2. Misdemeanors (Les Délits) – Moderate Offenses; 3. Infractions – Minor Offenses."
  - Location paragraph 11===from https://life-in-france.net/2025/02/26/main-laws-of-france-key-legal-frameworks/

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: Under the Penal Code, no individual can be punished for an act unless it is explicitly defined as a crime by existing law, reflecting the principle of legality.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "Legality of Crimes and Punishments – No one can be punished unless a law explicitly defines the crime and penalty (Nullum crimen, nulla poena sine lege)."
  - Location paragraph 12===from https://life-in-france.net/2025/02/26/main-laws-of-france-key-legal-frameworks/

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: The Labour Code (Code du Travail) is the comprehensive legal framework regulating employment relationships, worker rights, and employer obligations in France.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "The French Labour Code (Code du Travail) is the main body of laws governing employment, workers’ rights, and employer obligations in France."
  - Location paragraph 14===from https://life-in-france.net/2025/02/26/main-laws-of-france-key-legal-frameworks/

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: Major areas of French law are systematically organized into books and sections within formal legal codes, ensuring structured access and application of regulations.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "The Labour Code is divided into eight books, covering all aspects of employment law."
  - Location paragraph 15===from https://life-in-france.net/2025/02/26/main-laws-of-france-key-legal-frameworks/

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: The Constitutional Council ensures that laws comply with the Constitution, serving as a key regulatory mechanism for legal conformity.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "The Constitutional Council (Conseil Constitutionnel) ensures laws follow the Constitution."
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://life-in-france.net/2025/02/26/main-laws-of-france-key-legal-frameworks/

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: Regulatory authorities in France must be genuinely independent to ensure the impartiality of public action and stakeholder safety, though this independence operates within a framework of democratic (parliamentary) and jurisdictional control.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "The need to guarantee both the impartiality of public action and the safety of stakeholders makes it necessary for regulators to be genuinely independent, although this does not mean that their duties are carried out without any democratic control (Parliament) or jurisdictional control (supervisory bodies and judicial authorities)."
  - Location p4===from https://chairgovreg.fondation-dauphine.fr/en/publication/450/l-organisation-institutionnelle-de-la-regulation-en-france-quel-positionnement-et

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: The independence of regulatory authorities is secured through organic appointment procedures for decision-making members, functional autonomy from hierarchical supervision, and collegiate decision-making processes.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "This independence is guaranteed organically by the appointment of the members of the decision-making bodies and, functionally, by the fact that they are not subject to hierarchical or supervisory authority, as well as by the collegiate decision-making process."
  - Location p4===from https://chairgovreg.fondation-dauphine.fr/en/publication/450/l-organisation-institutionnelle-de-la-regulation-en-france-quel-positionnement-et

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: The legislator defines the scope and responsibilities of regulatory authorities, and their independence is reinforced through appointment mechanisms by political authorities and through budgetary, accounting, jurisdictional, and institutional controls.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "The independence of the regulatory authorities is also guaranteed by the legislator, who defines their remit and scope of intervention, by the way in which the members of the colleges are appointed by the political authorities, and by the threefold budgetary, accounting, jurisdictional and institutional control to which they are subject."
  - Location p4===from https://chairgovreg.fondation-dauphine.fr/en/publication/450/l-organisation-institutionnelle-de-la-regulation-en-france-quel-positionnement-et

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: Since 2017, laws have been adopted to harmonize governance rules across independent administrative and public authorities, aiming to strengthen independence while improving parliamentary oversight.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "At the initiative of the Senate, two laws aimed at harmonising the rules of governance of independent administrative authorities (AAI) and independent public authorities (API) and ensuring better parliamentary control of their action in a context of strengthened independence were adopted at the beginning of 2017."
  - Location p3===from https://chairgovreg.fondation-dauphine.fr/en/publication/450/l-organisation-institutionnelle-de-la-regulation-en-france-quel-positionnement-et

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: The term "marché" is the most common and general word used in French to refer to any type of market, regardless of size or goods sold, and applies to both rural and urban settings.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "The word 'marché' is your safest and most widely understood option when referring to a market in French. It’s a general term, encompassing everything from a small farmers market in a rural village to a large, sprawling urban marketplace."
  - Location p3===from https://eatingchoice.com/what-do-the-french-call-a-market/

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: A "marché alimentaire" specifically refers to a food market focused on fresh produce, meats, cheeses, seafood, and other edible goods, emphasizing its role in French gastronomy.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "This specifically refers to a food market, where you can find a wide array of fresh produce, meats, cheeses, seafood, and other culinary delights."
  - Location p5===from https://eatingchoice.com/what-do-the-french-call-a-market/

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: A "marché paysan" is a market where local farmers sell their products directly to consumers, featuring seasonal produce and artisanal goods, reflecting a connection to rural life and sustainable agriculture.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "This type of market features goods directly from the farm, offering a true taste of the French countryside. You can expect to find seasonal produce, homemade jams, farm-fresh eggs, and other artisanal products."
  - Location p6===from https://eatingchoice.com/what-do-the-french-call-a-market/

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: A "marché aux puces" is a flea market specializing in second-hand goods, antiques, vintage clothing, and collectibles, often held on weekends with opportunities for haggling.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "This translates to 'flea market' and is a treasure trove of second-hand goods, collectibles, and curiosities. These markets are often held on weekends and are a popular destination for bargain hunters and those seeking a piece of history."
  - Location p7===from https://eatingchoice.com/what-do-the-french-call-a-market/

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: A "marché de Noël" is a seasonal Christmas market offering festive items such as handcrafted gifts, decorations, mulled wine, and gingerbread, contributing to holiday celebrations and community gatherings.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "During the holiday season, France comes alive with 'marchés de Noël' or Christmas markets. These festive gatherings offer a magical atmosphere with stalls selling handcrafted gifts, traditional Christmas decorations, and seasonal treats like mulled wine and gingerbread."
  - Location p8===from https://eatingchoice.com/what-do-the-french-call-a-market/

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: A "halle" is a covered, indoor market hall that provides sheltered, permanent stalls, differing from open-air markets by being more established and protected from weather.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "A 'halle' in the context of a French market refers to a covered market hall. Unlike an open-air 'marché,' a 'halle' provides a sheltered space for vendors and shoppers, protecting them from the elements."
  - Location p12===from https://eatingchoice.com/what-do-the-french-call-a-market/

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: A "brocante" refers to a market or shop selling used or vintage items that are not antiques, including furniture, books, and retro clothing, offering curated second-hand goods.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "‘Brocante’ refers to a type of market or shop that specializes in selling used or vintage goods, but not quite antiques... At a ‘brocante,’ you might find vintage furniture, old books, retro clothing, antique linens, glassware, and various household items with a past."
  - Location p13===from https://eatingchoice.com/what-do-the-french-call-a-market/

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: A "foire" is a larger, less frequent, and more festive market event than a regular "marché," often tied to festivals or anniversaries and featuring broader offerings and entertainment.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "A 'foire' generally implies a larger, less frequent, and more festive event than a regular 'marché.' A 'foire' is often associated with a specific occasion, such as a festival, agricultural event, or town anniversary, and tends to draw vendors from a wider geographic area."
  - Location p14===from https://eatingchoice.com/what-do-the-french-call-a-market/

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: Markets in France vary by region, with coastal areas hosting fish markets and mountainous regions focusing on local cheeses and cured meats, reflecting regional agricultural and cultural traditions.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "For instance, in coastal regions like Brittany or Normandy, you’ll often find 'marchés aux poissons' (fish markets) that specialize in fresh seafood... Conversely, in the mountainous regions like the Alps or the Pyrenees, you might find markets focusing on local cheeses, cured meats, and mountain honey."
  - Location p17===from https://eatingchoice.com/what-do-the-french-call-a-market/

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: French markets serve as central social hubs where community members gather not only to shop but also to interact, exchange news, and strengthen local bonds.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "For locals, it’s more than just buying groceries—it’s an opportunity to meet friends, exchange news, and experience the pulse of the community."  
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://www.learnfrenchwithsonal.com/the-tradition-of-french-markets-a-cultural-and-culinary-experience/

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: French markets prioritize fresh, seasonal, and locally sourced food items, reflecting a cultural value placed on agricultural authenticity and regional availability.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "French markets are known for their incredible variety of fresh, seasonal produce. Depending on the time of year, you might find baskets brimming with ripe strawberries, plump tomatoes, or fragrant herbs."  
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://www.learnfrenchwithsonal.com/the-tradition-of-french-markets-a-cultural-and-culinary-experience/

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: Markets highlight regional specialties, showcasing traditional products unique to specific areas of France, thus preserving and promoting local gastronomic heritage.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "One of the most delightful aspects of French markets is the opportunity to explore regional specialties... In Provence, you might find olive oil, lavender honey, and tapenade. In Brittany, you’ll encounter fresh seafood and buttery galettes."  
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://www.learnfrenchwithsonal.com/the-tradition-of-french-markets-a-cultural-and-culinary-experience/

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: Products at French markets are often made by small, family-run farms or artisanal producers, emphasizing cultural support for traditional craftsmanship and sustainable local economies.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "Many of the products are made by small, family-owned farms or artisanal producers, ensuring high quality and preserving traditional methods."  
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://www.learnfrenchwithsonal.com/the-tradition-of-french-markets-a-cultural-and-culinary-experience/

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: Engaging with French markets is considered a multisensory and culturally immersive experience, involving sight, smell, taste, and interaction with vendors.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "A visit to a French market is a sensory feast... the mouth-watering aroma of roasting chickens or sizzling crepes, and the melodic chatter of vendors calling out their wares all combine to create an unforgettable experience."  
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://www.learnfrenchwithsonal.com/the-tradition-of-french-markets-a-cultural-and-culinary-experience/

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: Despite the rise of supermarkets and online shopping, French markets remain popular, reflecting a cultural commitment to maintaining historical traditions in everyday life.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "Even in an age of supermarkets and online shopping, these markets thrive, providing a link between the past and the present."  
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://www.learnfrenchwithsonal.com/the-tradition-of-french-markets-a-cultural-and-culinary-experience/

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: Shopping at open-air markets for fresh food is a deeply rooted cultural norm in France, preferred over supermarkets which are seen as less traditional and somewhat unusual.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "In France, shopping for dinner in the open air by vendor and not by supermarket aisle, is simply the norm."
  - Location paragraph 5

- Rule Description French people typically view regular market shopping as a long-standing personal habit, often continuing practices passed down through generations, rather than a trendy or novel lifestyle choice.
- ===from https://www.francethisway.com/tourism/france-markets.php

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: In France, a Société (company) is recognized as a legally independent entity (Personne Morale), whereas an Entreprise (individual enterprise) is not; the individual and the business are considered the same legal entity.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "The biggest difference between the two is Société is a legally independent entity (Personne Morale)."
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://www.micco.app/post/comprehensive-explanation-of-french-company-types

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: Under the EIRL (Entrepreneur Individuel à Responsabilité Limitée) form, the company and the individual operator are legally considered the same entity, meaning there is no legal separation between personal and business identity.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "The company and the individual operator are legally considered the same entity."
  - Location paragraph 10===from https://www.micco.app/post/comprehensive-explanation-of-french-company-types

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: The SASU is an independent legal entity, which means it is legally distinct from its owner, allowing for separation between personal assets and business liabilities.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "As an independent legal entity, SASU protects her personal assets from business debts."
  - Location paragraph 8===from https://www.micco.app/post/comprehensive-explanation-of-french-company-types

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: Individuals are allowed to reproduce images of buildings and sculptures that are permanently located in public spaces, but only for non-commercial purposes; organizations are not permitted to do so.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "On 7 October 2016, the French parliament approved a law recognizing a limited version of the freedom of panorama that authorizes the reproduction by individuals (not organizations) of buildings and sculptures permanently located in public space, but only for non-commercial utilizations."
  - Location paragraph 1 (under "Freedom of panorama" section)===from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Commons:Copyright_rules_by_territory/France

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: The freedom of panorama exception does not apply to two-dimensional public art, including street art, even for non-commercial uses.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "The non-commercial freedom of panorama exception only covers works of architecture and sculptures in public spaces. A case file from 2023 (Combo v. Melénchon), concerning a politician's use of a street art in their ad campaign, sets a precedence that all street art is not covered by the panorama exception. Therefore, all 2D art is Not OK, even for non-commercial uses."
  - Location paragraph 2 (under "Freedom of panorama" section)===from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Commons:Copyright_rules_by_territory/France

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: Text, video, and graphics published on the French government website (gouvernement.fr) between March 2014 and September 2014 were licensed under CC BY 3.0 FR and can be used accordingly; however, photographs from government sites are generally not included unless specified.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "Video, text and graphics published on the gouvernement.fr website are now licensed under Creative Commons CC BY-NC-ND but were in 2014 under CC BY 3.0 FR. Be careful, since this does not apply to photographs."
  - Location paragraph 2 (under "Images from public web sites" section)===from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Commons:Copyright_rules_by_territory/France

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: Documents issued under the Licence Ouverte (e.g., from data.gouv.fr) may be used under the terms of that license.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "{{Licence Ouverte}} and {{Licence Ouverte 2}} – For documents issued under the Licence Ouverte (for example from http//data.gouv.fr)."
  - Location paragraph 4 (under "Copyright tags" section)===from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Commons:Copyright_rules_by_territory/France

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: Aerial photographs from the BD ORTHO catalogue produced by the Institut national de l'information géographique et forestière (IGN) are available for use under specific licensing terms.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "{{BD ORTHO - IGN}} – For aerial photographs part of the BD ORTHO catalogue produced by the Institut national de l'information géographique et forestière (IGN). Those aerial photographs are accessible via Géoportail and the website remonterletemps.ign.fr."
  - Location paragraph 5 (under "Copyright tags" section)===from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Commons:Copyright_rules_by_territory/France

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: In France, businesses are expected to adhere to laws, regulations, and standards relevant to their operations as part of compliance.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "Compliance refers to adhering to laws, regulations, and standards that apply to business operations."  
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://www.valoris-avocats.com/en/needs/compliance-advisor-france/

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: Ensuring compliance is culturally valued in France as a means to avoid legal penalties, protect reputation, and promote ethical business practices.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "Ensuring compliance helps businesses avoid legal penalties, maintain their reputation, and promote ethical practices within their operations."  
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://www.valoris-avocats.com/en/needs/compliance-advisor-france/

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: Companies in France are expected to stay informed about evolving legal requirements to meet compliance obligations effectively.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "Companies must stay updated with the ever-evolving legal landscape to meet these regulatory requirements effectively."  
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://www.valoris-avocats.com/en/needs/compliance-advisor-france/

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: Businesses are expected to implement formal compliance programs, including internal policies and monitoring mechanisms, particularly in areas like anti-corruption and anti-money laundering.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "They provide strategic advice, ensure that all business practices comply with relevant laws, and help implement effective compliance programs."  
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://www.valoris-avocats.com/en/needs/compliance-advisor-france/

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: It is a recognized practice in France for companies to conduct internal audits to verify adherence to national laws and regulations.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "Conducting thorough audits to ensure compliance with French laws and regulations."  
  - Location paragraph 8 (under "Regulatory Compliance Audits")===from https://www.valoris-avocats.com/en/needs/compliance-advisor-france/

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: Providing training to employees on compliance topics is a standard expectation for companies operating in France.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "Providing training programs on compliance-related topics for staff."  
  - Location paragraph 8 (under "Employee Training")===from https://www.valoris-avocats.com/en/needs/compliance-advisor-france/

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: Companies in France commonly rely on legal advisors to represent them during regulatory investigations or disputes, reflecting an institutionalized compliance culture.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "Representing companies during regulatory investigations and disputes."  
  - Location paragraph 8 (under "Regulatory Representation")===from https://www.valoris-avocats.com/en/needs/compliance-advisor-france/

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: Formal greetings are expected in public and professional settings, including using "bonjour" or "bonsoir" with honorifics like Monsieur or Madame when entering shops, and saying "au revoir" when leaving.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "You are expected to say ‘bonjour’ or ‘bonsoir’ (good morning and good evening) with the honorific title Monsieur or Madame when entering a shop and ‘au revoir’ (good-bye) when leaving."  
  - Location paragraph 28

- Rule Description Punctuality is important in social and business contexts; arriving late without prior notice is considered impolite, though flexibility increases in southern regions.  
- ===from https://commisceo-global.com/country-guides/france-guide/

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: Certain provisions in a company’s code of ethics or conduct may be unenforceable in France if they conflict with local legal protections for employees’ freedom of expression and right to privacy, particularly regarding social media usage and conflict-of-interest disclosures.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "French law may prohibit the inclusion of certain obligations in your Code or require you to add certain local legal requirements. For example, employees’ freedom of expression and right to privacy is highly protected in France. This can namely make it difficult to regulate what employees cannot say on social media or to impose disclosure of conflicts of interests."  
  - Location p1===from https://chambers.com/articles/rolling-out-your-code-of-ethics-conduct-in-france-2

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: A code of ethics or conduct intended for use in France must be submitted to staff representatives (CSE) for consultation, who must be given sufficient time (up to one month) to provide their opinion, which although non-binding, is a required procedural step.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "To do so, you need to inform and consult your Staff Representatives. Their opinion is not binding but they need to be given sufficient information and time (maximum 1 month) to render such opinion."  
  - Location p2===from https://chambers.com/articles/rolling-out-your-code-of-ethics-conduct-in-france-2

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: After integration into the Internal Work Rules and consultation with staff representatives, the updated rules including the code must be submitted to the local labour inspector, who has the authority to require changes if the content does not comply with French law.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "Before you can communicate your Code to all employees, the modified Internal Work Rules, with your Code and the Staff Representatives’ opinion then need to be communicated to the local Employment Tribunal but also to the local Labour Inspector who does have the power to impose changes to the Code in case of non-compliance with French law."  
  - Location p2===from https://chambers.com/articles/rolling-out-your-code-of-ethics-conduct-in-france-2

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: Companies with more than 50 employees in France must establish a whistleblowing mechanism compliant with Loi Sapin II, including specific rules on reportable subjects, handling procedures, and data privacy; this policy must also be discussed with staff representatives.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "If you have more than 50 employees working in France, you will be subject to the French anticorruption law (“Loi Sapin II law”) which namely requires you to set up a whistleblowing mechanism. There are strict rules with regards the type of subjects which can be reported via the whistleblowing line and how reports must be handled and investigated. In addition, there are strict data privacy rules... Again, you will have to inform and consult the Staff Representatives on this policy."  
  - Location p3===from https://chambers.com/articles/rolling-out-your-code-of-ethics-conduct-in-france-2

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: It is mandatory to translate the code of ethics or conduct into French, especially when it includes health and safety rules or when it is integrated into the Internal Work Rules of the French subsidiary.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "Even if all your subsidiary’s French employees understand the language in which your Code is written, it is highly recommended to have it translated. This is mandatory for any rules relating to health and safety which your Code will no doubt contain. Also, if you have decided to integrate your Code into your French subsidiary’s Internal Work Rules (see 2/ above), this is mandatory."  
  - Location p4===from https://chambers.com/articles/rolling-out-your-code-of-ethics-conduct-in-france-2

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: Requiring contractors or service providers to comply with an employee-focused code of conduct may lead them to claim employee status due to the high level of legal protection associated with such status in France; instead, tailored codes should be included in their contracts.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "In France, having employee status offers a high level of legal protection against termination and many benefits. What distinguishes an employee from a contractor/service provider is the level of control the company exerts on their activity and behaviour. Asking a contractor/service provider to comply with your Code could therefore be used to try and obtain employee status."  
  - Location p5===from https://chambers.com/articles/rolling-out-your-code-of-ethics-conduct-in-france-2

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: In France, regulatory compliance is a core cultural expectation in investment practices, where adherence to rules set by authorities like the AMF is not only a legal requirement but also a strategic approach to managing risk and building investor confidence.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "Regulatory bodies in France, such as the Autorité des Marchés Financiers (AMF), play a pivotal role in overseeing market stability and protecting investors through policy enforcement and risk disclosure requirements."  
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://fastercapital.com/content/Risk-Management--Risk-and-Reward--Mastering-Risk-Management-in-France-s-Investment-Scene.html

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: French investors culturally favor cautious risk management, often choosing financial products like life insurance ("assurance vie") that offer both security and growth potential, reflecting a societal preference for balanced, low-volatility investment strategies.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "This is reflected in the popularity of life insurance products in France, which offer a balance of security and growth potential."  
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://fastercapital.com/content/Risk-Management--Risk-and-Reward--Mastering-Risk-Management-in-France-s-Investment-Scene.html

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: There is a growing cultural norm in France to incorporate environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors into investment decisions, as investors increasingly align their portfolios with sustainable values to manage long-term risk.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "French investors are showing a growing preference for sustainable investment options that align with these values."  
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://fastercapital.com/content/Risk-Management--Risk-and-Reward--Mastering-Risk-Management-in-France-s-Investment-Scene.html

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: Diversification across sectors and geographies is a widely accepted practice among French investors, reflecting a cultural emphasis on reducing unsystematic risk through broad portfolio allocation.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "By spreading investments across various asset classes, sectors, and geographies, French investors can reduce the impact of a single underperforming investment."  
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://fastercapital.com/content/Risk-Management--Risk-and-Reward--Mastering-Risk-Management-in-France-s-Investment-Scene.html

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: France has implemented a regulatory framework for games with monetisable digital objects (JONUM), which combine video gaming and online gambling elements, particularly involving blockchain, crypto-assets, and NFTs. Operators must declare their activity to the French National Gaming Authority (ANJ), establish physical offices in France, and strictly prohibit minors from participating in paid gaming through mandatory age verification.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "Article 41 of the SREN Act sets forth several obligations for companies operating JONUM. They must declare their activity to the French National Gaming Authority (Autorité nationale des jeux, ANJ), meet office establishment requirements and strictly prohibit minors from paid gaming, with mandatory age verification, especially when creating an account."
  - Location paragraph 2

- Rule Description The Digital Operational Resilience Act (DORA) is now applicable across the EU, including France, imposing obligations on financial entities to manage ICT risks, including through Threat-Led Penetration Testing (TLPT). France is taking a pioneering role by developing national implementation guidance via the ACPR and Banque de France (BdF).
- ===from https://practiceguides.chambers.com/practice-guides/fintech-2025/france/trends-and-developments

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: The French cultural network abroad operates through a structured and collaborative relationship with the Institut français, involving various entities such as embassy services, Instituts français, Alliances françaises, and bi-national centers to promote international cultural cooperation.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "This network is made up of various structures embassy cooperation and cultural action services (SCAC), Instituts français, Alliances françaises and bi-national cultural centers. Together, they promote the French language, disseminate contemporary creation and foster intercultural dialogue."
  - Location p6===from https://www.institutfrancais.com/en/reseau-culturel-francais-etranger

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: The Ateliers de l'Institut français serve as a strategic platform for aligning international cultural actors around shared priorities and global sector developments.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "The AIF are a unique space for reflection, exchange and consultation. Conferences, collaborative workshops, presentations and networking events enable us to share major orientations, promote initiatives in the field and identify common priorities. They play a structuring role for the network and provide a sounding board for changes in the cultural sector on a global scale."
  - Location p10===from https://www.institutfrancais.com/en/reseau-culturel-francais-etranger

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: International cultural projects are co-constructed between the Institut français, the global network, and sometimes external partners, ensuring alignment through shared input and co-financing.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "These calls enable co-construction of projects between the Institut français, the network and sometimes partners. Each scheme is based on transparent criteria, methodological support and a principle of co-financing."
  - Location p15===from https://www.institutfrancais.com/en/reseau-culturel-francais-etranger

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: The network actively promotes French culture, language, and values internationally by supporting the circulation of works, artists, and ideas across borders.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "Together, they carry the voice of France, Europe and the French-speaking world around the world, promoting dialogue between cultures, the circulation of ideas and the influence of contemporary creativity."
  - Location p16===from https://www.institutfrancais.com/en/reseau-culturel-francais-etranger

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: French has been historically used as the common language for European diplomatic communication since the 17th century due to France's political and cultural influence.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "In the 17th century, French emerged as the lingua franca of European diplomacy due to France’s influential political and cultural standing."
  - Location p2===from https://elitefrenchtutoring.com/why-is-french-the-international-language-of-diplomacy/

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: The grammatical structure and vocabulary of French allow for precise and nuanced expression, making it effective for conveying complex diplomatic ideas clearly.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "French’s grammatical structure and vocabulary offer precision and nuance, enabling diplomats to convey complex ideas with clarity."
  - Location p3===from https://elitefrenchtutoring.com/why-is-french-the-international-language-of-diplomacy/

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: French is officially used in major international organizations such as the United Nations and the International Red Cross, supporting its role in global diplomatic exchanges.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "Entities like the United Nations and the International Red Cross use French as an official language."
  - Location p4===from https://elitefrenchtutoring.com/why-is-french-the-international-language-of-diplomacy/

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: French serves as a neutral and impartial medium in diplomacy, enabling fair communication among representatives from diverse linguistic backgrounds without favoring any one language group.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "French’s neutrality and impartiality make it an ideal choice for diplomatic communication. It serves as a neutral medium, allowing representatives from diverse linguistic backgrounds to engage in discussions without linguistic biases."
  - Location p5===from https://elitefrenchtutoring.com/why-is-french-the-international-language-of-diplomacy/

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: France engages in mutual cultural promotion with Indo-Pacific countries through large-scale, reciprocal cultural events known as Saisons culturelles, which facilitate two-way cultural exchange between France and partner nations.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "The organisation of joint cultural events, such as the Saisons culturelles, helps to promote and spread foreign cultures in France and vice versa."  
  - Location p6===from https://ww2.frstrategie.org/en/publications/fiches-indo-pacifique/n9-cultural-cooperation-and-francophonie

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: France promotes international values of press freedom and media pluralism in the Indo-Pacific through public media outlets like RFI and France 24, and supports journalists in exile and media development in countries with poor press freedom records.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "France Médias Monde (including France 24 and Radio France Internationale – RFI) and the TV5Monde group promote French-speaking and are emblems of the defence of pluralism and press freedom."  
  - Location p10  
- Rule Description France actively supports media development and press freedom in the Indo-Pacific, particularly in Burma, through targeted programs that assist exiled journalists and protect free expression.  
- ===from https://ww2.frstrategie.org/en/publications/fiches-indo-pacifique/n9-cultural-cooperation-and-francophonie

Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.feature: France’s cultural network in the Indo-Pacific, including Alliances françaises, contributes to raising awareness and promoting human rights as part of its broader cultural diplomacy mission.
Regulation_and_Policy-Financial Market R.original:
- Quoted text "The cultural network, including the FAs, also plays a role in promoting and raising awareness of human rights."  
  - Location p7===from https://ww2.frstrategie.org/en/publications/fiches-indo-pacifique/n9-cultural-cooperation-and-francophonie
