Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Education an.feature: Students are actively encouraged to participate in discussions, ask questions, and engage intellectually, reflecting a cultural value placed on active involvement in learning.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Education an.original:
- Quoted text "The emphasis on la participation (participation) is crucial. Students are actively encouraged to contribute to classroom discussions, ask questions, and engage with the material."
  - Location p4===from https://rt-students.com/in-the-classroom-in-french

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Education an.feature: In France, there is a strong cultural value placed on maintaining a balance between professional work and personal leisure time, which is supported by labor policies.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Education an.original:
- Quoted text "In France, there is a strong emphasis on work-life balance. The French value their leisure time and often prioritize it over work."
  - Location paragraph 9===from https://voyagelinguist.com/vocabulary/discussing-career-choices-in-french/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Education an.feature: French workplaces tend to have a hierarchical structure where titles and formalities are significant, and distinctions between authority levels are clearly maintained.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Education an.original:
- Quoted text "French workplaces often have a more hierarchical structure compared to some English-speaking countries. Titles and formalities are important, and there is a clear distinction between different levels of authority."
  - Location paragraph 10===from https://voyagelinguist.com/vocabulary/discussing-career-choices-in-french/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Education an.feature: Educational background and formal qualifications play a crucial role in career discussions and professional identity in France.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Education an.original:
- Quoted text "Education plays a significant role in career discussions in France. The French education system is highly regarded, and specific qualifications can be essential for certain professions."
  - Location paragraph 11===from https://voyagelinguist.com/vocabulary/discussing-career-choices-in-french/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Education an.feature: In French culture, a person's job is considered only one aspect of their life and not necessarily the most important, with greater emphasis often placed on culture, leisure, or politics.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Education an.original:
- Quoted text "In France, it's one part of your life—not necessarily the most important. Don’t be surprised if people shift the conversation to culture, leisure, or politics."
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/8/6/talking-about-your-job-in-french-vocabulary-cultural-context

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Education an.feature: Job titles carry social significance in France, but openly discussing or boasting about salary and status is considered impolite.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Education an.original:
- Quoted text "Job titles carry social weight in France, but it’s not considered polite to brag or talk excessively about salary or status."
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/8/6/talking-about-your-job-in-french-vocabulary-cultural-context

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Education an.feature: French cultural norms prioritize work-life balance, and frequently working overtime or emphasizing busyness is not seen as admirable and may be viewed with suspicion.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Education an.original:
- Quoted text "French culture values work-life balance over constant productivity. Working overtime or boasting about being “so busy” isn’t a badge of honor—it might even seem suspect."
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/8/6/talking-about-your-job-in-french-vocabulary-cultural-context

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.feature: Fireworks are a central festive entertainment activity during Bastille Day, held in public spaces across France to celebrate national pride.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.original:
- Quoted text "The fireworks are the highlight of the night, illuminating the sky with magnificent colors and shapes."  
  - Location p5===from https://www.startfrenchnow.com/blog/post/les-fetes-traditionnelles-francaises-celebrations-et-coutumes-uniques?postLang=en

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.feature: Musical performances during La fête de la musique take place in various public locations such as streets, parks, squares, and cafes, emphasizing widespread public access to free entertainment.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.original:
- Quoted text "Outdoor concerts are organized in the streets and squares, showcasing the musical diversity of the country."  
  - Location p10===from https://www.startfrenchnow.com/blog/post/les-fetes-traditionnelles-francaises-celebrations-et-coutumes-uniques?postLang=en

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.feature: The Music Festival encourages festive entertainment activities in different places where both amateur and professional musicians perform publicly, promoting free artistic expression.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.original:
- Quoted text "Since its creation, the Music Festival has become an essential meeting for amateur and professional musicians, offering free performances accessible to all."  
  - Location p9===from https://www.startfrenchnow.com/blog/post/les-fetes-traditionnelles-francaises-celebrations-et-coutumes-uniques?postLang=en

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.feature: The Lemon Festival in Menton is a festive entertainment activity held in February that celebrates citrus fruits through parades, sculptures, and crafts, rooted in the local production of lemons and oranges.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.original:
- Quoted text "Held over two weeks in February, the Fête du Citron (Lemon Festival) celebrates all things citrus in the city of Menton."
  - Location p10===from https://www.expatica.com/fr/lifestyle/holidays/top-french-festivals-444873/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.feature: The Nice Carnival is a major festive entertainment event held every February featuring themed parades, music, dance, and illuminated floats, positioning itself among the world’s largest carnivals with cultural parallels to those in Brazil, Venice, and New Orleans.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.original:
- Quoted text "Taking place every February, the famous Nice Carnival is one of the largest carnivals in the world; alongside those in Brazil, Venice, and Mardi Gras in New Orleans."
  - Location p13===from https://www.expatica.com/fr/lifestyle/holidays/top-french-festivals-444873/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.feature: The International Kite Festival in Berck-sur-Mer is a festive entertainment activity held every April featuring giant kites, competitions, and night-time flying displays, attracting hundreds of thousands of spectators to the seaside town.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.original:
- Quoted text "Giant pigs actually might fly at the International Kite Festival (Rencontres Internationales de Cerfs-Volants) at Berck-sur-Mer. For over two decades, more than half a million spectators have come to watch the spectacular display of kites fly over the seaside town."
  - Location p16===from https://www.expatica.com/fr/lifestyle/holidays/top-french-festivals-444873/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.feature: The Cannes Film Festival is a prestigious annual entertainment event in May that functions as both a professional film industry gathering and a public celebration of cinema, featuring red carpet premieres, screenings, and celebrity appearances.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.original:
- Quoted text "Film buffs will no doubt want to head to the world’s most famous movie festival, the Cannes Film Festival. The red carpet event was created by a French Minister of Education and Fine Arts. He wanted to establish an international cultural event in France to rival the Venice Film Festival."
  - Location p19===from https://www.expatica.com/fr/lifestyle/holidays/top-french-festivals-444873/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.feature: The Sedan Medieval Festival in May is a festive entertainment activity that recreates medieval life with jousting, parades, markets, and performances at Europe’s largest medieval castle, attracting thousands of visitors seeking historical immersion.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.original:
- Quoted text "For an unforgettable slice of Medieval France, head to the Sedan Medieval Festival (Festival Médieval de Sedan) in May. Held at the largest medieval castle in Europe, the Château de Sedan, the festival brings the spirit of the Middle Ages alive."
  - Location p21===from https://www.expatica.com/fr/lifestyle/holidays/top-french-festivals-444873/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.feature: Music Day on 21 June is a nationwide festive entertainment event where free public music performances occur across streets, parks, and venues, encouraging participation from amateur and professional musicians of all genres.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.original:
- Quoted text "There’s music in the air throughout France on 21 June, the day of the summer solstice. This is when La Fête de la Musique (Music Day) takes part, celebrating the diversity and scope of musical practices in all its different genres."
  - Location p24===from https://www.expatica.com/fr/lifestyle/holidays/top-french-festivals-444873/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.feature: Bastille Day on 14 July is a national festive entertainment event marked by parades, concerts, and fireworks across France, with major celebrations centered in Paris, including a large military parade and a prominent fireworks display at the Eiffel Tower.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.original:
- Quoted text "Celebrated nationwide on 14 July, Bastille Day (Fête Nationale or Quatorze Juillet) is the biggest and most important festival in the French calendar."
  - Location p27===from https://www.expatica.com/fr/lifestyle/holidays/top-french-festivals-444873/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.feature: The Festival d’Avignon is a major July theater festival held in Avignon featuring official and independent performances in historic venues, transforming the city into a hub for theater, dance, and artistic exchange.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.original:
- Quoted text "Another fantastic French festival not to miss is the Festival d’Avignon. The annual theater festival is held in July in the courtyard of the Palais des Papes in Avignon."
  - Location p30===from https://www.expatica.com/fr/lifestyle/holidays/top-french-festivals-444873/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.feature: The Chorégies d’Orange is an August opera festival held in a Roman theater in Orange, presenting classical music and opera productions in a historic setting with exceptional acoustics, drawing nearly 9,000 spectators annually.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.original:
- Quoted text "Dating back to 1869, the Chorégies d’Orange is the oldest festival in France and the place to be if you love opera and classical music. It takes place every August in a beautifully preserved Roman Theatre in Orange."
  - Location p33===from https://www.expatica.com/fr/lifestyle/holidays/top-french-festivals-444873/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.feature: The Festival of Lights in Lyon is a December event where the city is illuminated with candles, light installations, and projections, creating a magical atmosphere centered around religious homage and artistic expression.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.original:
- Quoted text "For four days in December, the city of Lyon comes aglow during the Festival of Lights, which pays homage to the Virgin Mary. Thousands of flickering candles can be seen in windows and on balconies, creating a beautiful and magical atmosphere."
  - Location p36===from https://www.expatica.com/fr/lifestyle/holidays/top-french-festivals-444873/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.feature: The French Cancan is a lively, high-energy dance characterized by high kicks and quick steps, traditionally performed by pairs in colorful costumes, and it originated in 19th-century Paris as part of cabaret culture.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.original:
- Quoted text "The French Cancan, a lively dance, features pairs who switch energetic moves with high kicks and quick steps. Known for its colorful costumes, it reflects dances with are distinctive style. Originating in 19th-century Paris, it reached its popularity peak then and remains a symbol of France has several beautiful dance and cabaret traditions."
  - Location p1===from https://civilisable.com/french-dance-styles/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.feature: The Valse Musette is a traditional French waltz from 19th-century Paris cafés, featuring slow, smooth movements and accordion-based music that evokes romance and nostalgia.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.original:
- Quoted text "The Valse Musette is one of the traditional French dance styles from Paris cafés in the 19th century. This dance style has slow, smooth movements and gentle turns. Its music, often played on accordion, brings a feeling of romance and nostalgia."
  - Location p2===from https://civilisable.com/french-dance-styles/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.feature: The Farandole is a medieval-style folk dance from Provence, performed in circles or lines with rhythmic steps, and remains central to traditional festivals in southern France.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.original:
- Quoted text "The Farandole, from Provence, is among France’s several beautiful and mostly medieval in fashion dances. Dancers form circles and feature pairs, following rhythmic steps. This lively dance’s popularity after World War II helped maintain it. The Farandole remains a key part of folk dances in southern France and traditional festivals."
  - Location p3===from https://civilisable.com/french-dance-styles/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.feature: The Bourrée is a fast-paced traditional dance from Central France, danced in pairs with lively steps and shifting rhythms between 2/4 and 6/8 time.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.original:
- Quoted text "The Bourrée is a fast traditional dance from Central France, danced in pairs with lively steps and shifting rhythms between 2/4 and 6/8 time."
  - Location p4===from https://civilisable.com/french-dance-styles/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.feature: The Maraîchine is a traditional dance from the Vendée region in Western France, historically linked to rural festivals and performed in lines or circles with simple, lively steps.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.original:
- Quoted text "The Maraîchine is a traditional French dance from the Vendée region, whose history often goes back to rural festivals. Dancers form lines or circles with lively rhythms and simple steps."
  - Location p5===from https://civilisable.com/french-dance-styles/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.feature: The Gavotte is a traditional French dance originating from Brittany and Dauphiné, associated with folk celebrations and later popularized in the 17th-century French court under the Sun King.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.original:
- Quoted text "The Gavotte is a traditional French dance from Brittany and Dauphiné, whose history often goes back to folk celebrations. Part of French Dance 101, it became popular in the French court during the 17th century, admired by the Sun King, who appreciated elegant performance."
  - Location p6===from https://civilisable.com/french-dance-styles/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.feature: The Menuet is a traditional French dance in triple time, originating in ancient times with live music accompaniment, and was less choreographed compared to other formal dances.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.original:
- Quoted text "The Menuet dance is usually danced in triple time and is less choreographed and coordinated. It dates back to ancient times, and music was usually played live."
  - Location p7===from https://civilisable.com/french-dance-styles/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.feature: The Courante is an older French dance style in triple time, historically less choreographed and accompanied by various music styles, with roots in ancient traditions.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.original:
- Quoted text "The Courante is one of the older French dance styles, usually danced in triple time. Mixes and variations started to occur over the centuries, showing how dance has changed throughout history. Often less choreographed and coordinated than others, it was usually played with different styles of music, and it dates back to ancient traditions."
  - Location p8===from https://civilisable.com/french-dance-styles/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.feature: The Gigue is a traditional French dance featuring energetic steps and a skipping motion, originally performed with music by street performers and later associated with bal musette.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.original:
- Quoted text "The Gigue dance features energetic steps and includes a skip. Music was usually played by street performers with diverse styles. Later, the bal musette became popular, leading to mixes and variations."
  - Location p9===from https://civilisable.com/french-dance-styles/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.feature: The Loure is a Baroque-era French dance from the 17th century with slow, majestic movements and dotted rhythms, once popular in French courts and now being revived by dance academies.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.original:
- Quoted text "The Loure, a traditional dance from the Baroque period, features slow, majestic movements and dotted rhythms. Popular in 17th-century French courts, it is among several beautiful and different dances."
  - Location p10===from https://civilisable.com/french-dance-styles/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.feature: The Passacaille is a historic French dance linked to royal courts, typically performed with music, and is part of efforts by dance academies to revive fading traditional forms.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.original:
- Quoted text "The Passacaille, one of the diverse traditional dances, was usually played with music. It is part of historic French dance styles linked to royal courts. Academies want to revive French tradition, as dances that have lost much popularity are changing."
  - Location p11===from https://civilisable.com/french-dance-styles/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.feature: The Chaconne is a traditional French dance that declined in popularity but was historically performed in bars or halls with music, and is currently experiencing revival efforts due to renewed interest in traditional culture.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.original:
- Quoted text "The Chaconne, one of several dances that lost much popularity, was usually played in bars or halls with music. Now, dance academies and troops aim at recapturing these beautiful traditional styles. Though once fading, a recent rise in traditional culture helps preserve their grandeur..."
  - Location p12===from https://civilisable.com/french-dance-styles/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.feature: The Tourdion is a traditional French dance related to the Gavotte, characterized by rapid, light hopping steps often done on one foot, and is preserved in modern times for its distinctive style.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.original:
- Quoted text "The Tourdion, part of Dance 101 and related to the Gavotte, is one of several beautiful and various French dance styles. This dance is being maintained with its distinctive rapid, light hopping steps, often danced with one foot."
  - Location p13===from https://civilisable.com/french-dance-styles/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.feature: The Java is a fast-paced French variation of the waltz from early 20th-century dance halls, known for rhythmic turns and a close partner hold, reflecting the vibrancy of French social life.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.original:
- Quoted text "The Java is a fast-paced French variation of the waltz, part of the vibrant tradition of French dance styles. It is characterized by rhythmic turns and a close hold between partners. The dance became popular in early 20th-century dance halls, where couples would glide around the floor in time with lively music."
  - Location p14===from https://civilisable.com/french-dance-styles/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.feature: Zouk is a French dance style influenced by Afro-Caribbean and French traditions, featuring flowing movements that reflect cultural blending and are being preserved through renewed traditional interest.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.original:
- Quoted text "Zouk is among several beautiful French dance styles shaped by Afro-Caribbean and French influences. Its flowing movements reflect changing and the beauty of cultural blends. Though some dances that lost much visibility, a recent rise in traditional interest has helped preserve them."
  - Location p16===from https://civilisable.com/french-dance-styles/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.feature: Unique musical traditions from each region of France have been preserved and passed down through generations.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.original:
- Quoted text "In addition, the folklore of each French region has preserved unique musical traditions that have been transmitted from generation to generation."
  - Location paragraph 3

No other characteristics combining traditional music and dance can be extracted, as the text does not mention traditional dance in the context of French culture.===from https://folkfiesta.net/en/post/musical-traditions-french-culture/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Always greet people with "Bonjour" (or "Bonsoir" in the evening) when entering shops, cafés, or homes, as failing to do so is considered rude.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "When entering any establishment – be it a small boutique, a bustling café, or a friend’s home – make sure you offer a friendly “Bonjour!” (or “Bonsoir” in the evening). This simple gesture is considered essential. Failing to greet someone properly, especially in smaller shops or local settings, can be perceived as rude or dismissive."
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://welcome.fr/en/top-10-cultural-etiquette-tips-for-visitors-to-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The cheek kiss ("la bise") is common among friends and acquaintances but should not be initiated in formal or professional settings; visitors should follow the other person’s lead.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The cheek kiss – known as “la bise” – is common among friends, family members, and even new acquaintances in some contexts. However, not everyone greets with la bise, especially in formal or professional settings. When you meet someone new, offering a handshake is typically safer unless the other person initiates the cheek kiss."
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://welcome.fr/en/top-10-cultural-etiquette-tips-for-visitors-to-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Begin interactions in French if possible, using basic phrases like “Bonjour, excusez-moi de vous déranger…”, as this shows respect for the language and culture.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "When you approach someone, start with a simple French greeting “Bonjour, excusez-moi de vous déranger…” This small gesture demonstrates respect for their language and culture."
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://welcome.fr/en/top-10-cultural-etiquette-tips-for-visitors-to-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Avoid discussing personal topics such as salary, religion, or political affiliation when speaking with new acquaintances.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "In French culture, certain topics – like someone’s salary, religion, or political affiliation – are considered quite personal and are usually avoided when chatting with new acquaintances."
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://welcome.fr/en/top-10-cultural-etiquette-tips-for-visitors-to-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Keep your voice low in public spaces such as public transport, and avoid loud conversations or boisterous behavior, which may draw unwanted attention.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The French can be quite reserved in public spaces – loud conversations or boisterous laughter might draw unwanted attention. On public transport, keep your voice low and avoid taking phone calls on speaker."
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://welcome.fr/en/top-10-cultural-etiquette-tips-for-visitors-to-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Offer a polite “bonjour” to neighbors when staying in an apartment or passing through residential areas, though extended conversations should not be initiated unless welcomed.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "If you are staying in an apartment or passing through a residential neighborhood, a polite “bonjour” to any neighbors you encounter is usually appreciated. Conversely, you wouldn’t strike up an overly friendly conversation in an elevator unless the other person seems open to it."
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://welcome.fr/en/top-10-cultural-etiquette-tips-for-visitors-to-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Always greet people with “Bonjour” when entering a shop or interacting with strangers, including service staff like waiters, and use “Au revoir” when leaving.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Say 'Bonjour' (hello ), 'Merci' (thank you) and 'au revoir' ( goodbye ) whenever you leave a place."  
  - Location paragraph 1===from https://www.private-frenchlessons-paris.com/blog/tips-french-etiquette

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Address unfamiliar individuals, including waiters, using “Monsieur” or “Madame” as a sign of respect.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Address strangers (including waiters) as 'Monsieur' or 'Madame'."  
  - Location paragraph 1===from https://www.private-frenchlessons-paris.com/blog/tips-french-etiquette

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Regularly use polite expressions such as “s’il vous plaît” (please), “merci” (thank you), and “je vous en prie” or “de rien” (you’re welcome) in any situation where appropriate.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "‘Please’ (s’il voul plait ), ‘Thank you’ ( merci ) and ‘You’re welcome’ ( je vous en prie or de rien) are used in any circumstances, whenever given the chance."  
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://www.private-frenchlessons-paris.com/blog/tips-french-etiquette

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Add a smile when using polite phrases to enhance the courtesy of the interaction.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "In both cases add a large smile to your sentence."  
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://www.private-frenchlessons-paris.com/blog/tips-french-etiquette

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Shake hands when being introduced to someone new; reserve cheek kissing (“la bise”) for people you know well, as initiating it with strangers may be inappropriate.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Shake hands when you are introduced to someone. Parisians do 'la bise' (one, sometimes two, kisses on each cheek) when meeting people they know; it could be considered as a faux pas to try la bise with people you have just met, unless they kiss first."  
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://www.private-frenchlessons-paris.com/blog/tips-french-etiquette

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Hugging is seen as inappropriate in French social interactions and should be avoided.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "American-style hugging strikes the French as inappropriate."  
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://www.private-frenchlessons-paris.com/blog/tips-french-etiquette

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Keep quiet or limit conversation with strangers in public spaces such as elevators or grocery stores, preserving personal privacy.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Silence can be very appropriate in France, especially among strangers... The French rarely strike up a conversation with their neighbours in the queue or discuss some intimate detail of their personal life."  
  - Location paragraph 10===from https://www.private-frenchlessons-paris.com/blog/tips-french-etiquette

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Talking about income, occupation, or financial matters is culturally frowned upon and considered vulgar or tacky.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "It is not in the culture to talk about money and it remains rather taboo. This means that if you want to meld into French life, avoid asking people what they do for a living or how much they earn... It would considered as vulgar, tacky and even boring..."  
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://www.private-frenchlessons-paris.com/blog/tips-french-etiquette

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Engage in discussions about food, art, politics, music, philosophy, and current events instead of money, as these are considered more appropriate and valued subjects.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Avoid talking about money and stick to safer routes such as French culture, art, food, music, philosophy, architecture, and popular events."  
  - Location paragraph 8===from https://www.private-frenchlessons-paris.com/blog/tips-french-etiquette

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: When attending a dinner, compliment the host’s cooking using positive adjectives and show appreciation for the dishes served.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Compliment your host it is the appropriate moment to use all the adjectives connected to food that you have learnt during your French lessons such as 'C’est vraiment délicieux' (it’s very delicious!), 'excellent, original!'."  
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://www.private-frenchlessons-paris.com/blog/tips-french-etiquette

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Offer help before, during, and after a dinner party as a sign of politeness and engagement.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Offer assistance to your French host (before, during and after the party)."  
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://www.private-frenchlessons-paris.com/blog/tips-french-etiquette

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Make an effort to use basic French phrases, such as asking “Vous parlez anglais?”, as this demonstrates respect and interest in the culture, and is appreciated by locals.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Don’t just assume everyone speaks English... learn a few key phrases, as it demonstrates your interest for the country and the culture... people will be thankful that you have made an effort to speak the language and immersed yourself in the culture."  
  - Location paragraph 9===from https://www.private-frenchlessons-paris.com/blog/tips-french-etiquette

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: When entering a shop, restaurant, elevator, or any small shared space, it is expected to greet others with “Bonjour” (before 6 PM) or “Bonsoir” (after 6 PM) as a sign of acknowledgment and respect.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "When entering a shop, restaurant, or even an elevator with only one other person, the French say “bonjour” (before noon) or “bonsoir” (after 6 PM)."  
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://francevibes.com/french-culture-and-etiquette/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The formal pronoun “vous” should be used when addressing strangers, service workers, elders, or people in authority, as it signifies respect and recognition of their autonomy.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Use vous with Anyone you don’t know personally, Shop workers, servers, hotel staff, Professional contacts, Older people, Anyone in a position of authority."  
  - Location paragraph 40===from https://francevibes.com/french-culture-and-etiquette/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: One should never initiate the use of the informal “tu” form; the transition from “vous” to “tu” must be proposed by the French person as a sign of growing intimacy.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Never initiate tu Let French people suggest the transition. Using tu prematurely is overly familiar and disrespectful."  
  - Location paragraph 41===from https://francevibes.com/french-culture-and-etiquette/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: When leaving a shop or ending an interaction, one should say “Au revoir” or “Bonne journée/soirée” to acknowledge the other person respectfully.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Departure “Au revoir, madame/monsieur” or “Bonne journée/soirée”"  
  - Location paragraph 8===from https://francevibes.com/french-culture-and-etiquette/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In contained public spaces like elevators, making eye contact and greeting someone is necessary to acknowledge shared space, unlike casual street greetings which are considered overly familiar.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "But in contained spaces like shops or elevators, the greeting acknowledges shared space temporarily."  
  - Location paragraph 9===from https://francevibes.com/french-culture-and-etiquette/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Smiling at strangers in public spaces such as streets or metros is not customary and may be perceived as suspicious or inappropriate.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The mistake American-style friendly smiling at strangers on streets or métro. Why it’s problematic Random smiling at strangers seems suspicious or suggests romantic interest."  
  - Location paragraph 32===from https://francevibes.com/french-culture-and-etiquette/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French married women keep their birth name (maiden name) on all official documents throughout their lives and do not adopt their spouse’s name legally.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "As a direct consequence, French married women keep their unmarried name on their official documents all their life."  
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://mafrenchlife.com/french-naming-rules/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The last name and first name on official documents must exactly match the names listed on the birth certificate; shortened or alternate versions (e.g., Ron for Aaron) are not accepted.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The first name on your passport should also exactly match the first name on your birth certificate. French governmental agencies will not accept documents as proof of ID if they use shortened first names, such as Ron for Aaron or Frank for Francis."  
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://mafrenchlife.com/french-naming-rules/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Individuals may use a "nom d’usage" (usage name) in daily life, which can be the spouse’s birth name, a combination of one’s own and spouse’s name, or one parent’s family name, but it does not replace the legal family name.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "In France, people can use a usual name (nom d’usage)... You must chose between spouse’s last name at birth... your last name at birth concatenated to your spouse’s family name... one of your parent’s family name."  
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://mafrenchlife.com/french-naming-rules/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The nom d’usage is displayed next to the legal family name on documents like passports, marked as "usage," but the legal name remains unchanged.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Noms d’usage don’t replace family names on official documents but they show as usage next to the family name."  
  - Location paragraph 8===from https://mafrenchlife.com/french-naming-rules/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: A child born in France must inherit a family name from one or both parents—either the father’s, mother’s, or a combined version—and siblings must share the same name as the first child.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The first child of a couple inherits his last name from his/her father, mother, both parent’s name combined, separated by a space. The siblings of the first child will get the same family name as the first child."  
  - Location paragraph 10===from https://mafrenchlife.com/french-naming-rules/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French citizens over 18 may change their last name once in their lifetime to one of their parents’ names or a combination of both, but changing to another name requires a legitimate reason and formal approval.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Since July 2022, French people over 18 can easily change their last name to one of their parent’s last name or a combination of both of their parent’s names... A French person can only make that change once in a lifetime."  
  - Location paragraph 12===from https://mafrenchlife.com/french-naming-rules/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French first names must follow strict spelling rules only the first letter is capitalized in single names; compound names have each part capitalized; only specific diacritics and ligatures are allowed.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Unlike in the United States, you cannot capitalize a letter in the middle of a first name... Compound first names (prénoms composés) have one capitalized letter at the beginning of each name... French first names can only contains letters from the French dictionary. The only authorized diacritics are à â ä é è ê ë ï î ô ö ù û ü ÿ ç. The 2 ligatures allowed are æ and œ."  
  - Location paragraph 14===from https://mafrenchlife.com/french-naming-rules/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: There are no naming suffixes like "Jr." or "II" in France; instead, terms like "père" (senior) and "fils" (junior) may be used conversationally to distinguish individuals with identical names, but these are not official name parts.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "There is no junior name suffix in France... To distinguish between 2 persons of a same family with the exact same name, you can say Jean Martin père (senior) and Jean Martin fils (junior). Those are not name suffixes though but simply a way to distinctively refer to people."  
  - Location paragraph 13===from https://mafrenchlife.com/french-naming-rules/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French names are often long and complex, frequently combining multiple given names or using hyphens to link several names, making them difficult for non-native speakers to pronounce.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "In France, it’s all about stringing together as many letters as possible to create a name that is virtually unpronounceable for non-native speakers."
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://namesflare.com/ridiculous-french-names-exploring-outlandish-naming-conventions-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French naming conventions commonly include the use of hyphens and apostrophes, resulting in compound names that may appear linguistically complex.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The French also have a fondness for using hyphens and apostrophes in their names, resulting in a jumble of consonants and vowels that even the most skilled linguist would struggle to decipher."
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://namesflare.com/ridiculous-french-names-exploring-outlandish-naming-conventions-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It is a tradition in France to use the father’s name as a middle name for children, serving to honor familial lineage and maintain generational connections.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "One important aspect of French names is the use of patronymics, which is the practice of using the father’s name as a middle name for children."
  - Location paragraph 1 (under "Cultural Significance of French Names")===from https://namesflare.com/ridiculous-french-names-exploring-outlandish-naming-conventions-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French names typically have clear gender associations, with specific names being used predominantly for boys or girls, reinforcing gender identity within naming practices.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "French names often have clear gender associations, with specific names being more commonly used for boys or girls."
  - Location paragraph 5 (under "Cultural Significance of French Names")===from https://namesflare.com/ridiculous-french-names-exploring-outlandish-naming-conventions-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French names are often chosen to reflect religious beliefs or historical significance, including names derived from saints, biblical figures, or notable national leaders.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Many traditional French names are derived from biblical figures or saints, such as Marie, Jean, or Pierre."  
  - Location paragraph 4 (under "Cultural Significance of French Names")===from https://namesflare.com/ridiculous-french-names-exploring-outlandish-naming-conventions-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Different regions in France exhibit distinct naming patterns influenced by local heritage, such as Celtic roots in Brittany or Italian influences in Corsica.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "In the Brittany region, located in the northwest of France, you will find names that have Celtic origins."  
  - Location paragraph 3 (under "Exploring Regional Variations in French Names")===from https://namesflare.com/ridiculous-french-names-exploring-outlandish-naming-conventions-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French names have origins in Latin, a legacy of the Roman occupation of Gaul, and evolved as Latin transformed into Romance languages including Old French.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The Latin influence on French names is particularly pronounced, a relic of the Roman occupation of Gaul. As Latin evolved into the Romance languages, including Old French, it left an indelible mark on personal names."
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://ilab.academy/en/french-names/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French names also derive from Germanic roots, introduced by Frankish tribes migrating into modern-day France, often reflecting warrior virtues and leadership.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Complementing the Latin roots, the Germanic influence emerged with the migration of Frankish tribes into what is now modern-day France. This intermingling of cultures added a robustness to French names, with names like ‘Louis’ (from the Germanic ‘Chlodowig’) and ‘Charles’ (from ‘Karl’) signifying power and leadership."
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://ilab.academy/en/french-names/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French names are influenced by regional languages such as Breton, Occitan, and Catalan, contributing to local identity and diversity in naming practices.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Regional languages, such as Breton, Occitan, and Catalan, contribute to the mosaic of French names, adding a layer of local color and identity. For instance, the name ‘Yves’ is of Breton origin, highlighting the regional diversity within French naming practices."
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://ilab.academy/en/french-names/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In border regions like Alsace and Lorraine, surnames show Germanic influence due to historical intermingling with neighboring countries, resulting in names such as “Schneider” or “Weber”.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "In Alsace and Lorraine, names might have Germanic influence, such as “Schneider” or “Weber”."
  - Location paragraph 9===from https://ilab.academy/en/french-names/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In Brittany, surnames reflect Celtic heritage, with examples such as “Le Roux” or “Le Gall” indicating ancestral ties to the region’s cultural background.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "In Brittany, Celtic heritage is evident with names like “Le Roux” or “Le Gall”."
  - Location paragraph 9===from https://ilab.academy/en/french-names/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Some popular French names, such as Emma, originate from Germanic roots and carry meanings related to completeness or universality.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Emma A name of Germanic origin meaning “whole” or “universal,” Emma has enjoyed a surge in popularity."
  - Location paragraph 11===from https://ilab.academy/en/french-names/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The name Lucas is derived from Latin, specifically from “lux” meaning “light,” and is associated with illumination and clarity in French culture.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Lucas Stemming from the Latin “lux,” meaning “light,” Lucas is associated with illumination and clarity."
  - Location paragraph 11===from https://ilab.academy/en/french-names/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The name Chloé originates from Greek, meaning “young green shoot,” symbolizing new growth, fertility, and renewal in French naming traditions.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Chloé Derived from the Greek “khloe,” meaning “young green shoot,” Chloé symbolizes new growth and fertility."
  - Location paragraph 11===from https://ilab.academy/en/french-names/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French names often derive from the names of cities, regions, or landmarks, reflecting the country's diverse landscapes and historical geography.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Many French names are derived from the names of cities, regions, or landmarks. For example, the name “Paris” is derived from the name of the famous capital city of France. Similarly, the name “Lorraine” comes from the region of the same name in northeastern France."
  - Location paragraph 8===from https://namesflare.com/exploring-the-meaning-and-origins-of-french-names/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Certain surnames are associated with specific regions in France, serving as regional identifiers that reflect local cultural identities.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "One way regional identities are expressed is through the use of specific names that are associated with a particular region. For example, names like Lévesque and Dupont are often associated with the Normandy region, while names like Dubois and Leroy are commonly found in the northern part of France."
  - Location paragraph 17===from https://namesflare.com/exploring-the-meaning-and-origins-of-french-names/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The prefix “de” in French surnames often signifies noble or aristocratic lineage and is particularly common in certain regions such as Provence and Burgundy.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The prefix “de” is commonly used in surnames and signifies a noble or aristocratic lineage. This prefix is often seen in names from the Provence and Burgundy regions."
  - Location paragraph 18===from https://namesflare.com/exploring-the-meaning-and-origins-of-french-names/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Some regions in France, such as the Basque region, have unique naming traditions, including the practice of inheriting both parents’ surnames, resulting in longer and more complex names.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "For example, in the Basque region, it is common for children to inherit both their father’s and mother’s surnames, resulting in longer and more complex names."
  - Location paragraph 19===from https://namesflare.com/exploring-the-meaning-and-origins-of-french-names/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French names frequently originate from Latin, Greek, or Celtic linguistic roots, reflecting historical and cultural influences on naming practices.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "French names often derive from Latin, Greek, or Celtic roots, reflecting historical and cultural influences."
  - Location p1 (Key Takeaways)===from https://names-meanings.net/origin-guides/french-names-meanings/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The popularity and persistence of certain French names are tied to their association with influential historical figures, especially royalty such as kings and emperors.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Many names gained popularity through historical figures who shaped France’s identity. For example, names like Louis or Charlemagne evoke the legacy of influential kings and emperors."
  - Location p2 (Origins and Historical Significance of French Names)===from https://names-meanings.net/origin-guides/french-names-meanings/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Many traditional French names are chosen based on religious significance, particularly those linked to Catholic saints, reflecting deep-rooted Christian traditions.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Many parents choose names inspired by saints to honor their faith and seek protection or blessings. The influence of saints on naming customs is significant; you’ll find a high prevalence of names like Marie, Jean, and Louis, linked to revered figures."
  - Location p3 (Religious Influences)===from https://names-meanings.net/origin-guides/french-names-meanings/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French names often have Latin or Germanic origins, reflecting centuries of cultural evolution and linguistic blending.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The data shows us something fascinating 68% of French names have Latin or Germanic origins, revealing centuries of cultural evolution and linguistic blending."
  - Location paragraph 1 of "The Timeless Appeal of French Names"===from https://teamgroupnames.com/french-names/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French names are deeply connected to historical figures, as evidenced by the large number of streets in Paris named after them, illustrating how name origins are intertwined with national identity.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Paris alone has over 6,000 streets named after historical French figures, showing how deeply names are woven into French cultural identity."
  - Location paragraph 1 of "The Timeless Appeal of French Names"===from https://teamgroupnames.com/french-names/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French names, particularly surnames and middle names, are used to honor family heritage by being passed down from ancestors, including both paternal and maternal lineages, and may reflect a child’s dual familial identity.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Middle names, often derived from grandparents or other relatives, serve as an additional homage to family ties and ancestry."
  - Location paragraph 1

- Rule Description Children may be named after grandparents or ancestors as a way to honor family history, reinforcing familial bonds and continuity.
- ===from https://ilab.academy/en/french-names/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French names carry cultural significance by evoking the legacy of notable historical and literary figures, linking personal identity to national heritage and collective memory.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "For the French, these names are more than mere labels; they are a celebration of cultural heritage and an homage to the enduring influence of the country’s storied past."
  - Location paragraph 2

- Rule Description Names like Jeanne and Louis are associated with bravery, national heroism, royalty, and historical importance due to their connection with figures such as Joan of Arc and King Louis XIV.
- ===from https://ilab.academy/en/french-names/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Popular French names are chosen for their meaningful connotations, reflecting virtues and characteristics valued in French society such as completeness, illumination, guidance, and renewal.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "These names are not just labels, but embodiments of history, traits, and aspirations that resonate with French parents and the values they wish to bestow upon their children."
  - Location paragraph 3

- Rule Description The meanings behind names like Emma (meaning “whole” or “universal”), Lucas (meaning “light”), and Chloé (symbolizing new growth and fertility) reflect ideals cherished in French culture.
- ===from https://ilab.academy/en/french-names/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French surnames often signify geographic origins or ancestral occupations, serving as markers of regional identity and historical livelihoods.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "French surnames reveal fascinating insights into regional identities and ancestral occupations. These surnames are not just labels inherited by birth; they are storied maps tracing the lineage of families to particular locales and trades."
  - Location paragraph 4

- Rule Description Surnames such as Boulanger (baker), Carpentier (carpenter), Roux (red-haired person), and Le Gall (Celtic heritage) reflect specific professions or regional linguistic influences.
- ===from https://ilab.academy/en/french-names/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French names often reflect regional identities and geographic origins, with specific names or naming patterns associated with particular regions of France.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "French names often carry significant regional identifiers, reflecting the diverse and rich cultures found throughout France."  
  - Location paragraph 1 (p1)

- Rule Description Certain surnames are commonly linked to specific regions, such as Lévesque and Dupont with Normandy, and Dubois and Leroy with northern France.  
- ===from https://namesflare.com/exploring-the-meaning-and-origins-of-french-names/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: When attending a casual social gathering, such as a dinner party at a friend’s home, it is considered polite to arrive 10 to 15 minutes late, as this gives the host time to finish preparations.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "For casual gatherings – like a dinner party at a friend’s home – arriving 10 to 15 minutes late is often considered polite, as it gives your host some final prep time."
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://welcome.fr/en/top-10-cultural-etiquette-tips-for-visitors-to-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Arriving late for reservations, especially at restaurants, is discouraged in France, as punctuality is highly valued in such settings.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "On the other hand, don’t arrive late for reservations. Punctuality is valued in France, especially in restaurants."  
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://travelpander.com/dos-and-don-t-when-visiting-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It is customary to arrive 15 minutes late when invited to a dinner in France, as arriving exactly on time is not considered appropriate.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Don’t arrive exactly on time in France. When you are invited to diner, never arrive on time. Fifteen minutes late is ideal."
  - Location paragraph 4

- Rule Description Arriving 15 minutes late is considered normal when visiting someone’s home for dinner.
- ===from https://www.private-frenchlessons-paris.com/blog/tips-french-etiquette

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French women may wear ballerina flats with a suit when commuting to work, and might change into heels once at the office.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "A French woman would still wear some kind of ballerinas with a suit, on her way from the métro to work, and then maybe change into heels at work."  
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://www.thoughtco.com/what-shoes-to-wear-in-france-1371484

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French men typically wear small, delicate lace-up tennis shoes resembling old-fashioned sneakers or street shoes rather than bulky athletic shoes in casual settings.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "There's a kind of shoe that is typical for French (younger) men they are tennis shoes, with laces, but smaller, more delicate than athletic—kind of old fashioned tennis shoes, like street shoes or sneakers."  
  - Location paragraph 9===from https://www.thoughtco.com/what-shoes-to-wear-in-france-1371484

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Flip-flops are fashionable for young French men in summer, but only if their feet and nails are well-groomed; otherwise, they avoid wearing them.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "For young adults, les tongs (flip-flops) are also very fashionable... But, and this is essential, a Frenchmen would show his feet only if their feet and nails are impeccable."  
  - Location paragraph 10===from https://www.thoughtco.com/what-shoes-to-wear-in-france-1371484

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Wearing socks with sandals is considered a major fashion faux-pas in France.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Socks and sandals are a big fashion faux-pas in France."  
  - Location paragraph 10===from https://www.thoughtco.com/what-shoes-to-wear-in-france-1371484

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Leather shoes are required for formal occasions or going out, and most French men own at least one pair.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "For dressy wear or going out, leather shoes are a must, and every French man would have at least one pair of leather shoes—many would wear leather shoes everyday."  
  - Location paragraph 11===from https://www.thoughtco.com/what-shoes-to-wear-in-france-1371484

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Guests should bring a gift when visiting a French friend’s home, as arriving empty-handed is considered impolite; appropriate gifts include wine, flowers (excluding chrysanthemums), chocolates, pastries, or a small item from one's country.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Don’t arrive empty-handed."
  - Location p4===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/8/23/cultural-dos-and-donts-for-visiting-a-french-friends-house

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Guests are expected to accept the apéritif offered by the host unless they have a serious reason such as health, pregnancy, or sobriety, as declining it may be seen as disrespectful.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The apéritif is sacred. Don’t decline it unless you have a serious reason (like pregnancy, sobriety, or health)."
  - Location p7===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/8/23/cultural-dos-and-donts-for-visiting-a-french-friends-house

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It is polite for guests to compliment the host’s home upon arrival, even if they are not particularly interested in interior design.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Even if you’re not a design critic, it’s polite to acknowledge your host’s home."
  - Location p6===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/8/23/cultural-dos-and-donts-for-visiting-a-french-friends-house

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Guests may offer once to help clear the table after the meal, but must respect the host’s decision if the offer is declined, as insisting or helping without permission can cause embarrassment.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Offer once 'Je peux t’aider à débarrasser ?' If declined, respect it."
  - Location p9===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/8/23/cultural-dos-and-donts-for-visiting-a-french-friends-house

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Guests should never criticize the food and should refrain from exploring areas of the house not accessible during normal interaction, as both behaviors violate unspoken rules of politeness.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Don’t snoop around the house. Don’t criticize the food."
  - Location p10===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/8/23/cultural-dos-and-donts-for-visiting-a-french-friends-house

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Guests should verbally express thanks for the evening and the meal before leaving, and sending a follow-up message the next day is considered an extra polite gesture.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Say 'Merci beaucoup pour cette soirée, c’était délicieux !' ... A follow-up message the next day is extra polite."
  - Location p11===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/8/23/cultural-dos-and-donts-for-visiting-a-french-friends-house

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: When invited to a meal at someone’s home, it is expected that guests arrive 15 to 20 minutes after the set time, rather than arriving exactly on time.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "However, when invited for a meal at someone’s house, one is expected not to arrive à l’heure (on time). It is best to arrive about 15 to 20 minutes after the set time."
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-etiquette

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Guests invited to a dinner may be expected to bring something, such as a bottle of wine or dessert, and often ask the host in advance if they should bring an item.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "When invited to a dinner, it is common for guests to ask their hosts if they are required to bring something on the day. Guests may also bring a bottle of wine or dessert."
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-etiquette

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: If bringing wine as a gift, it should be of high quality, as French people appreciate wine and expect good offerings.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "If you give wine, ensure it is of the highest quality you can offer. French people appreciate their wines."
  - Location paragraph 10===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-etiquette

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: When invited to an apéro (a pre-dinner drink event with food), guests should bring gourmet items such as tapenade, olives, fresh bread, or cheese, rather than simple snacks like chips.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "If you are invited to an apéro, it is best to bring something gourmet (rather than a bag of chips/crisps). For example, tapenade, olives, fresh bread, or cheese would be appropriate."
  - Location paragraph 8===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-etiquette

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It is considered rude not to greet everyone present upon arrival and departure, regardless of the number of people.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "It is seen as rude if you do not greet everyone when arriving and leaving, regardless of how many people are present."
  - Location paragraph 9===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-etiquette

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Guests are generally expected to dress well when visiting someone’s home.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Guests are usually expected to dress well."
  - Location paragraph 9===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-etiquette

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Guests should arrive 10–15 minutes late to a dinner party, as arriving exactly on time is considered overly eager or inflexible and does not allow the host sufficient time for final preparations.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Arrive 10-15 minutes late (never early, never on time)"
  - Location paragraph 69===from https://francevibes.com/french-culture-and-etiquette/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Suitable gifts for hosts include flowers (excluding chrysanthemums and red roses), chocolates, or specialty items from one’s home country; wine is acceptable but should be of good quality and its serving is not expected.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Bring flowers (but not chrysanthemums—they’re for cemeteries, or red roses—they’re romantic). Wine is tricky—bring good wine, but don’t expect it to be served that evening (it implies you don’t trust host’s selection). Chocolates or specialty items from your country work well."
  - Location paragraph 70===from https://francevibes.com/french-culture-and-etiquette/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Guests should expect a pre-dinner drinks period lasting 30 to 60 minutes, during which light conversation occurs before the meal begins.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Aperitif period Guests gather for pre-dinner drinks and light conversation. This can last 30-60 minutes—don’t expect to eat immediately."
  - Location paragraph 72===from https://francevibes.com/french-culture-and-etiquette/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Guests must wait to be told where to sit, as seating is typically assigned, with couples separated and the guest of honor seated to the host’s right.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Wait to be told where to sit. Couples are usually separated. Guest of honor sits to host’s right."
  - Location paragraph 74===from https://francevibes.com/french-culture-and-etiquette/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Acceptable conversation topics include politics, philosophy, culture, and art; personal finance, salaries, and costs are inappropriate, while religion may be discussed intellectually but not devotionally.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Politics, philosophy, culture, art—all acceptable topics. Personal finance, salaries, costs—inappropriate topics. Religion can be discussed intellectually but not devotionally."
  - Location paragraph 75===from https://francevibes.com/french-culture-and-etiquette/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Guests should not begin eating before the hostess starts, should compliment the food sincerely, take moderate initial portions, participate in all courses, and rest cutlery parallel on the plate when finished.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Never start eating before the hostess begins. Compliment the food sincerely and specifically. Take moderate portions initially (seconds may be offered). Participate in all courses even if you’re full. Rest cutlery parallel on plate when finished (pointing to 1020 on clock face)."
  - Location paragraph 77===from https://francevibes.com/french-culture-and-etiquette/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French dinner parties typically last between 3 to 5 hours, and leaving before coffee and digestifs are served is considered rude unless previously explained.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "French dinner parties last 3-5 hours minimum. Leaving before coffee and digestifs is rude unless you’ve explained in advance."
  - Location paragraph 78===from https://francevibes.com/french-culture-and-etiquette/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Guests should thank the hosts warmly upon departure and send a follow-up message or email the next day to express appreciation.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Thank hosts warmly upon leaving. Send a follow-up text or email the next day expressing appreciation."
  - Location paragraph 79===from https://francevibes.com/french-culture-and-etiquette/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It is customary and expected to bring a small gift when invited to someone’s home for a meal in France, even for casual gatherings.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "it is uncommon to arrive at someone’s home empty-handed, especially if you’ve been invited for a meal."
  - Location p3===from https://www.laclassedestelle.com/blog/gifts-for-french-hosts

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Common and appropriate gifts include wine, flowers, homemade treats, or regional gourmet specialties that reflect personal or local character.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Wine remains the classic and most frequently cited option... A good bottle of red, white, or sparkling wine is always welcome..."
  - Location p5  
  - Quoted text "Flowers are also a common choice, especially when the host is someone the guest does not know well, or when invited for the first time."
  - Location p6  
  - Quoted text "Some guests like to prepare something at home to bring with them a cake, a tart, or another dessert."
  - Location p7  
  - Quoted text "A thoughtful option mentioned by several respondents is to bring a specialty from one’s own region. This could be artisanal jam, biscuits, olive oil, or other gourmet items..."
  - Location p8===from https://www.laclassedestelle.com/blog/gifts-for-french-hosts

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Guests should avoid bringing exceptionally expensive gifts, such as a high-end wine, as this may make the host uncomfortable.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "some care should be taken not to bring an exceptionally expensive bottle, which could make the host feel uncomfortable."
  - Location p5===from https://www.laclassedestelle.com/blog/gifts-for-french-hosts

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Even for informal apéritif gatherings, guests are expected to bring something to contribute, such as snacks or drinks, to participate in the shared experience.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "guests are still expected to bring something to contribute, even if it’s just a bag of crisps or a bottle of wine."
  - Location p9  
  - Quoted text "The idea is to show that you are not simply there to consume but to participate in the shared experience."
  - Location p9===from https://www.laclassedestelle.com/blog/gifts-for-french-hosts

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: When staying at someone's home for a weekend or holiday period, it is customary to bring a more generous gift as a reflection of the host’s extended effort.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "If you are invited to spend the weekend at someone’s home, or to stay for a holiday period, it is customary to bring something more generous."
  - Location p10===from https://www.laclassedestelle.com/blog/gifts-for-french-hosts

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It is not customary to include a card with a gift when giving it in person; verbal expressions of gratitude or occasion are considered sufficient.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Most respondents said they do not include a card when offering a gift in person. A simple 'joyeux anniversaire' or 'merci encore' spoken aloud is considered sufficient."
  - Location p12===from https://www.laclassedestelle.com/blog/gifts-for-french-hosts

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: When invited to someone’s home, it is customary to bring a small, high-quality gift for the host, typically a bottle of wine.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "When invited to someone’s home, try to bring a small, good-quality gift for the host. Usually one will bring a bottle of wine."
  - Location paragraph 1===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-etiquette

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: If giving wine as a gift, it should be of the highest quality possible, as French people appreciate fine wines.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "If you give wine, ensure it is of the highest quality you can offer. French people appreciate their wines."
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-etiquette

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Young couples who have been married for less than a year or are engaged should not be seated separately; however, couples married for over a year may be seated apart.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "You can actually sit a couple separately as long as they have been married for over a year. Young couples, married for less than a year, or fiancés cannot be separated."
  - Location p2===from https://lesmenusplaisir.com/en/french-etiquette-at-a-dinner-party/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The primary guest of honor should be seated to the right of the host, especially if they are a religious representative, an elderly person, or a first-time guest; other honored guests should be placed to the left of the host.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Place your guests of honor to the right of the hosts as well as if they are a religious representative, an old person or someone who is invited for the first time. Any other guest of honor will be placed to the left of the hosts."
  - Location p2===from https://lesmenusplaisir.com/en/french-etiquette-at-a-dinner-party/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: When hosting a dinner, the host and their spouse typically sit across from each other, unless the dinner is specifically in honor of a particular individual.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "When you host a dinner, your spouse sits across from you, unless the dinner party is thrown in honor of someone in particular."
  - Location p2===from https://lesmenusplaisir.com/en/french-etiquette-at-a-dinner-party/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The guest of honor is seated to the right of the host, reflecting status and respect within the seating arrangement.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Guest of honor → right of the host."  
  - Location paragraph 10===from https://www.grandcruandetiquette.com/journal/french-table-manners-and-dining-etiquette

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Couples are typically seated separately to encourage more diverse and engaging conversation among guests.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Couples → often separated to encourage diverse conversation."  
  - Location paragraph 10===from https://www.grandcruandetiquette.com/journal/french-table-manners-and-dining-etiquette

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Women are usually given priority by being seated first at the table.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Women → usually seated first."  
  - Location paragraph 10===from https://www.grandcruandetiquette.com/journal/french-table-manners-and-dining-etiquette

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Wait until everyone at the table has been served before beginning to eat, as a sign of respect and consideration for dining companions.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Wait to Eat Until Everyone is Served Good manners dictate that you wait until everyone at the table has been served before you begin eating. This shows respect and consideration for your dining companions."
  - Location paragraph 10 (section 3 Navigate French Dining Etiquette)===from https://welcome.fr/en/top-10-cultural-etiquette-tips-for-visitors-to-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: When invited to a French home, it is customary to bring a small gift such as flowers (excluding chrysanthemums), wine, or chocolates.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Bring a small gift Flowers (but not chrysanthemums), wine, or chocolates."
  - Location paragraph 10===from https://frenchglimpses.com/2025/04/10/essential-french-manners-you-need-to-know/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Arriving 10–15 minutes late is considered polite when invited to a French home.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Punctuality Arriving 10–15 minutes late is actually polite."
  - Location paragraph 10===from https://frenchglimpses.com/2025/04/10/essential-french-manners-you-need-to-know/
