Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Guests should compliment the food when visiting a French home.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Compliment the food Always."
  - Location paragraph 10===from https://frenchglimpses.com/2025/04/10/essential-french-manners-you-need-to-know/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Visitors should express gratitude upon leaving by saying “Merci pour l’invitation.”
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Say “Merci pour l’invitation” when you leave."
  - Location paragraph 10===from https://frenchglimpses.com/2025/04/10/essential-french-manners-you-need-to-know/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Guests should arrive 10 to 15 minutes late to a dinner party, as arriving exactly on time is considered overly eager or inflexible, and this delay allows the host time for final preparations.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Arrive 10-15 minutes late (never early, never on time). This lateness (le quart d’heure de politesse—the polite quarter-hour) allows hosts final preparations. Arriving exactly on time suggests you’re overeager or inflexible."  
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://francevibes.com/french-culture-and-etiquette/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Guests should bring a gift for the host, such as flowers (excluding chrysanthemums and red roses), chocolates, or specialty items from their country; wine may be brought but should be of good quality and not expected to be served immediately.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Bring flowers (but not chrysanthemums—they’re for cemeteries, or red roses—they’re romantic). Wine is tricky—bring good wine, but don’t expect it to be served that evening (it implies you don’t trust host’s selection). Chocolates or specialty items from your country work well."  
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://francevibes.com/french-culture-and-etiquette/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Guests should expect a pre-dinner drinks period lasting between 30 to 60 minutes and should not anticipate eating immediately upon arrival.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Aperitif period Guests gather for pre-dinner drinks and light conversation. This can last 30-60 minutes—don’t expect to eat immediately."  
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://francevibes.com/french-culture-and-etiquette/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Guests must wait to be told where to sit, as seating is assigned; couples are typically separated and the guest of honor sits to the host’s right.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Wait to be told where to sit. Couples are usually separated. Guest of honor sits to host’s right."  
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://francevibes.com/french-culture-and-etiquette/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Guests should not begin eating until the hostess starts, should compliment the food sincerely, take moderate initial portions, participate in all courses, and rest cutlery parallel on the plate when finished.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Never start eating before the hostess begins. Compliment the food sincerely and specifically. Take moderate portions initially (seconds may be offered). Participate in all courses even if you’re full. Rest cutlery parallel on plate when finished (pointing to 1020 on clock face)."  
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://francevibes.com/french-culture-and-etiquette/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Dinner conversation values intelligence and spirited debate on topics like politics, philosophy, and culture; personal finance, religion (as belief), and costs are inappropriate, and passionate disagreement is normal and not personal.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "French dinner conversation values intelligence, wit, and spirited debate. Politics, philosophy, culture, art—all acceptable topics. Personal finance, salaries, costs—inappropriate topics. Religion can be discussed intellectually but not devotionally. Passionate disagreement is normal—don’t take it personally."  
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://francevibes.com/french-culture-and-etiquette/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Dinner parties typically last a minimum of 3 to 5 hours, and leaving before coffee and digestifs is considered rude unless previously explained.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "French dinner parties last 3-5 hours minimum. Leaving before coffee and digestifs is rude unless you’ve explained in advance."  
  - Location paragraph 8===from https://francevibes.com/french-culture-and-etiquette/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Guests should thank the hosts warmly upon departure and send a follow-up message or email the next day to express appreciation; a handwritten note is elegant but rare.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Thank hosts warmly upon leaving. Send a follow-up text or email the next day expressing appreciation. A handwritten note is elegant but increasingly rare."  
  - Location paragraph 9===from https://francevibes.com/french-culture-and-etiquette/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Wait until everyone at the table has been served and the host says "Bon appétit" before beginning to eat.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Wait until everyone at the table has their food, and the host says Bon appétit before you begin eating."  
  - Location paragraph 15 (under section "4. DINING DOS AND DON’TS 🍽️")===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/6/7/lgwqqeq2hvj7pj84i1lr5resyqma0k

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Show appreciation for a meal by saying “merci” or complimenting the food, such as saying “C’est délicieux,” to contribute positively to the dining atmosphere.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "A sincere C’est délicieux or Merci pour ce repas is appreciated and adds to the good vibe at the table."  
  - Location paragraph 15 (under section "4. DINING DOS AND DON’TS 🍽️")===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/6/7/lgwqqeq2hvj7pj84i1lr5resyqma0k

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French cuisine generally does not rely heavily on salt for flavor, prioritizing fresh and high-quality ingredients instead.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "I can tell you that in general good French cuisine does not rely on a lot of salt to be flavorful. Instead flavor is sought after in using the very freshest and highest quality ingredients."  
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://www.easy-french-food.com/sodium-in-french-food.html

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French restaurants are often sympathetic to dietary restrictions, and it is socially acceptable to request food prepared without salt or with sauces served separately.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "When dining out, you will find that many restaurants will be sympathetic to your needs. In France it would not be considered outrageous to ask for special attention to be paid in how a food is prepared or served in a restaurant."  
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://www.easy-french-food.com/sodium-in-french-food.html

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Packaged foods in France may carry specific labels indicating low or no sodium content, such as “sans sodium,” “faible en sodium,” “teneur réduite en sodium,” and “sans sel ajouté.”
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "When dining out, you will find that many restaurants will be sympathetic to your needs. In France it would not be considered outrageous to ask for special attention to be paid in how a food is prepared or served in a restaurant. Stick to restaurants that have simply prepared menu items and you should have no problem being served without the salt. Asking that any sauce be served on the side should be fine as well."  
  - Location paragraph 8===from https://www.easy-french-food.com/sodium-in-french-food.html

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In French culinary practice, fleur de sel is traditionally used as a finishing salt, applied to dishes just before serving to enhance flavor with its crunchy texture.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Fleur de sel from France Harvested by hand from the surface of salt pans, fleur de sel is a delicate, flaky salt with a subtle flavor and crunchy texture. It is often used as a finishing salt to add a burst of flavor to dishes just before serving."  
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://www.numberanalytics.com/blog/the-ultimate-guide-to-salt-in-european-cuisine

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Salt plays an essential role in traditional French cuisine, particularly in dishes like bouillabaisse, where it balances the flavors of seafood and broth.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Bouillabaisse A hearty fish stew from France that relies on salt to balance the flavors of the broth and the seafood."  
  - Location paragraph 10===from https://www.numberanalytics.com/blog/the-ultimate-guide-to-salt-in-european-cuisine

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Wine is the most popular alcoholic beverage in France and is deeply integrated into daily life, often consumed with meals and viewed as part of the country’s culinary heritage.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The most popular type of alcohol consumed in France is wine."  
  - Location p13===from https://tableandspoon.com/what-alcohol-do-the-french-drink/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The French emphasize moderation in drinking, often enjoying alcohol in social settings such as family dinners or outdoor events, and associate it with responsible behavior rather than excessive consumption.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The French approach to drinking is often seen as more responsible and moderate, with an emphasis on enjoying drinks in a social setting, rather than binge drinking."  
  - Location p16===from https://tableandspoon.com/what-alcohol-do-the-french-drink/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Alcohol, especially wine, is traditionally paired with food in France to bring out flavors and enhance the overall dining experience, reflecting the integration of drinking culture with cuisine.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The French have a long tradition of pairing wine with food, with different wines being paired with different dishes to bring out the flavors and aromas."  
  - Location p17===from https://tableandspoon.com/what-alcohol-do-the-french-drink/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: While the legal drinking age in France is 18, younger individuals may be introduced to alcohol like wine at an earlier age in social or familial contexts.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The typical drinking age in France is 18 years old, although it is not uncommon for younger people to be introduced to wine and other drinks at a younger age."  
  - Location p16===from https://tableandspoon.com/what-alcohol-do-the-french-drink/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Champagne holds a special cultural role and is primarily associated with celebrations, milestones, and formal toasts, symbolizing luxury and elegance.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Champagne is often associated with luxury, elegance, and sophistication, making it a popular choice for weddings, anniversaries, and other milestone events."  
  - Location p14===from https://tableandspoon.com/what-alcohol-do-the-french-drink/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Pastis is culturally significant in southern France, particularly in Provence, where it is served as an apéritif during social gatherings and summer months, symbolizing hospitality and conviviality.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Pastis is a symbol of French hospitality, and it is not uncommon to see the French offering pastis to guests as a sign of welcome and friendship."  
  - Location p15===from https://tableandspoon.com/what-alcohol-do-the-french-drink/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Cognac is traditionally consumed after meals as a digestif, reflecting its role in concluding a meal and contributing to the sophisticated nature of French drinking customs.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Cognac is a type of brandy that is produced exclusively in the Cognac region of France. It is known for its rich, complex flavor profile and is often enjoyed as a digestif after meals."  
  - Location p9===from https://tableandspoon.com/what-alcohol-do-the-french-drink/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Pork is deeply embedded in French culinary traditions and is used in a wide variety of dishes across regions, reflecting its importance in French gastronomy.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Cochon, the French word for pig, is a testament to the rich culinary traditions of France. From the succulent rôtis to the decadent terrines, pork plays an integral role in French gastronomy."  
  - Location p1===from https://www.linguavoyage.org/fr/24272.html

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Pigs have historically been essential to rural French communities, providing both food and cooking fat, especially during the Middle Ages.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Pigs have been a staple food source in France for centuries. In the Middle Ages, the pig played a vital role in the survival of rural communities, providing sustenance and fat for cooking."  
  - Location p2===from https://www.linguavoyage.org/fr/24272.html

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Different regions of France have developed unique pork-based dishes that reflect local ingredients and traditions.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Pork is a culinary chameleon that adapts effortlessly to the diverse regions of France. In Normandy, the pork is combined with apples for a dish called Tête de Porc à la Normande... In Alsace, pork is marinated in Riesling wine and spices for Choucroute Garnie... In the southwest of France, pork is paired with beans for Cassoulet..."  
  - Location p6===from https://www.linguavoyage.org/fr/24272.html

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The preservation and preparation of pork through charcuterie is a fundamental aspect of French cuisine, with specific regional products like Jambon de Bayonne and Saucisson de Lyon.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Charcuterie, the art of preserving meats, is an essential part of French cuisine. Pork products are particularly well-suited for charcuterie, offering a range of textures and flavors that can be enhanced through various curing and smoking techniques."  
  - Location p4===from https://www.linguavoyage.org/fr/24272.html

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French cuisine utilizes less common parts of the pig such as tripe and feet, which are featured in traditional dishes like Andouille de Vire and Pieds de Cochon.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "French cuisine also embraces offal and other parts of the pig that are often overlooked in other cultures. Andouille de Vire, a sausage made from pig tripe, is a popular ingredient in soups and stews. Pieds de Cochon, or pig's feet, are often braised or roasted until tender and served with a flavorful sauce."  
  - Location p5===from https://www.linguavoyage.org/fr/24272.html

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Modern French chefs are reinterpreting pork in innovative ways, incorporating new techniques and global influences into contemporary dishes.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "In recent years, there has been a growing trend towards using pork in innovative and modern dishes. Chefs are experimenting with new cuts and cooking techniques, creating pork dishes that are both delicious and visually appealing."  
  - Location p7===from https://www.linguavoyage.org/fr/24272.html

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Pork is the primary and most widely used meat in French charcuterie, forming the foundation of traditional preparations due to its versatility, flavor, and suitability for preservation.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Pork is without a doubt the most widely used meat in French charcuterie."
  - Location p6===from https://meatcheftools.com/what-is-the-most-used-meat-in-french-charcuterie/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French charcuterie emphasizes using nearly every part of the pig, reflecting a historical practice of resourcefulness and waste reduction in household pig raising.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "When families raised pigs, they ensured that practically every part was used, thereby yielding a wide array of products."
  - Location p7===from https://meatcheftools.com/what-is-the-most-used-meat-in-french-charcuterie/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Different regions in France produce distinct pork-based charcuterie items influenced by local customs, ingredients, and cultural practices, resulting in regional specialties.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Each region shapes its pork delicacies based on local customs, available ingredients, and cultural influences, leading to a delightful diversity within French charcuterie."
  - Location p9===from https://meatcheftools.com/what-is-the-most-used-meat-in-french-charcuterie/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The preparation of pork in French charcuterie often follows artisanal methods passed down through generations, highlighting craftsmanship and tradition.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Many charcutiers (charcuterie specialists) in France still practice techniques that have been passed down through generations."
  - Location p15===from https://meatcheftools.com/what-is-the-most-used-meat-in-french-charcuterie/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Pork-based charcuterie plays a central role in social gatherings, where it is shared communally on charcuterie boards, fostering connection and appreciation for food.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "In social contexts, charcuterie boards are focal points that bring people together."
  - Location p16===from https://meatcheftools.com/what-is-the-most-used-meat-in-french-charcuterie/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: When invited to a French home for a meal or party, it is expected to bring a gift for the host, preferably before the event begins.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "When you are invited to a French home for a meal or a party, it’s expected that you’ll bring a gift. You’ll want to give your gift to the host before the party or event begins."
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://www.annieandre.com/a-guide-to-gift-giving-and-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The most appropriate gifts for a host in France are high-quality flowers, chocolates, or liqueur; giving low-quality items is considered offensive.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The most commonly gifted items to a host are flowers, chocolates, or liqueur in French culture. Whichever you choose, make sure that it is a high-quality item. Giving something cheap is considered an insult."
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://www.annieandre.com/a-guide-to-gift-giving-and-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Certain flowers carry specific meanings in France—chrysanthemums are associated with funerals, red roses with romantic interests, and carnations with bad luck—so they should be avoided unless appropriate.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "If you choose to give flowers, the type of flowers you choose will say a lot. Chrysanthemums are given at funerals, while red roses are given to romantic interests. Carnations often symbolize bad luck."
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://www.annieandre.com/a-guide-to-gift-giving-and-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Flowers should be given in odd numbers according to an old European tradition, making a baker’s dozen more suitable than a dozen.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "An old European tradition says that flowers should be gifted in odd numbers. In other words, skip a dozen roses and go for a baker’s dozen to make a better impression."
  - Location paragraph 8===from https://www.annieandre.com/a-guide-to-gift-giving-and-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Wine is not typically recommended as a gift because the host usually selects it; instead, after-dinner drinks like dessert wine, liqueur, or port are safer choices.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "While wine is commonly given as a gift to the host in the US, this isn’t always a good idea or proper etiquette in France. In France, the host will typically make the wine selection... If you want to give alcohol, a safe choice is a bottle of something meant to drink after the meal, an after-dinner digestif dessert wine or liqueur, port etc."
  - Location paragraph 9===from https://www.annieandre.com/a-guide-to-gift-giving-and-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Giving corporate gifts in France is not expected, and most people prefer hosting events or dinners instead of exchanging gifts.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "It’s not just friends and families that we give gifts to... However, when it comes to corporate gift-giving in France, this is not something that’s expected. Most people in France skip the gifts and simply hold an event or dinner for their business contact."
  - Location paragraph 11===from https://www.annieandre.com/a-guide-to-gift-giving-and-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Giving promotional items with company logos is considered vulgar in France and should be avoided in favor of more personal gifts.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "In the United States, it’s fairly commonplace for us to dish out swag at the end of a business meeting. In France, however, this is considered vulgar. Skip the company logo gifts and instead opt for something personal."
  - Location paragraph 12===from https://www.annieandre.com/a-guide-to-gift-giving-and-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Including a business card with a gift is against French business etiquette and should be avoided.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Another American tradition is to throw in your business card with the gift you’re giving... In France, this goes against proper business etiquette, so make sure to leave your business card out."
  - Location paragraph 13===from https://www.annieandre.com/a-guide-to-gift-giving-and-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Sending gifts by mail to someone’s home is inappropriate and may seem strange; all gifts should be presented in person.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "While sending a gift to someone’s home in the United States may be considered okay, this is not okay in France. In fact, it could come across as creepy. Always make sure to give gifts in person to avoid an awkward situation."
  - Location paragraph 14===from https://www.annieandre.com/a-guide-to-gift-giving-and-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Gifts in France should be both practical and thoughtful, reflecting the recipient’s interests, hobbies, and daily needs.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "In the realm of French gift-giving, practicality and thoughtfulness take precedence. When selecting a gift, delve into the recipient’s interests, hobbies, and everyday needs."  
  - Location paragraph 1 under "Do of Gift Giving Etiquette in France" (p8)===from https://giftvant.com/gift-giving-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Adding a personalized touch such as engraving or a handwritten note increases the emotional value of the gift.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Elevate your gift by infusing a personalized touch, a cherished practice in French culture. Consider engraving initials, including a handwritten note, or choosing a gift that resonates with the recipient’s personality and preferences."  
  - Location paragraph 2 under "Do of Gift Giving Etiquette in France" (p9)===from https://giftvant.com/gift-giving-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Gifts must be wrapped neatly with high-quality materials, as presentation reflects care and respect in French culture.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The presentation of your gift matters significantly in French gift-giving etiquette. Wrap your chosen item with precision and flair, using high-quality wrapping paper adorned with a decorative ribbon."  
  - Location paragraph 3 under "Do of Gift Giving Etiquette in France" (p10)===from https://giftvant.com/gift-giving-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Gifts should be presented upon arrival or at an appropriate moment during a social interaction, aligning with expectations of punctuality and timing.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Timing is key—offer your gift during the initial greeting or a suitable moment in the social exchange for maximum impact."  
  - Location paragraph 3 under "Do of Gift Giving Etiquette in France" (p10)===from https://giftvant.com/gift-giving-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It is customary for recipients to open gifts immediately upon receiving them so the giver can witness their reaction.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Opening gifts immediately upon receipt is a courteous practice, allowing the giver to witness the recipient’s genuine reaction and expressions of gratitude."  
  - Location paragraph 6 under "Do of Gift Giving Etiquette in France" (p13)===from https://giftvant.com/gift-giving-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Gifts should not be excessively expensive, as this may cause discomfort; modesty and appropriateness are valued.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "French gift-giving thrives on modesty and thoughtfulness. Steer clear of excessively expensive presents that may cause discomfort or embarrassment."  
  - Location paragraph 5 under "Do of Gift Giving Etiquette in France" (p12)===from https://giftvant.com/gift-giving-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Handmade gifts such as drawings, paintings, or homemade food are cherished because they reflect effort and personal attention.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Handmade gifts hold a special place in French culture, embodying effort and thoughtfulness. Whether it’s a drawing, painting, or a batch of homemade treats, these crafted offerings are often cherished for the personal touch they convey."  
  - Location paragraph 7 under "Do of Gift Giving Etiquette in France" (p14)===from https://giftvant.com/gift-giving-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: If someone receives a gift, they are expected to return a gift of equal or slightly lesser value as a sign of mutual respect.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "If you receive a gift, reciprocate with a thoughtful present of equal or slightly lesser value. This practice underscores mutual respect and contributes to the ongoing exchange of thoughtful gestures."  
  - Location paragraph 8 under "Do of Gift Giving Etiquette in France" (p15)===from https://giftvant.com/gift-giving-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Re-gifting is frowned upon in France because it suggests indifference and lack of effort.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "In French culture, the act of re-gifting is generally frowned upon as it can convey a sense of indifference and a lack of effort."  
  - Location paragraph 1 under "Donts of Gift Giving Etiquette in France" (p16)===from https://giftvant.com/gift-giving-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Perishable items or those with short shelf lives should be avoided, especially if they have dietary restrictions.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "French gift-giving leans towards durable offerings with lasting value. Steer clear of perishable items or gifts with short shelf lives, especially if they come with dietary restrictions."  
  - Location paragraph 2 under "Donts of Gift Giving Etiquette in France" (p17)===from https://giftvant.com/gift-giving-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Gifts should not serve as tools for self-promotion, as this may be seen as insincere or self-serving.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Using gifts as a platform for self-promotion is discouraged in French culture. Such gestures may be perceived as insincere or self-serving."  
  - Location paragraph 3 under "Donts of Gift Giving Etiquette in France" (p18)===from https://giftvant.com/gift-giving-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Gifts should not carry hidden messages, especially romantic or inappropriate connotations, to prevent misunderstandings.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Avoid presenting gifts that carry hidden meanings or may be misconstrued, particularly as romantic or inappropriate. Prioritize neutral gifts that respect personal boundaries."  
  - Location paragraph 5 under "Donts of Gift Giving Etiquette in France" (p20)===from https://giftvant.com/gift-giving-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Poor wrapping or lack of attention to presentation reduces the perceived value of the gift and shows disrespect.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Neglecting the wrapping and overall presentation can diminish the perceived value of the gift. Ensure that your gift is wrapped neatly and thoughtfully, upholding the cultural emphasis on aesthetic presentation."  
  - Location paragraph 6 under "Donts of Gift Giving Etiquette in France" (p21)===from https://giftvant.com/gift-giving-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Failing to reciprocate after receiving a gift goes against French customs and undermines mutual respect.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "If you receive a gift, make an effort to reciprocate with a thoughtful present of equal or slightly lesser value. This practice underscores mutual respect and contributes to the ongoing exchange of meaningful gestures."  
  - Location paragraph 7 under "Donts of Gift Giving Etiquette in France" (p22)===from https://giftvant.com/gift-giving-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Gift givers must be aware of cultural taboos and avoid items that could be offensive or disrespectful in the French context.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Be vigilant about cultural differences and sensitivities when selecting gifts. Certain items may be considered taboo or offensive in French culture. Conduct thorough research to avoid unintentional cultural faux pas."  
  - Location paragraph 8 under "Donts of Gift Giving Etiquette in France" (p23)===from https://giftvant.com/gift-giving-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Gifts in French culture should be elegantly wrapped, as the manner of presentation is considered crucial.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "It’s also important to remember that the manner of presenting a gift is crucial. Gifts should be elegantly wrapped..."
  - Location paragraph 15===from https://www.checkcharm.com/cultural/the-art-of-gifting-in-french-culture-what-to-know/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: When attending a dinner party, it is polite to offer the gift to the hostess upon arrival.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "When attending a dinner party, it’s polite to offer the gift to the hostess upon arrival."
  - Location paragraph 15===from https://www.checkcharm.com/cultural/the-art-of-gifting-in-french-culture-what-to-know/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: A gift is often accompanied by a personal note or card with a heartfelt message to enhance its impact and show sincerity.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "It’s common for the offering to be accompanied by a personal note. A simple card with a heartfelt message can make your gift stand out and truly touch the recipient."
  - Location paragraph 15===from https://www.checkcharm.com/cultural/the-art-of-gifting-in-french-culture-what-to-know/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Chrysanthemums should be avoided when giving flowers as gifts because they are associated with mourning; red roses should also be avoided unless expressing romantic feelings.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Flowers also make a good choice, but beware of cultural faux pas – avoid chrysanthemums, which are typically associated with mourning. It might also be wise to steer clear of red roses unless there’s a romantic sentiment you wish to express."
  - Location paragraph 15===from https://www.checkcharm.com/cultural/the-art-of-gifting-in-french-culture-what-to-know/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French gifting culture values high-quality, tasteful gifts over expensive or numerous items, emphasizing thoughtfulness and sophistication.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "When in doubt, go for quality over quantity. French culture appreciates gifts that are simple yet high in quality."
  - Location paragraph 8===from https://www.checkcharm.com/cultural/the-art-of-gifting-in-french-culture-what-to-know/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Giving very expensive gifts is discouraged as it may be seen as an attempt to outshine others and is generally frowned upon.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Gifting etiquette in France dictates that some gifts can send the wrong message. For example, giving someone very expensive gifts can feel like an attempt to outshine, which is often frowned upon."
  - Location paragraph 20===from https://www.checkcharm.com/cultural/the-art-of-gifting-in-french-culture-what-to-know/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Overly practical gifts, such as domestic appliances or utilitarian items, are not well-received in social contexts as they may imply domestic duty and blur personal boundaries.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Avoiding overly practical gifts for social occasions is also wise. The French tend to separate the personal and domestic spheres, so domestic appliances or overly utilitarian items might not be well-received as they could imply domestic duty."
  - Location paragraph 21===from https://www.checkcharm.com/cultural/the-art-of-gifting-in-french-culture-what-to-know/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Giving gifts to school teachers is not obligatory, but if done, a box of chocolates or a thoughtful card is appreciated; more expensive gifts like scarves or wine may be given in some schools where it is a tradition.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "You’re under absolutely no obligation to give a present. If your kids insist, a box of chocolates or a thoughtful card will be appreciated. But talk to other parents at your kids’ school – we’ve heard of some teachers receiving things like scarves and bottles of wine for the holidays. If gift giving is a tradition at your particular school, you may feel compelled to fall in line."
  - Location p3===from https://www.frenchasyoulikeit.com/french-gift-giving-etiquette-les-etrennes/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It is thoughtful but not required to give a small gift such as flowers, a handwritten note, or another token to extra-curricular instructors, especially after a performance or event they organized.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "It’s thoughtful, though not necessary, to offer a little something to your kids’ soccer coach, ballet teacher or private tutors. If the teacher has produced a December recital, concert or performance, you may want to present the teacher with flowers, a handwritten note or card, or another small gift at that time."
  - Location p4===from https://www.frenchasyoulikeit.com/french-gift-giving-etiquette-les-etrennes/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Gifts for building concierges or janitors are expected and typically range from 5% to 10% of monthly rent or mortgage, or between €50 and €300, depending on local norms.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "When it comes to your concierge and gardien, gifts get a little more pricey. The going price is – gasp – 5% to 10% of your monthly rent or mortgage. If that seems too steep, ask others in your building but typically, apartment dwellers give anything from €50 to €300 at Christmas."
  - Location p5===from https://www.frenchasyoulikeit.com/french-gift-giving-etiquette-les-etrennes/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It is customary to give house cleaners and babysitters either a cash gift equivalent to one month’s salary or an amount between €50 and €100, optionally accompanied by a personal gift such as flowers, chocolates, or a scarf.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Some say offer a month’s salary to your femme de ménage (cleaning person); other says that €50 – €100 is sufficient. If you feel close to her or know her tastes, a gift of flowers, chocolates, or a scarf – in addition to cash – is also acceptable. The same works for babysitters (nounous) too."
  - Location p6===from https://www.frenchasyoulikeit.com/french-gift-giving-etiquette-les-etrennes/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Public workers such as garbage collectors and firefighters receive cash tips placed in an envelope, usually between €5 and €25, with possible increases for personal assistance during the year; firefighters often give calendars in return.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Be aware that the French usually tip public workers for their service. The tip must always be in cash, and placed in an envelope. If you’re going to be away for the holidays, give the gift before you leave. Typically, these workers get between €5 and €25 – possibly more if they have helped you personally during the year. Usually, the firefighters will give you a calendar in exchange."
  - Location p7===from https://www.frenchasyoulikeit.com/french-gift-giving-etiquette-les-etrennes/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Postal carriers are typically given between €5 and €25 in exchange for a calendar they offer, with the understanding that generosity may improve service.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Give €5 to €25 in exchange for the calendar they’ll inevitably offer. You’re free to buy it or not, but service may improve if you’re generous."
  - Location p8===from https://www.frenchasyoulikeit.com/french-gift-giving-etiquette-les-etrennes/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Gifts for children in the context of French language learning should prioritize educational value, language development, and age-appropriate skills.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "the activities included in these Lovevery kits are INCREDIBLE for language learning and age-appropriate developmental skills."
  - Location p4===from https://123petitspas.com/best-french-gifts-for-kids/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Interactive electronic books and devices that provide audio support in French are culturally favored gifts to aid pronunciation and vocabulary acquisition.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "This electronic book allows little ones to practice some of our favourite French tunes! Songs like 'Bateau sur l'eau' and 'Petit lapin' are included. It's great to have the French lyrics as you listen to the tune together."
  - Location p5===from https://123petitspas.com/best-french-gifts-for-kids/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Toys that engage sensory exploration and physical interaction are valued for supporting French vocabulary learning through play.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Making a book into a sensory experience is perfect for this age!"
  - Location p8===from https://123petitspas.com/best-french-gifts-for-kids/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Gifts that enable parents to participate in their child’s French learning, such as crash courses or bilingual tools, are considered meaningful and practical.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Although this gift may be used by the parents rather than the infants, I promise there's no better gift than the gift of using a second language at home!"
  - Location p9===from https://123petitspas.com/best-french-gifts-for-kids/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Bilingual books paired with tools like reading wands that offer spoken French are culturally preferred to support independent and accurate language exposure.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "These books are a genius idea by two Mothers who wanted their children to be able to read the same book in different languages, AND with support! The magic reading wand reads aloud in either of your chosen languages (and you can click on anything, not just the words!)."
  - Location p10===from https://123petitspas.com/best-french-gifts-for-kids/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French books for young children are expected to use repetition, simple language, and engaging themes to facilitate language learning.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "There's a lot of repetition and not much writing on each page - it's the perfect level for young readers and/or for parents hoping to learn some French alongside their child."
  - Location p13===from https://123petitspas.com/best-french-gifts-for-kids/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Board games are culturally recognized as effective tools for practicing French vocabulary, counting, and question-answer structures in a family setting.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Board games are a great way to practice your French and Sequence is one of my household's favourites. With this game you can practice animal names, counting, and common board game vocabulary."
  - Location p15===from https://123petitspas.com/best-french-gifts-for-kids/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French learning gifts for children should be fun and engaging to maintain interest, especially when teaching foundational language skills.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "It's hard to find workbooks that are engaging, but this one has been my son's favourite so far!"
  - Location p14===from https://123petitspas.com/best-french-gifts-for-kids/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In France, it is considered courteous to open gifts immediately upon receipt, as this allows the giver to witness the recipient’s genuine reaction and expressions of gratitude.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Opening gifts immediately upon receipt is a courteous practice, allowing the giver to witness the recipient’s genuine reaction and expressions of gratitude."
  - Location paragraph 10===from https://giftvant.com/gift-giving-etiquette-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It is considered polite to open a gift in the presence of the giver, as this gesture shows appreciation and acknowledges the thought behind the gift.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Moreover, it is polite to open the gift in front of the giver. This act demonstrates appreciation and acknowledgment of the gesture."  
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://travelpander.com/what-are-gifts-placed-in-france/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Greetings are considered essential social norms in France and must be observed in most interactions, especially when entering a shop, starting a conversation, or joining a group.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Saying bonjour when entering a shop, beginning a conversation, or joining a group is expected and considered a fundamental sign of good manners."  
  - Location p2===from https://gogofrance.com/en/blog/french-greetings/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Failing to greet someone can be perceived as impolite or disrespectful, even in casual settings.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Neglecting to greet someone can be seen as rude or dismissive, even in casual interactions."  
  - Location p2===from https://gogofrance.com/en/blog/french-greetings/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The greeting "bonjour" is appropriate in nearly all contexts and should be used when entering any shared space where people are present.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "It’s customary to greet everyone with bonjour when you enter a room or space."  
  - Location p3===from https://gogofrance.com/en/blog/french-greetings/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The greeting should change based on the time of day—use "bonsoir" instead of "bonjour" after approximately 6 PM.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "After around 6 PM, switch to bonsoir (good evening)."  
  - Location p3===from https://gogofrance.com/en/blog/french-greetings/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Informal greetings like "salut" and "coucou" are only suitable among friends, peers, or in playful contexts, and not in formal situations.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Salut is a casual, friendly greeting. Coucou is even more playful and affectionate, often used with close friends, children, or in text messages."  
  - Location p4===from https://gogofrance.com/en/blog/french-greetings/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The number of cheek kisses involved in "la bise" varies by region in France, ranging from two to four.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The number of kisses varies by region, ranging from two to four."  
  - Location p8===from https://gogofrance.com/en/blog/french-greetings/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: A handshake is used in formal or professional contexts, or when cheek kissing is inappropriate, typically during meetings or introductions.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "In formal or professional contexts, or when la bise feels inappropriate, a handshake is the standard. It’s firm, brief, and used when meeting someone or concluding a meeting."  
  - Location p9===from https://gogofrance.com/en/blog/french-greetings/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Using formal titles such as "Monsieur" or "Madame" along with "bonjour" demonstrates respect and cultural awareness, especially when uncertain about familiarity.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "When in doubt, default to Bonjour Monsieur or Bonjour Madame rather than a simple Bonjour."  
  - Location p10===from https://gogofrance.com/en/blog/french-greetings/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Greetings are considered important in French culture and are necessary to make a good impression.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Greetings are important in France. Thus, it is necessary to greet others correctly to make a good impression."
  - Location p1===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-greetings

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: A handshake is the standard greeting in business settings or when meeting acquaintances, and one is expected to shake hands with everyone present upon arrival and departure.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Handshakes are the norm in a business setting or with acquaintances. It is expected that you will shake hands with everyone present when arriving and leaving."
  - Location p2===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-greetings

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Among friends and relatives, the common greeting is ‘la bise’, which involves cheek kissing with a kiss sound, repeated on both cheeks, and may include an embrace.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Among friends and relatives, the most common greeting is the ‘la bise’ (kiss on both cheeks). The la bise consists of placing one’s cheek against another’s, making a kiss noise, then repeating it on the opposite side. A la bise is sometimes accompanied with an embrace."
  - Location p3===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-greetings

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: While two kisses are typical during ‘la bise’, the number can vary by region, and one should follow the lead of their French counterpart.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "People generally kiss twice during a la bise; however, this varies depending on the region in France. In this instance, follow your French counterpart."
  - Location p4===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-greetings

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: One should remove sunglasses and/or hats when performing ‘la bise’ as a sign of respect.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "One should remove their sunglasses and/or hat when doing a la bise."
  - Location p5===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-greetings

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Respect in verbal greetings is shown by addressing individuals as ‘Madam’ or ‘Monsieur’, with ‘Madam’ now used for all women regardless of marital status.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Respect is shown in verbal greetings by referring to the person as ‘Madam’ (‘Ms’) or ‘Monsieur’ (‘Mr’). Though previously the title ‘Madam’ referred to a married woman and ‘Mademoiselle’ referred to an unwed woman, this practice is no longer commonplace. Instead, ‘Madam’ is the title used to address any woman, regardless of her marital status."
  - Location p6===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-greetings

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In formal contexts or when speaking to elders, individuals should be addressed by their last name and appropriate title until invited to use first names.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "In formal contexts or when speaking to elders, use last names and appropriate titles until you are invited by your French counterpart to move on to a first-name basis."
  - Location p7===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-greetings

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Academic titles should be acknowledged if applicable when addressing someone.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "It is important to acknowledge someone by their academic title (if relevant)."
  - Location p8===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-greetings

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In formal settings, a person should be addressed by their title at the beginning of any conversation or request.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "In a formal setting, addressing someone by their title always precedes any conversation or request (e.g. “Madam, would you like a drink?”)."
  - Location p9===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-greetings

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It is expected to greet people with "bonjour" when meeting someone, entering a store, or leaving a place, as it is considered rude not to do so before asking questions or making requests.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Politeness is a cornerstone of French etiquette. Saying bonjour (hello), merci (thank you), and au revoir (goodbye) is expected when meeting someone, entering a store, or leaving a place. It’s considered quite rude to ask a question or make a request without first saying bonjour."  
  - Location paragraph 6

- Rule Description Using polite expressions such as "s’il vous plaît," "merci," and "je vous en prie" or "de rien" is essential in daily interactions and part of standard greeting etiquette.  
- ===from https://www.private-frenchlessons-paris.com/blog/10-french-greeting-expressions-and-etiquette

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In France, greetings are mandatory when entering enclosed public spaces such as shops, restaurants, or elevators with someone present, and they serve as a sign of respect and acknowledgment of the other person’s presence.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "When entering a shop, restaurant, or even an elevator with only one other person, the French say “bonjour” (before noon) or “bonsoir” (after 6 PM). This isn’t pointless ceremony—it’s acknowledging the other person’s existence, their right to courtesy, their humanity."
  - Location paragraph 5

- Rule Description The appropriate greeting depends on the time of day—“Bonjour” is used from morning until noon, and “Bonsoir” is used in the afternoon and evening.
- ===from https://francevibes.com/french-culture-and-etiquette/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It is mandatory to greet others with "Bonjour" or "Bonsoir" in daily interactions, depending on the time of day—“Bonjour” before 6 PM and “Bonsoir” after.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Always say Bonjour or Bonsoir This is non-negotiable. Even if you are just asking for directions or buying a baguette, you must start with “Bonjour.” After 6 PM, switch to “Bonsoir.”"
  - Location p2===from https://frenchglimpses.com/2025/04/10/essential-french-manners-you-need-to-know/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Failing to greet someone is considered impolite, even if the visitor does not speak French well.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Skipping a greeting is considered rude, even if you don’t speak French well."
  - Location p2===from https://frenchglimpses.com/2025/04/10/essential-french-manners-you-need-to-know/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: When leaving a shop, café, or meeting, it is expected to say "Au revoir."
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Au revoir Always say goodbye when leaving a shop, café, or meeting."
  - Location p2===from https://frenchglimpses.com/2025/04/10/essential-french-manners-you-need-to-know/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In formal or business settings, or when greeting acquaintances, men typically greet each other with a handshake. It is expected to shake hands with everyone present upon arrival and departure.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Handshakes are the norm in a business setting or with acquaintances. It is expected that you will shake hands with everyone present when arriving and leaving."  
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-greetings

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: When greeting men in formal contexts or when addressing elders, it is respectful to use last names along with appropriate titles (e.g., “Monsieur”), and one should wait to be invited before using first names.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "In formal contexts or when speaking to elders, use last names and appropriate titles until you are invited by your French counterpart to move on to a first-name basis."  
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-greetings

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Male acquaintances, including close male friends, commonly use a handshake when greeting, especially in professional or less intimate contexts.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Handshakes may also be used among male acquaintances (close male friends are more likely to faire la bise)."  
  - Location paragraph 14===from https://frenchtogether.com/blog/french-greetings

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Close male friends may exchange la bise (cheek kisses), though it is less common than among women.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Handshakes may also be used among male acquaintances (close male friends are more likely to faire la bise)."  
  - Location paragraph 14===from https://frenchtogether.com/blog/french-greetings

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Men typically do not exchange la bise with male colleagues in the workplace, especially post-pandemic, opting instead for verbal greetings or handshakes.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "For instance, most men probably won’t exchange the bise with their male colleagues or male strangers at a party. Instead, they’d shake hands or just say hello."  
  - Location paragraph 12===from https://frenchtogether.com/blog/french-greetings

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The practice of exchanging la bise between men, particularly in workplaces, has significantly decreased due to the Covid pandemic and increased awareness from movements like MeToo.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Since Covid, it’s become increasingly rare for people to exchange la bise with coworkers or strangers."  
  - Location paragraph 13===from https://frenchtogether.com/blog/french-greetings

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Men in France commonly shake hands to greet each other in family, friendly, or professional settings.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The majority of men shake hands to greet each other, whether in a family, friendly or professional environment."
  - Location paragraph 10===from https://www.ohlalafrenchcourse.com/en/blog/article/greeting-someone-in-french

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Men may also use cheek kissing (la bise) to greet each other, though this is a familiar gesture typically reserved for friends and family.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "La bise remains an equally familiar gesture to do with friends and family."
  - Location paragraph 12

(Note The text states that "everyone kisses each other (on the cheek) women to each other, women and men, and sometimes men to each other," but only explicitly confirms that men sometimes engage in la bise. Therefore, the rule is framed as a possibility under familiar conditions.)===from https://www.ohlalafrenchcourse.com/en/blog/article/greeting-someone-in-french

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Women in France commonly greet each other with cheek kisses (la bise), which is considered a familiar gesture typically used among friends and family.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "La bise remains an equally familiar gesture to do with friends and family."
  - Location paragraph 14

- Rule Description Women may also use handshakes when greeting women they do not know well, particularly in professional or formal settings.
- ===from https://www.ohlalafrenchcourse.com/en/blog/article/greeting-someone-in-french

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Women are generally expected to exchange cheek kisses (faire la bise) when greeting each other, especially in social or informal settings.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Women are pretty much always expected to faire la bise, but there are often exceptions for men."
  - Location paragraph 15===from https://frenchtogether.com/blog/french-greetings

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Female coworkers may exchange cheek kisses, though this practice has become significantly less common since the Covid pandemic.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Due to the Covid pandemic, it’s become significantly less common to do la bise with coworkers."
  - Location paragraph 17===from https://frenchtogether.com/blog/french-greetings

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Many French women feel uncomfortable or annoyed with having to exchange cheek kisses with female coworkers or female strangers.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Numerous articles in sources like French women’s magazines have shown that many French women feel uncomfortable or annoyed with having to faire la bise to coworkers and strangers."
  - Location paragraph 16===from https://frenchtogether.com/blog/french-greetings

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In formal or initial interactions between men and women, a handshake is the expected greeting, particularly in business settings or with acquaintances.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Handshakes are the norm in a business setting or with acquaintances."
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-greetings

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Among friends and relatives, including between men and women, the common greeting may be ‘la bise’ (a kiss on both cheeks), which involves cheek contact and a kissing sound, sometimes accompanied by an embrace.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Among friends and relatives, the most common greeting is the ‘la bise’ (kiss on both cheeks). The la bise consists of placing one’s cheek against another’s, making a kiss noise, then repeating it on the opposite side. A la bise is sometimes accompanied with an embrace."
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-greetings

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Men and women may greet each other with a cheek kiss (la bise), which is a familiar gesture typically used among friends and family.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "La bise remains an equally familiar gesture to do with friends and family."  
  - Location paragraph 13  

- Rule Description Men and women may exchange a handshake, particularly in professional and formal settings when they do not know each other well.  
- ===from https://www.ohlalafrenchcourse.com/en/blog/article/greeting-someone-in-french

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Women are generally expected to exchange cheek kisses ("la bise") with others, including in some workplace settings, while men are often exempt from this expectation, especially when greeting other men.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Women are pretty much always expected to faire la bise, but there are often exceptions for men."
  - Location paragraph 15===from https://frenchtogether.com/blog/french-greetings

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It is increasingly uncommon for coworkers of any gender to exchange "la bise" in professional settings since the Covid pandemic, particularly between men and women.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Since Covid, it’s become increasingly rare for people to exchange la bise with coworkers or strangers."
  - Location paragraph 18===from https://frenchtogether.com/blog/french-greetings

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: A man should not assume that a female coworker expects or wants to exchange "la bise", and should be cautious about initiating it.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "But don’t assume that it’s expected or wanted - especially if you’re a man greeting a female coworker."
  - Location paragraph 20===from https://frenchtogether.com/blog/french-greetings

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Appointments for business meetings must be scheduled at least two weeks in advance.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Appointments are necessary and should be made at least two weeks in advance."  
  - Location paragraph 1===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-business-culture

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Business meetings should not be scheduled during August or on workdays adjacent to public holidays, due to vacation periods.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Avoid scheduling meetings in August (the month of summer vacation) or on workdays next to a public holiday."  
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-business-culture

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Appointments can be arranged either in writing or by telephone.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Common ways to make an appointment are in writing or by telephone."  
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-business-culture

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The scheduling of appointments may be managed by a secretary, particularly depending on the seniority of the person being met.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Depending on the level of the person you are meeting, the appointment scheduling is often handled by the secretary."  
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-business-culture

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It is common practice to send a meeting invitation (un avis de convocation) and/or the meeting agenda (un ordre du jour) to participants before a business meeting in French.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "It’s common practice to send a meeting invitation (un avis de convocation) and / or the meeting agenda (un ordre du jour) to the participants."  
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://live-french.net/blog/business-french/prepare-business-meeting-french/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Business attire in France is typically formal, with men expected to wear suits and ties, and women expected to appear smart and professional; however, heels are not required for women.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Business attire in France is usually formal. Men are usually in suits and ties, while women are expected to look smart. Ties are expected, but heels are not expected."
  - Location paragraph 8===from https://snippetsofparis.com/french-business-etiquette/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In startup environments, business casual attire such as khakis and sneakers is acceptable, though sweatshirts and hoodies are generally avoided unless the person is an intern.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "If the company is a startup, the attire will be business casual with kakis and sneakers. There are usually no sweatshirts or hoodies, unless one is an intern."
  - Location paragraph 8===from https://snippetsofparis.com/french-business-etiquette/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Makeup and jewelry should be understated and low-key, following the principle of minimalism; however, one eye-catching accessory may be added for impact.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Makeup is not required and is usually kept understated. In addition, jewelry is also kept low-key. In the words of the famous French designer Coco Chanel, 'before you leave the house, look in the mirror and take one thing off.' For maximum punch, add one eye-catching piece such as dangly earrings, a bracelet, or broach."
  - Location paragraph 9===from https://snippetsofparis.com/french-business-etiquette/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Business attire in Paris should be classic and tailored, reflecting a polished and sophisticated appearance; men are expected to wear dark suits, white shirts, and leather shoes, while women should wear tailored dresses, skirt suits, or pantsuits with modest heels.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Men should wear a dark suit, crisp white shirt, and leather shoes. Women typically opt for a tailored dress, skirt suit, or pantsuit, paired with modest heels."
  - Location p8===from https://girlsfrance.com/blog/paris-business-meeting-etiquette-how-to-avoid-common-faux-pas

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Jeans and sneakers should be avoided unless the meeting is explicitly informal, as casual clothing does not align with French professional expectations.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Avoid overly casual clothing like jeans or sneakers unless the meeting is explicitly marked as informal."
  - Location p8===from https://girlsfrance.com/blog/paris-business-meeting-etiquette-how-to-avoid-common-faux-pas

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Accessories should be tasteful and understated, such as a refined watch or silk scarf, to enhance professionalism without distracting from the business discussion.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Subtle accessories, such as a tasteful watch or a silk scarf, add a refined touch without drawing attention away from the discussion."
  - Location p8===from https://girlsfrance.com/blog/paris-business-meeting-etiquette-how-to-avoid-common-faux-pas

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The overall aim of one’s appearance should be to look polished and respectful of the sophisticated aesthetic valued by French professionals.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:

  - Location paragraph 7===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/8/29/how-to-politely-interrupt-someone-in-french-yes-it-happens

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: One should wait for a pause, change in rhythm, or breath from the speaker before interrupting politely.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Wait for A pause, A change in the speaker’s rhythm, An intake of breath. That’s your window to interject politely."
  - Location paragraph 14===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/8/29/how-to-politely-interrupt-someone-in-french-yes-it-happens

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In business meetings, using a raised hand or slight forward lean can signal politely that one wishes to speak.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "In France, gestures accompany speech. A raised hand or slight forward lean signals politely that you’d like to speak."
  - Location paragraph 15===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/8/29/how-to-politely-interrupt-someone-in-french-yes-it-happens

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: After interrupting, one should keep their comment short to avoid appearing rude.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Keep It Short. If you interrupt, be concise. Long-winded interjections are seen as rude."
  - Location paragraph 16===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/8/29/how-to-politely-interrupt-someone-in-french-yes-it-happens

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In professional settings, extra care should be taken when interrupting someone of higher status.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Ignoring Social Hierarchy In professional settings, be particularly cautious when interrupting superiors."
  - Location paragraph 19===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/8/29/how-to-politely-interrupt-someone-in-french-yes-it-happens
