Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Young people often engage in public displays of affection such as embracing or kissing.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Young people will often engage in public displays of affection, such as embracing or kissing."
  - Location paragraph 1 (under "Physical Contact")===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-communication

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The French commonly greet friends, family, and acquaintances by lightly brushing cheeks and mimicking a kiss, typically without actual lip contact.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Lean forward and slightly brush cheeks with the other person while mimicking a kiss (with the sound and lips gesture). Then, switch cheeks and repeat."
  - Location p4===from https://www.frenchpod101.com/blog/2019/08/16/french-body-gestures/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Handshakes are a standard greeting among friends, colleagues, and strangers, characterized by being brisk and firm with eye contact.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "French handshakes are brisk and firm, with one or two up-and-down movements while looking the person you’re greeting straight in the eyes."
  - Location p5===from https://www.frenchpod101.com/blog/2019/08/16/french-body-gestures/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Among younger generations, informal greetings such as fist bumps or more elaborate sequences ("Check") are becoming common, influenced by hip-hop and urban culture.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "In casual settings, the Afro-American “Check” is growing increasingly popular. For the French, the “Check” is a generational thing, spread through hip-hop and urban culture without any racial aspect. Checks can range from a simple fist bump to a highly choreographed sequence of moves."
  - Location p5===from https://www.frenchpod101.com/blog/2019/08/16/french-body-gestures/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The French tend to stand or sit closer during informal interactions with friends or acquaintances, as closer proximity signifies intimacy and connection.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "In casual settings, such as with friends or acquaintances, the French might stand or sit closer than what is typical in some other cultures. This closeness can create a sense of intimacy and connection, reflecting the French emphasis on personal relationships."
  - Location p5===from https://www.learnfrenchwithsonal.com/personal-space-and-touch-in-french-interactions/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Standing too far away in casual conversations may be interpreted as aloofness or disinterest.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Standing too far away might be interpreted as aloofness or disinterest, so it’s important to be mindful of the distance you maintain during informal conversations."
  - Location p6===from https://www.learnfrenchwithsonal.com/personal-space-and-touch-in-french-interactions/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In professional environments, the French maintain a more formal distance, though it may still be closer than in some other cultures; the appropriate distance depends on formality and business relationship.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "In professional settings, the French maintain a more formal distance, though it may still be closer than in some other cultures. The level of formality and the nature of the business relationship will often dictate the appropriate distance."
  - Location p7===from https://www.learnfrenchwithsonal.com/personal-space-and-touch-in-french-interactions/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: During business meetings, maintaining a respectful yet engaged distance is important to avoid appearing intrusive or disengaged.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "During meetings or business interactions, maintaining a respectful but engaged distance is key. Avoid standing too close, which could be seen as intrusive, or too far, which might be perceived as disengaged."
  - Location p8===from https://www.learnfrenchwithsonal.com/personal-space-and-touch-in-french-interactions/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In crowded public areas like public transportation or busy markets, minimal personal space is normal, and the French typically remain calm and nonchalant in such situations.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "In crowded public spaces, such as on public transportation or in busy markets, personal space can be minimal. The French are accustomed to these environments and often navigate them with a sense of nonchalance."
  - Location p9===from https://www.learnfrenchwithsonal.com/personal-space-and-touch-in-french-interactions/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Close physical proximity in crowded urban settings is not considered rude but rather a cultural norm.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "It’s important to remain calm and polite in such situations, understanding that the lack of personal space is not a sign of rudeness but rather a cultural norm in crowded urban settings."
  - Location p10===from https://www.learnfrenchwithsonal.com/personal-space-and-touch-in-french-interactions/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In France, it is customary to greet even recently met individuals with "la bise" (a kiss on each cheek), a gesture involving close physical proximity that may seem intrusive in other cultures.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Paradoxically enough, as we’ve seen in the introduction, it is not uncommon in France to “faire la bise” to greet people you just met, whereas it is perceived as very personal contact in the United States because of the physical proximity that this gesture implies."
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://blogs.dickinson.edu/toulouse/2018/11/07/how-is-the-concept-of-personal-space-different-between-france-and-the-united-states/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French homes are considered intimate and private spaces, typically accessible only to close friends or family, reflecting a cultural value of privacy and selectivity in personal relationships.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The French regard the home as an intimate, personal space which only close friends or family usually have the invitation to see inside."
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://blogs.dickinson.edu/toulouse/2018/11/07/how-is-the-concept-of-personal-space-different-between-france-and-the-united-states/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: French buildings commonly use shutters, gates, walls, or hedges to block outside views and enhance security, demonstrating a cultural emphasis on protecting the privacy of private spaces.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "One can observe simply by walking down a typical Toulouse street that most houses also have a gate, a wall, or tall hedges surrounding the house to block the view from the street. This adds another layer of security as well as personal privacy, which the French cherish."
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://blogs.dickinson.edu/toulouse/2018/11/07/how-is-the-concept-of-personal-space-different-between-france-and-the-united-states/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The French tend to be selective about who they invite into their homes and how often, unlike some American social practices where gathering at home is more common and casual.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The French enjoy sleepovers and lazy hangouts too, but tend to be more selective with who they let into their homes and how frequently."
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://blogs.dickinson.edu/toulouse/2018/11/07/how-is-the-concept-of-personal-space-different-between-france-and-the-united-states/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The appropriate personal space in France is an arm's length or slightly closer.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "An arm's length distance or a bit closer is an appropriate amount of personal space."
  - Location paragraph 1===from https://guide.culturecrossing.net/basics_business_student_details.php?Id=9&CID=71

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The French are generally more comfortable with reduced personal space because of their customary close greetings involving kisses.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Given the close nature of the French greeting with kisses, the French are generally more at ease maintaining personal space."
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://guide.culturecrossing.net/basics_business_student_details.php?Id=9&CID=71

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: While the French may appear reserved at first, they may touch during conversations in later meetings, which is seen as a sign of affection.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The French may seem reserved upon first meeting. However, during subsequent meetings, touching during a conversation is acceptable and considered a sign of affection."
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://guide.culturecrossing.net/basics_business_student_details.php?Id=9&CID=71

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Among French men, the double kiss on the cheeks is a gesture reserved for family and very close friends, signifying deep acceptance and belonging.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "among French men, this is reserved for family and the closest friends."
  - Location p1===from https://expatsplanet.com/are-you-too-close-5-surprising-truths-about-personal-space-around-the-world/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Receiving the double cheek kiss from a French male friend indicates that the person is considered part of the inner circle, reflecting strong social inclusion.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "It was a huge honor, a way of saying, 'You’re one of us.'"
  - Location p1===from https://expatsplanet.com/are-you-too-close-5-surprising-truths-about-personal-space-around-the-world/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Pinching the fingers and thumb together to resemble a bird’s beak and moving it up and down is used to emphasize that someone is talking excessively.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Fingers and thumb pinched together, resembling a bird’s beak, moving up and down."
  - Location p2===from https://www.learnfrenchwithsonal.com/a-quick-guide-to-hand-gestures-and-their-significance-in-french-culture/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: A quick downward-palm hand flick conveys indifference or dismissal, similar to saying “whatever” or “I don’t care.”
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "A quick flick of the hand, palm facing downwards."
  - Location p3===from https://www.learnfrenchwithsonal.com/a-quick-guide-to-hand-gestures-and-their-significance-in-french-culture/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Crossing the index and middle fingers expresses hope or a wish for good luck, consistent with its meaning in other cultures.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Crossing your index and middle fingers."
  - Location p4===from https://www.learnfrenchwithsonal.com/a-quick-guide-to-hand-gestures-and-their-significance-in-french-culture/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Raising the thumb with other fingers closed signifies approval or agreement and can also be used for hitchhiking.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Thumbs up, with other fingers closed."
  - Location p5===from https://www.learnfrenchwithsonal.com/a-quick-guide-to-hand-gestures-and-their-significance-in-french-culture/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Flicking the hand outward from under the chin is a rude gesture indicating “I don’t care” or “Get lost.”
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Flicking your hand outward from under your chin."
  - Location p6===from https://www.learnfrenchwithsonal.com/a-quick-guide-to-hand-gestures-and-their-significance-in-french-culture/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Pointing at each finger as if counting is commonly used when listing points or enumerating items in conversation.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Pointing at each finger as if counting on your hand."
  - Location p7===from https://www.learnfrenchwithsonal.com/a-quick-guide-to-hand-gestures-and-their-significance-in-french-culture/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: To indicate having nothing of something, bite the thumb and flick it outward; this gesture is emphatic and may be considered rude.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "If somebody asks you if you have any sugar, books, money—of any material thing, really—you can say que dalle (absolutely zilch), or you can just bite your thumb and flick it outwards. It’s rather emphatic, and so could be taken as a bit rude."
  - Location p1===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-gestures/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: To express disapproval or disdain, pucker the lips, narrow the eyes, and look bored.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "You can’t have a proper French conversation without being disgusted or disdainful. Pucker your lips, narrow your eyes and look bored."
  - Location p2===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-gestures/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: To indicate someone is drunk, raise a fist in front of the nose and twist it as if revving a motorcycle.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "In France, we can do that too, but the truly French way is to raise your fist in front of your nose and twist it like you’re rev-ing a motorcycle."
  - Location p3===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-gestures/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: To show ignorance or indifference, raise hands to shoulder height.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "To show that you just don’t know (or care), raise your hands to shoulder height."
  - Location p4===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-gestures/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: To express that something is delicious, kiss the fingers, spread them outward, and optionally say “magnifique.”
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Kiss your fingers, spread them outwards, and say magnifique (fabulous)."
  - Location p5===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-gestures/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: To show suspicion or disbelief, place one finger on the lower eyelid and pull it down slightly.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "To show that you’re suspicious or that you think that the person you are addressing may be lying, put one finger on your eyelid and pull it down a little bit."
  - Location p6===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-gestures/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: To indicate cleverness or intuition about something, tap one side of the nose with the index finger.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Tap one side of your nose with your index finger, and then brag about whatever you think you have a flair for."
  - Location p7===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-gestures/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: To signal imminent danger or trouble, hold a bent arm in front of the chest with palm facing inward, fingers apart, and shake the hand while saying “aïe, aïe, aïe.”
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Hold your arm bent in front of you with your palm just in front of and facing your chest. Keep your fingers apart, and shake your hand, saying aïe, aïe, aïe, aïe, aïe!"
  - Location p8===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-gestures/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: To indicate someone is annoying or boring, stroke the jowls with the back of the fingers, often accompanying the phrase “quelle barbe.”
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "To show that someone is annoying or boring, you can say quelle barbe (what a beard) and stroke your jowls with the back of your fingers."
  - Location p9===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-gestures/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: To signal it’s time to leave, slap the back of one hand with the other, or alternatively knock wrists or chop hand sides together.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "To do it, slap the back of one hand with the other hand. You’ll also see people hit the back of their hands, knock their wrists together, or chop the sides of their hands together."
  - Location p10===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-gestures/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: To indicate someone is crazy, either tap the side of the head or touch the side of the head with the index finger and twist it as if screwing out the brain.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "To do it, you should tap the side of your head to indicate that someone is nuts... Or—and this is the funner version—you can touch the side of your head with your index finger and twist, like you’re screwing out your brains."
  - Location p11===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-gestures/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: To express being fed up or done with something, swipe a hand horizontally over the head, optionally joining thumb and index finger during the motion.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "When this feeling of annoyance strikes, use this handy gesture, where you swipe your hand horizontally over your head. Another version is to join your thumb and index finger as you make the same swiping motion over your head."
  - Location p12===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-gestures/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: To indicate understanding or acknowledgment, tap the side of the nose with the index finger.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "To make it, simply tap on the side of your nose with your index finger."
  - Location p13===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-gestures/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: To express excitement or optimism about something, rub the palms of both hands together.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Simply rub together the palms of your two hands."
  - Location p14===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-gestures/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: To indicate something is not one’s responsibility, raise hands above shoulder height with palms facing outward.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "To make this one, hold your hands up just above shoulder height, with your palms facing out toward the person."
  - Location p15===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-gestures/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: To tell someone to go away angrily, extend the arm with a fist (palm up), then jerk it upward while slapping the upper arm with the other hand.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "To make this gesture, hold your arm out with your hand in a fist, palm up. Then pull it up in a sudden jerk while slapping your upper arm with your other hand."
  - Location p16===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-gestures/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: To indicate something is expensive or fancy, hold the hand up with fingers up and rub the thumb and fingers together.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "To make this one, hold your hand up, fingers up, and rub your thumb and fingers together."
  - Location p17===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-gestures/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: To express something is cool or impressive, or to mock someone as pretentious, hold the hand at chest height with fingers downward and shake it as if waking up a numb hand.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "To make this one, hold your hand at chest height, fingers downward, and shake your hand like you’re trying to wake up a numb hand."
  - Location p18===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-gestures/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: A subtle shoulder lift accompanied by a sigh or pout is used to express indifference, doubt, or lack of concern about a situation.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The 'Bof' Gallic Shrug is when someone slightly lifts one or both shoulders with a faint sigh or pout."
  - Location p1

- Rule Description This gesture conveys attitudes such as “Whatever”, "not my fault", or "so what?" and reflects emotional detachment from the issue at hand.
- ===from https://blablafrancais.com/12-typically-french-gestures-you-really-need-to-know-not-found-at-home/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Puffing cheeks and blowing air through tightened lips to create a soft sound expresses indifference, confusion, or not being bothered by something.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "French people will often puf up their cheeks and blow out air through their tightened lips, creating a soft, fart-like sound. This is commonly used to express indifference, cluelessness, or that you’re not bothered by something."
  - Location p2===from https://blablafrancais.com/12-typically-french-gestures-you-really-need-to-know-not-found-at-home/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Mimicking shaving by rubbing a loose fist against the cheek indicates boredom or annoyance with someone or something, equivalent to saying "c'est chiant".
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The 'What a drag!' hand gesture involves making a loose fist and pretending to rub the top of it against your cheek, like you're mimicking the act of shaving. It means 'c'est chiant', expressing boredom with someone or something."
  - Location p3===from https://blablafrancais.com/12-typically-french-gestures-you-really-need-to-know-not-found-at-home/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Pulling down the lower eyelid with the index finger signals disbelief or skepticism, often accompanying the phrase "mon oeil!" to sarcastically reject a claim.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "This gesture involves using your index finger to slightly pull down the bottom lid of one eye. It's used to express disbelief or skepticism, like saying, 'Yeah, right!' sarcastically. It usually goes with the person saying 'mon oeil!' ('my foot' in U.S talk)."
  - Location p4===from https://blablafrancais.com/12-typically-french-gestures-you-really-need-to-know-not-found-at-home/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Sweeping the hand over the top of the head communicates that one has reached their limit due to frustration or annoyance, often paired with the phrase "Ras le bol!".
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "You sweep your hand over the top of your head to signal that you've had enough, that you're completely fed up or done with a situation. It usually goes with the sentence 'Ras le bol!' (fed up)."
  - Location p5===from https://blablafrancais.com/12-typically-french-gestures-you-really-need-to-know-not-found-at-home/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Holding the hand palm-down and twisting it side to side slightly indicates that something is somewhat, just a little bit, or only moderately the case.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "This French gesture involves holding your hand palm down, slightly opened, and twisting it side to side in a small motion. It’s used to indicate that something is just a little bit or somewhat, like when you’re saying something is just okay or slightly off."
  - Location p6===from https://blablafrancais.com/12-typically-french-gestures-you-really-need-to-know-not-found-at-home/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Shaking a loosely held hand at the wrist while raising it in front of the shoulder expresses surprise, shock, or exaggerated disbelief, often accompanied by saying "Oh la la!".
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "This one involves raising your hand in front of your shoulder with your elbow slightly out, and shaking your hand loosely at the wrist while saying 'Oh la la!' It’s used to express surprise, shock, or sometimes disbelief, often in an exaggerated way."
  - Location p7===from https://blablafrancais.com/12-typically-french-gestures-you-really-need-to-know-not-found-at-home/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Twisting a fist back and forth near the nose suggests that someone is drunk or tipsy, referencing the expression "Avoir un coup dans le nez".
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "This gesture is done by making a fist and twisting it back and forth near your nose, as if you're screwing something in and out. It’s used to suggest that someone is drunk or tipsy - the French expression is 'Avoir un coup dans le nez' (litterally being hit in the nose)."
  - Location p8===from https://blablafrancais.com/12-typically-french-gestures-you-really-need-to-know-not-found-at-home/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Lightly touching cheeks and making a kissing sound, typically on both sides, serves as a common greeting among friends, family, and sometimes new acquaintances.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "It involves lightly touching cheeks with someone and making a soft kissing sound, often on both sides. It’s a common greeting in France, used among friends, family, and sometimes even new acquaintances."
  - Location p9===from https://blablafrancais.com/12-typically-french-gestures-you-really-need-to-know-not-found-at-home/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Flicking the thumb upward with a slight wrist motion is a casual way to indicate agreement or approval, meaning "It’s all good" or "That works".
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The 'ça marche!' gesture involves flicking your thumb upward, usually with a slight wrist up and down motion. It’s a quick way to say 'It’s all good' or 'That works' in a casual setting."
  - Location p10===from https://blablafrancais.com/12-typically-french-gestures-you-really-need-to-know-not-found-at-home/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Rubbing palms together shows eager anticipation for something positive, such as good food, financial gain, or an exciting event.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "This one involves rubbing your palms together in anticipation, as if you’re getting ready for something exciting. It’s used when you’re eagerly expecting something great, like a delicious meal, making good money, or any exciting event."
  - Location p11===from https://blablafrancais.com/12-typically-french-gestures-you-really-need-to-know-not-found-at-home/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Kissing the fingertips and then spreading them outward is a gesture used to emphasize that something, especially food, is delicious.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "This gesture is done by bringing your fingers together, kissing the tips, and then spreading them away and outward, as if releasing the kiss into the air. It’s used to show that something, usually food, is absolutely delicious."
  - Location p12===from https://blablafrancais.com/12-typically-french-gestures-you-really-need-to-know-not-found-at-home/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In French culture, beckoning involves using a hand gesture or head movement to silently call someone to come closer.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Matilda tried to beckon to her husband, who was standing on the other side of the room."  
  - Location p1===from https://www.wordreference.com/enfr/beckoning

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: A tilt of the head can be used to beckon someone, serving as a nonverbal summons.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Seb beckoned me with a tilt of his head."  
  - Location p1===from https://www.wordreference.com/enfr/beckoning

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In French context, beckoning can signal someone to perform a specific task, such as bringing something.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The king beckoned his servant to bring him a drink."  
  - Location p1===from https://www.wordreference.com/enfr/beckoning

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The French tend to maintain longer eye contact during conversations compared to North Americans, using it to show engagement rather than aggression.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Compared to North Americans, the French tend to hold eye contact longer during conversations. They’re not being aggressive—they’re showing engagement."  
  - Location paragraph 13===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/8/23/french-eye-contact-how-much-is-too-much

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In France, direct eye contact without a smile is common and does not indicate unfriendliness, especially with strangers.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Americans often pair eye contact with frequent smiling. The French smile less reflexively, especially with strangers. A direct look without a smile doesn’t mean someone is unfriendly—it’s normal."  
  - Location paragraph 14===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/8/23/french-eye-contact-how-much-is-too-much

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Looking someone in the eyes in France signals that you are paying attention, being honest, and establishing connection.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Shows you’re paying attention... Signals honesty... Establishes connection"  
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/8/23/french-eye-contact-how-much-is-too-much

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Not making eye contact may be interpreted as disinterest, secrecy, or rudeness in French interactions.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Avoiding eye contact may look like disinterest or boredom."  
  - Location paragraph 6  
  - Quoted text "Don’t avoid eye contact completely. This might seem suspicious or rude."  
  - Location paragraph 24===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/8/23/french-eye-contact-how-much-is-too-much

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Staring fixedly without blinking can be perceived as aggressive, while prolonged eye contact may be misinterpreted as flirtation depending on context.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Don’t stare fixedly without blinking. It can be interpreted as aggression."  
  - Location paragraph 23  
  - Quoted text "Too much, and you might be seen as rude—or, worse, flirtatious."  
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/8/23/french-eye-contact-how-much-is-too-much

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It is normal and appropriate to briefly break eye contact during conversation by glancing away, which helps keep the interaction natural.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "French speakers often intersperse eye contact with small looks away—to their coffee cup, to the side, to their notepad. It keeps things natural."  
  - Location paragraph 19===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/8/23/french-eye-contact-how-much-is-too-much

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In business contexts, maintaining strong eye contact demonstrates confidence and competence.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Strong eye contact projects confidence and competence."  
  - Location paragraph 27===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/8/23/french-eye-contact-how-much-is-too-much

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In arguments or debates, sustained eye contact is common and indicates conviction and active participation, not hostility.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "A debate might involve Strong eye contact... This doesn’t necessarily mean anger. Passionate discourse is part of French culture."  
  - Location paragraph 21  
  - Quoted text "Do maintain stronger eye contact when debating. This signals that you’re engaged and confident."  
  - Location paragraph 25===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/8/23/french-eye-contact-how-much-is-too-much

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: When entering shops or markets, it is polite to make brief eye contact while saying “Bonjour.”
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Always greet the shopkeeper with a brief look and 'Bonjour.'"  
  - Location paragraph 30  
  - Quoted text "A brief but direct look plus 'Bonjour' is polite."  
  - Location paragraph 38===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/8/23/french-eye-contact-how-much-is-too-much

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Whether eye contact is considered flirting depends on context; a lingering gaze with a smile may be flirtatious, but a neutral gaze usually indicates attentiveness.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "A prolonged gaze in a café, paired with a smile → possibly flirtatious. A direct, neutral gaze during conversation → usually just attentiveness."  
  - Location paragraph 29  
  - Quoted text "Don’t assume eye contact equals romantic interest. Context matters."  
  - Location paragraph 31===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/8/23/french-eye-contact-how-much-is-too-much

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Parisians tend to have more direct eye contact compared to people in provincial areas, where softer eye contact may be preferred.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Parisians may be more direct in their gaze than people in the provinces, who sometimes prefer softer eye contact."  
  - Location paragraph 35===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/8/23/french-eye-contact-how-much-is-too-much

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Younger French individuals are generally more comfortable with intense eye contact, while older generations may view prolonged eye contact with strangers as inappropriate.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Younger French people are often more relaxed about intense eye contact. Older generations might consider very prolonged eye contact with strangers inappropriate."  
  - Location paragraph 34===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/8/23/french-eye-contact-how-much-is-too-much

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Women may use shorter eye contact in some situations, particularly with strangers, to avoid misinterpretation.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Women might keep eye contact shorter in some settings, particularly with strangers, to avoid misinterpretation."  
  - Location paragraph 33===from https://www.polyglottistlanguageacademy.com/language-culture-travelling-blog/2025/8/23/french-eye-contact-how-much-is-too-much

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In French culture, direct eye contact is valued as a sign of attentiveness, confidence, and sincerity during conversations.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The French value direct eye contact as a sign of attentiveness and engagement in conversations."  
  - Location p2===from https://www.learnfrenchwithsonal.com/eye-contact-and-facial-expressions/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In informal settings, regular but not overly intense eye contact shows interest and engagement; natural shifts away from direct gaze are appropriate to avoid appearing intrusive.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "While direct eye contact is encouraged, it should not be overly intense or prolonged, as this might come across as intrusive or confrontational. A natural balance of looking at the person and occasionally glancing away is generally ideal."  
  - Location p3===from https://www.learnfrenchwithsonal.com/eye-contact-and-facial-expressions/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In formal or professional contexts, eye contact should be steady and measured to convey confidence, honesty, and focus without making others uncomfortable.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "In professional or formal settings, eye contact is equally important but is often more controlled and measured. It’s used to convey confidence, honesty, and professionalism."  
  - Location p4===from https://www.learnfrenchwithsonal.com/eye-contact-and-facial-expressions/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: During meetings, presentations, or interviews, maintaining eye contact demonstrates seriousness and active involvement in the discussion.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "During meetings or presentations, maintaining steady eye contact with your audience or conversation partner demonstrates that you are serious and focused on the matter at hand."  
  - Location p5===from https://www.learnfrenchwithsonal.com/eye-contact-and-facial-expressions/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In romantic situations, prolonged eye contact can signal attraction or affection and help create intimacy, but must be adjusted based on the other person’s comfort level.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "In romantic contexts, eye contact takes on a more intimate role. Prolonged eye contact can be a sign of attraction, interest, or affection, and it’s often used to create a deeper connection between partners."  
  - Location p6===from https://www.learnfrenchwithsonal.com/eye-contact-and-facial-expressions/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Maintaining direct eye contact during communication is considered respectful in French culture.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Direct eye contact is understood as a form of respect."
  - Location paragraph 1===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-communication

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Failing to make and sustain eye contact is viewed as highly impolite in French cultural interactions.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "It is considered to be extremely rude not to make and maintain eye contact."
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-communication

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Parisians generally avoid making eye contact with strangers, as it is considered slightly offensive and a violation of personal space.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "As a general rule, you have to avoid looking strangers in the eye; it’s slightly offensive. Remember, personal space reigns."
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://vingtparis.com/unspoken-rules-of-paris/unspoken-rules-of-paris-casual-eye-contact/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: If eye contact occurs more than once at a social gathering where alcohol is present, it is expected that one must follow up by introducing oneself; otherwise, the other person may perceive the behavior as strange or inappropriate.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "If you make eye contact with the same person more than once you have to commit to it. Go up to him/her and introduce yourself. If not, said person will think that you are weird."
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://vingtparis.com/unspoken-rules-of-paris/unspoken-rules-of-paris-casual-eye-contact/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: If someone else initiates eye contact (such as on the metro), it is acceptable to look back once, but further interaction depends on mutual cues and subtle actions.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "If ever the eye contact is initiated by the other person e.g. that cute one in the metro, then you are given a laissez-passer. You get to look back once."
  - Location paragraph 8===from https://vingtparis.com/unspoken-rules-of-paris/unspoken-rules-of-paris-casual-eye-contact/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: After mutual eye contact on public transit, one may initiate conversation with a discreet, open-ended question about the metro or next station, avoiding appearing like a tourist.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Ask a question concerning the metro or the next station. You don’t want it to be too obvious because one never wants to appear a Tourist. At the same time, it has to be something that is not answered by a simple yes or no."
  - Location paragraph 8===from https://vingtparis.com/unspoken-rules-of-paris/unspoken-rules-of-paris-casual-eye-contact/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: One should avoid eye contact with homeless individuals, petty criminals, scammers, metro performers, beggars, or aggressively dressed individuals, as such contact may lead to unwanted demands for money or provoke conflict.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "There is one type of person you definitely don’t want to make eye contact with... Most will detect the eye contact automatically and then ask you for money... These last won’t ask for money, they will pick a fight."
  - Location paragraph 9===from https://vingtparis.com/unspoken-rules-of-paris/unspoken-rules-of-paris-casual-eye-contact/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: It is culturally acceptable to use exaggerated bodily imagery to express that something is extremely expensive.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "Coûter les yeux de la tête literally means that something costs the eyes of the head—it’s a price that’s unreasonable."  
  - Location paragraph 1===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-idioms/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Describing someone as drinking like a hole indicates excessive drinking, and such vivid metaphors are commonly used in French to criticize or comment on behavior.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "When you say that someone drinks like a hole, it means that they never stop, even if they should."  
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-idioms/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Using expressions related to physical inability (like not knowing what to do with one’s ten fingers) is a recognized way to convey that someone is useless.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "Ne rien savoir faire de ses dix doigts means that somebody is completely useless."  
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-idioms/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Arriving at an awkward moment is culturally expressed using food-related metaphors, indicating disapproval through imagery of contamination.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "Arriver comme un cheveu sur la soupe refers to entering a situation at the most awkward moment possible."  
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-idioms/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Offering unsolicited opinions is metaphorically described as adding salt, reflecting a cultural recognition of intrusive input in conversations.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "Mettre son grain de sel means to give someone an unsolicited and unnecessary opinion."  
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-idioms/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Sleeping in is culturally acknowledged and humorously referred to as having a “fat morning,” showing acceptance of leisurely mornings.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "Faire la grasse matinée means to sleep in."  
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-idioms/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Love at first sight is culturally framed using natural phenomena (a lightning strike), indicating strong emotional immediacy.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "Coup de foudre literally translates to a strike of lightning, but actually refers to love at first sight."  
  - Location paragraph 8===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-idioms/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Speaking bluntly or honestly is culturally valued and expressed as calling a cat a cat, equivalent to calling things by their true name.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "Appeler un chat un chat is the equivalent of telling it like it is, or calling a spade a spade in English."  
  - Location paragraph 9===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-idioms/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Opinions can be softened by disclaiming responsibility, using phrases that allow indirect expression without full commitment.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "You would use this expression when giving your opinion but wanting to soften the blow a bit, or not assume total responsibility for it."  
  - Location paragraph 10===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-idioms/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Standing someone up is expressed using animal-based idioms, reflecting a humorous or dismissive cultural attitude toward broken plans.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "This French expression sounds as silly as its English equivalent—to stand somebody up or to not show up for something that you’ve planned."  
  - Location paragraph 11===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-idioms/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Abruptly changing topics in conversation is culturally recognized and humorously described as jumping from rooster to donkey.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "Sauter du coq à l’âne means to jump from topic to topic in conversation."  
  - Location paragraph 13===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-idioms/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Being mentally disoriented or crazy is expressed using directional metaphors, indicating a cultural association between west and confusion.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "Être à l’ouest refers to being completely crazy or out of it."  
  - Location paragraph 14===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-idioms/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Anger is described using sensory metaphors involving mustard rising to the nose, showing a bodily connection to emotion.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "La moutarde me monte au nez means that you’re getting angry."  
  - Location paragraph 15===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-idioms/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Interfering in others' affairs is described as bringing one’s strawberry, reflecting a cultural tendency to use food metaphors for social behavior.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "This is the French version of 'to stick your nose into something,' although it can also be used to invite someone to approach."  
  - Location paragraph 16===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-idioms/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Becoming arrogant is described as taking the melon, using fruit imagery to denote inflated ego.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "This one means 'to be big-headed.'"  
  - Location paragraph 17===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-idioms/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Telling someone to leave you alone is expressed as letting go of the bunch, using agricultural imagery for personal space.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "This is what someone might tell you if you won’t stop bothering them. 'Let go of my bunches!' or less literally, 'Leave me alone!'"  
  - Location paragraph 18===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-idioms/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Being disregarded is expressed as counting for plums, indicating cultural use of fruit to represent insignificance.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "I don’t know if the French have a particular reason to dislike plums, but this idiom translates as 'to count for nothing.'"  
  - Location paragraph 19===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-idioms/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Success or profitability is described as bearing fruit, aligning with common metaphorical use of agriculture for outcomes.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "It is used when saying that something is becoming profitable, giving good results."  
  - Location paragraph 20===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-idioms/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Blushing from shame is described as being red like a tomato, showing use of food to express emotional states.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "Feeling ashamed? Then this is the idiom you are looking for! 'To be red like a tomato.' Pretty self-explanatory."  
  - Location paragraph 21===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-idioms/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Being broke is expressed as not having a radish, using vegetable scarcity to denote poverty.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "Probably not something you’d like to say very often, this phrase means 'to be dead broke.'"  
  - Location paragraph 22===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-idioms/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Worrying excessively is described as taking the cabbage, using food to represent mental burden.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "This idiom refers to getting worried about something or overly complicating things."  
  - Location paragraph 23===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-idioms/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: When a situation is hopeless, it is said that the carrots are cooked, using food preparation to signify finality.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "This is the kind of idiom you’ll use when there’s no hope left. When there’s nothing else you can do about a certain situation, when 'the carrots are already cooked.'"  
  - Location paragraph 24===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-idioms/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Improving financial status is described as putting butter on spinach, reflecting a culinary metaphor for economic betterment.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "It’s frequently used to express the fact of needing to improve one’s financial situation or income."  
  - Location paragraph 25===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-idioms/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Talking nonsense is described as telling salads, using food to denote falsehood or absurdity.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "This phrase simply means to talk nonsense, or 'dire n’importe quoi' which is literally 'say whatever.'"  
  - Location paragraph 26===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-idioms/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Having a problem is described as having a pip, using small fruit seeds to represent minor issues.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "It means to have a problem, something that is not going as expected, an issue, a glitch."  
  - Location paragraph 27===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-idioms/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Being unintelligent is described as having a chickpea in the head, using small legumes to mock lack of wit.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "This is the French equivalent to 'have a pea-brain.'"  
  - Location paragraph 28===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-idioms/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Being wealthy is described as having wheat, linking agricultural abundance with financial success.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "This one literally means 'to have wheat,' but actually is saying that you are very wealthy."  
  - Location paragraph 29===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-idioms/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Overestimating one’s capacity (especially appetite) is described as having eyes bigger than the stomach, reflecting self-awareness of greed or overcommitment.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "This means 'to have eyes bigger than your stomach,' which is a pretty common idiom in French and English."  
  - Location paragraph 30===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-idioms/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Risk diversification is advised using the metaphor of not putting all eggs in one basket, showing shared wisdom with other cultures.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "This is another idiom that will be very familiar. It means 'don’t put all of your eggs in the same basket.'"  
  - Location paragraph 31===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-idioms/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Something easy is described as being a piece of cake, indicating cross-cultural use of dessert metaphors for simplicity.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "This one is the same in English as it is in French 'a piece of cake!'"  
  - Location paragraph 32===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-idioms/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Delayed action is accepted as better than none, reflecting a pragmatic cultural attitude toward timing.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "This is probably a favorite phrase of yours if you are a procrastinator. It means 'better late than never.'"  
  - Location paragraph 33===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-idioms/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Actions are valued more than words, reflecting a cultural preference for demonstration over declaration.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "Most English speakers tend to say 'actions speak louder than words.'"
