Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Those in power often justify their actions regardless of fairness, reflecting injustice due to power imbalances.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "It refers to people who always make excuses for their wrongdoings. This saying is used to express dismay at all kinds of injustice, particularly when there’s a large power differential between opposing forces."
  - Location paragraph 39===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-sayings/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Something that does not last long or quickly ends.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "Making a long fire means something will take a long time, so choosing not to make one implies that little time will be needed."
  - Location paragraph 40===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-sayings/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Misfortunes tend to occur in succession rather than isolation.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "When one bad thing happens, a series of other misfortunes seem to pile up on top of it."
  - Location paragraph 41===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-sayings/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Determination and strong will enable achievement of goals.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "This is the French equivalent of 'Where there’s a will, there’s a way.' It means that you can do anything you put your mind to."
  - Location paragraph 42===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-sayings/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Rumors often contain some element of truth, suggesting caution in dismissing them entirely.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "In every rumor, there seems to be a hint of truth."
  - Location paragraph 43===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-sayings/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Something that is very easy or straightforward to do.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "It’s a piece of cake/easy peasy."
  - Location paragraph 44===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-sayings/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Expressing disbelief or astonishment at something unreasonable or absurd.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "Are you serious? This famous line by French reality star Nabilla has become a cult classic among the youth of France, and is used as a remark of disbelief about something."
  - Location paragraph 45===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-sayings/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Thinking of a witty response too late, after the moment to use it has passed.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "To be unable to think of a witty comeback in time. The French use this saying when someone comes up with a retort or a comeback after the fact, when it’s too late to use it."
  - Location paragraph 46===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-sayings/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Being thoroughly familiar with a routine, person, or situation due to repeated experience.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "To know the score. This phrase is used when you’ve done something so often that you know exactly how it goes."
  - Location paragraph 47===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-sayings/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Dismissing a statement as nonsense or absurdity during disagreements.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "The French use this expression to suggest that what someone else has said in an argument or disagreement is nonsense or b.s."
  - Location paragraph 48===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-sayings/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Experiencing a brief but embarrassing situation.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "A brief, embarrassing experience. This saying refers to an embarrassing (but relatable) experience like tripping over your feet or forgetting someone’s name."
  - Location paragraph 49===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-sayings/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Summarizing or shortening a story or explanation concisely.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "In short or 'yada yada'. This word is used when someone’s trying to cut a long story short and summarize a situation or provide information quickly."
  - Location paragraph 50===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-sayings/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Intense, uncontrollable romantic passion that may dominate or destabilize a relationship.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "Uncontrollable passion. This saying describes a wild and uncontrollable passion that takes over when people fall in love."
  - Location paragraph 51===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-sayings/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Telling someone to mind their own business and refrain from interfering in personal matters.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "Mind your own business. You can also tell someone 'C’est pas tes oignons' which translates to 'It’s not your onions' and means 'It’s none of your business.'"
  - Location paragraph 52===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-sayings/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Experiencing a sudden, irrational urge to engage in dangerous or reckless behavior despite awareness of consequences.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "A sudden urge to do wild or reckless things. This saying describes the sudden inclination to do reckless and dangerous activities like jumping off a mountain despite the deadly consequences."
  - Location paragraph 53===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-sayings/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: False modesty or a sense of guilt-driven behavior that may lead to doing good deeds, though not always sincere.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "False modesty. This phrase can refer to a false sense of modesty, or it can describe a quality that makes you do good things, out of a sort of shame or guilt."
  - Location paragraph 54===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-sayings/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Moving at maximum speed or full force, often in urgency.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "You can use this phrase to say that someone is doing something at full speed or really quickly."
  - Location paragraph 55===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-sayings/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Despite apparent changes, underlying realities remain constant, expressing resignation to enduring patterns.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "Things will never change. This saying expresses a weary acceptance of the way things are."
  - Location paragraph 56===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-sayings/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Completing a task inadequately or with difficulty, yet to the best of one’s ability under the circumstances.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "As best as one could/with difficulty. This phrase is used to describe something that was carried out either partly or moderately successfully and usually with difficulty."
  - Location paragraph 57===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-sayings/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Having a hobby or secondary interest outside one’s main profession or expertise.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "A hobby. C’est mon violon d’Ingres means 'It’s my hobby.' This saying refers to Jean Auguste Dominique Ingres... who was also an exceptionally talented violinist."
  - Location paragraph 58===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-sayings/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Experiencing a midlife crisis, often involving drastic personal changes such as leaving a spouse for a younger partner.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "To have a midlife crisis. This saying is used especially for situations in which someone leaves their spouse for another (often much younger) person."
  - Location paragraph 59===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-sayings/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Assuming that a woman is the root cause of a problem, often in a sexist context.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "The cause of the situation/problem must be a woman. This is a sexist saying... used to insinuate that there must be a woman (a mistress, an angry wife, etc.) who’s at the root of whatever problem is being discussed."
  - Location paragraph 60===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-sayings/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Redirecting conversation back to the original topic when it has strayed.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "Let’s return to the matter at hand/get back on topic. If someone says in a French meeting that they must revenons à nos moutons, it’s a reminder to get back to the matter at hand."
  - Location paragraph 61===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-sayings/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: A situation remains unresolved despite some progress, indicating that challenges continue.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "We’re not out of the woods yet. This saying is used when some progress has been made or an issue has been partially, but not completely, resolved."
  - Location paragraph 62===from https://www.fluentu.com/blog/french/french-sayings/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: French sayings and idioms are short, memorable expressions that convey wisdom or cultural insights, often rooted in everyday life, and are commonly used in conversations to enhance fluency and authenticity.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "French sayings and idioms are short, memorable expressions that convey wisdom or cultural insights. They reflect everyday life, offering phrases like “Vouloir, c’est pouvoir” (Where there’s a will, there’s a way) to “Ce n’est pas la mer à boire” (It’s not a big deal)."
  - Location p2===from https://www.mondly.com/blog/french-sayings-idioms-sound-french-born/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: It is culturally appropriate to advise someone to delay decisions and reflect overnight, as reflected in the saying "La nuit porte conseil," which promotes thoughtful deliberation.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "This is the equivalent of 'sleep on it'. Or, in other words, take your time before making a decision."
  - Location p5===from https://www.mondly.com/blog/french-sayings-idioms-sound-french-born/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: The French cultural attitude emphasizes perseverance and self-belief, as shown in the saying "Impossible n’est pas français," which encourages rejecting the idea of impossibility.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "‘Impossible isn’t French’ is the French equivalent of ‘nothing is impossible’. While it may seem very patriotic, français here doesn’t refer to the French people, but rather to the French language. As in ‘impossible is not a French word’."
  - Location p7===from https://www.mondly.com/blog/french-sayings-idioms-sound-french-born/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: There is a cultural preference for thorough preparation and avoiding reliance on luck, expressed in the saying "Il ne faut rien laisser au hasard" (Nothing should be left to chance).
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "‘Nothing should be left to chance’ or, in other words, plan ahead."
  - Location p8===from https://www.mondly.com/blog/french-sayings-idioms-sound-french-born/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: The French proverb "L’habit ne fait pas le moine" reflects a cultural norm against judging individuals based solely on their outward appearance.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "‘Don’t judge a book by its cover’ or ‘don’t judge a person by their appearance’."
  - Location p9===from https://www.mondly.com/blog/french-sayings-idioms-sound-french-born/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Being late is considered better than not participating at all, as captured in the common saying "Mieux vaut tard que jamais" (Better late than never).
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "‘Better late than never.’ This is another French saying that is also very common in English. You can use it to tell someone that is better to do something late than not to do it at all."
  - Location p10===from https://www.mondly.com/blog/french-sayings-idioms-sound-french-born/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: It is culturally valued to be alone rather than in the company of those who have a negative influence, as expressed in "Mieux vaut être seul que mal accompagné."
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "It’s better to be alone than to be accompanied badly or by someone who isn’t good company. This can apply to all kinds of relationships and even to other unfortunate situations in someone’s life."
  - Location p12===from https://www.mondly.com/blog/french-sayings-idioms-sound-french-born/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: There is a cultural tendency to comfort others during difficult times with the belief that good times follow bad, as reflected in "Après la pluie, le beau temps."
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "This is a way of encouraging someone to ‘hang in there’. Even if things are bad now, everything will eventually get better."
  - Location p13===from https://www.mondly.com/blog/french-sayings-idioms-sound-french-born/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: French culture includes a cautionary awareness that private conversations may be overheard, as indicated by the expression "Les murs ont des oreilles" (The walls have ears).
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "Pay attention to what you say because there’s a chance you could be overheard."
  - Location p14===from https://www.mondly.com/blog/french-sayings-idioms-sound-french-born/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: The cultural value of concluding well despite difficulties is expressed in "Tout est bien qui finit bien," which highlights relief when a situation ends positively.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "The same as its English counterpart, Tout est bien qui finit bien is suitable after a period in which one experiences hardship and struggle."
  - Location p15===from https://www.mondly.com/blog/french-sayings-idioms-sound-french-born/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: The saying "L’appétit vient en mangeant" reflects a cultural understanding that desire or interest grows through participation, whether in eating or other activities.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "Appetite comes with eating.” This expression can be used both literally and figuratively and it refers to how the desire increases as an activity proceeds (to eat, to own, etc.)."
  - Location p16===from https://www.mondly.com/blog/french-sayings-idioms-sound-french-born/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: The French cultural ideal includes enjoying food, laughter, and love, as promoted by the saying "Mangez bien, riez souvent, aimez beaucoup."
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "Eat well, laugh often, love a lot.” “Live life to the fullest” or carpe diem (“seize the day”)."
  - Location p17===from https://www.mondly.com/blog/french-sayings-idioms-sound-french-born/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: It is culturally appropriate to avoid interfering in others’ affairs, as humorously expressed in "S’occuper de ses oignons" (To take care of your own onions).
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "This is a funny way of saying ‘mind your own business’."
  - Location p18===from https://www.mondly.com/blog/french-sayings-idioms-sound-french-born/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Telling falsehoods is culturally discouraged and described vividly using the idiom "Raconter des salades" (To tell salads), meaning to lie.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "‘To tell salads.’ ‘To tell lies’. This is another funny French saying that can also be used when you want to tell someone that everything they think they know is false."
  - Location p19===from https://www.mondly.com/blog/french-sayings-idioms-sound-french-born/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: The expression "Courir sur le haricot" (To run on the bean) indicates that certain behaviors are culturally recognized as irritating or nerve-wracking.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "‘To run on the bean.’ To get on someone’s nerves’."
  - Location p20===from https://www.mondly.com/blog/french-sayings-idioms-sound-french-born/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: There is a cultural emphasis on not wasting life on inferior experiences, exemplified by the saying "La vie est trop courte pour boire du mauvais vin" (Life is too short to drink bad wine).
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "This saying can be used both literally and figuratively. The idea is that life’s too short to do things that you don’t like."
  - Location p21===from https://www.mondly.com/blog/french-sayings-idioms-sound-french-born/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: When two opponents are evenly matched, it is culturally acknowledged through the idiom "À bon chat, bon rat" (To a good cat, a good rat).
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "Equally matched, tit for tat. ... You can use this saying to describe two competitors that improve as they fight against one another or to describe someone meeting an adversary worth his mettle."
  - Location p22===from https://www.mondly.com/blog/french-sayings-idioms-sound-french-born/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: The French saying "Les chiens ne font pas des chats" reflects the cultural belief that children inherit characteristics—positive or negative—from their parents.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "This is another way of saying ‘the apple doesn’t fall far from the tree’ or ‘you inherit the qualities and faults of your parents’."
  - Location p23===from https://www.mondly.com/blog/french-sayings-idioms-sound-french-born/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Situations that are not serious are downplayed using the expression "Il n’y a pas de quoi fouetter un chat," indicating that whipping a cat is unnecessary over small matters.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "‘There’s no reason to whip the cat.’ ‘It’s no big deal’ or ‘it doesn’t matter’."
  - Location p24===from https://www.mondly.com/blog/french-sayings-idioms-sound-french-born/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Failing to appear for a planned meeting is culturally recognized and expressed with the idiom "Poser un lapin" (To place a rabbit), meaning to stand someone up.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "If the person you were supposed to meet doesn’t show up, you can say il m’a posé un lapin (“he stood me up”)."
  - Location p25===from https://www.mondly.com/blog/french-sayings-idioms-sound-french-born/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Unconventional or strange behavior is humorously described as "Avoir une araignée au plafond" (To have a spider on the ceiling), implying someone is a bit crazy.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "If you know someone that ‘has screw loose’ or is a bit crazy, weird, or odd, in French, you can say il a une araignée au plafond (“he is a bit crazy”)."
  - Location p26===from https://www.mondly.com/blog/french-sayings-idioms-sound-french-born/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: The French cultural value prioritizes actual performance over boasting, as illustrated by "Ce n’est pas la vache qui crie le plus fort qui fait le plus de lait" (It’s not the cow that moos the loudest who gives the most milk).
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "Talkers are not always doers. The one who talks the most is not always the smartest or the most resourceful."
  - Location p27===from https://www.mondly.com/blog/french-sayings-idioms-sound-french-born/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: Engaging in long but ineffective tasks is culturally identified as futile, described by the idiom "Peigner la girafe" (To comb the giraffe).
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "‘To comb the giraffe.’ ‘To do unnecessary and very long work, to do nothing effective’. Because why on Earth would you comb a giraffe?"
  - Location p28===from https://www.mondly.com/blog/french-sayings-idioms-sound-french-born/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: This saying is used to describe something that is very easy or straightforward, despite the irony that greeting someone in France can actually be complicated due to social customs.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "This expression is used for anything that is very easy and comes naturally."
  - Location p1===from https://www.babbel.com/en/magazine/the-10-most-useful-french-expressions-for-everyday-life

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: This expression is used when a difficult situation has seen some progress but is far from being resolved, likening the unresolved issue to not having escaped a hostel (historically a euphemism for jail).
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "This phrase is used when you’ve made some progress on a difficult situation, but haven’t quite solved it yet."
  - Location p2===from https://www.babbel.com/en/magazine/the-10-most-useful-french-expressions-for-everyday-life

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: This phrase is used to express trying to outdo someone, originating from a complex and confusing declaration of love.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "Meaning To outdo someone"
  - Location p3===from https://www.babbel.com/en/magazine/the-10-most-useful-french-expressions-for-everyday-life

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: This expression means being in a difficult or messy situation, with a clear origin linked to historical French language development.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "Meaning To get yourself into a mess"
  - Location p4===from https://www.babbel.com/en/magazine/the-10-most-useful-french-expressions-for-everyday-life

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: This saying warns against exaggeration or overreaction, using the metaphor of not pushing one’s grandmother into stinging nettles.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "Meaning One shouldn’t exaggerate"
  - Location p5===from https://www.babbel.com/en/magazine/the-10-most-useful-french-expressions-for-everyday-life

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: This phrase refers to clarifying details or being precise, similar to ensuring accuracy by “dotting your i’s.”
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "Meaning To make things clear"
  - Location p6===from https://www.babbel.com/en/magazine/the-10-most-useful-french-expressions-for-everyday-life

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: This expression describes wasting effort on something futile, such as pursuing affection that goes unnoticed.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "Meaning To waste your efforts"
  - Location p7===from https://www.babbel.com/en/magazine/the-10-most-useful-french-expressions-for-everyday-life

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: This saying is used to indicate that something is unimpressive or ordinary, not remarkable in any way.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "Meaning It’s nothing special"
  - Location p8===from https://www.babbel.com/en/magazine/the-10-most-useful-french-expressions-for-everyday-life

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: This phrase reflects the idea that people interpret situations subjectively based on their own perspective or circumstances.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "Meaning To judge a situation based on your own subjective criteria"
  - Location p9===from https://www.babbel.com/en/magazine/the-10-most-useful-french-expressions-for-everyday-life

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: This expression conveys acting with hope based on luck rather than planning, akin to leaving outcomes to chance.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "Meaning With a bit of luck"
  - Location p10===from https://www.babbel.com/en/magazine/the-10-most-useful-french-expressions-for-everyday-life

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: The French value patience and believe that time will reveal outcomes, so one should accept uncertainty and allow events to unfold naturally.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "It suggests that time will reveal everything, and emphasizes the importance of patience and letting things unfold naturally."
  - Location p2===from https://lingolium.com/glossary/traditional-proverbs-and-sayings-in-french/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: The French caution against forming judgments based solely on outward appearances, as they may be misleading.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "This saying reminds us that appearances can be deceiving. It warns against judging something or someone solely by their outward appearance."
  - Location p3===from https://lingolium.com/glossary/traditional-proverbs-and-sayings-in-french/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: The French acknowledge that individuals perceive situations from their own viewpoints, often disregarding others' perspectives.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "This proverb... illustrates the idea that people will typically see things from their own perspective, often ignoring how others might see the same situation."
  - Location p4===from https://lingolium.com/glossary/traditional-proverbs-and-sayings-in-french/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.feature: The French believe that consistent, small efforts over time lead to significant achievements.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Fixed Expres.original:
- Quoted text "“Little by little, the bird makes its nest” symbolizes that small, consistent efforts lead to big achievements."
  - Location p5===from https://lingolium.com/glossary/traditional-proverbs-and-sayings-in-french/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The French prefer negotiations that use calm, logical, detail-focused presentation rather than confrontational or high-pressure tactics; aggressive bargaining or high-pressure sales tactics are discouraged.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original: - Quoted text The French dislike confrontational behaviour or high-pressure sales tactics. They are more receptive to a low-key, logical presentation that thoroughly explains the advantages of a proposal ===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-business-culture

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Negotiations tend to proceed slowly; decisions are seldom made on the spot during meetings, and formal, precisely worded contracts are used when agreements are reached.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original: - Quoted text When an agreement is reached, your French counterpart may insist the agreement be formalised in an extremely comprehensive, precisely worded contract ===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-business-culture

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Meetings and negotiations follow a formal structure with respect for hierarchy and formal protocol; outcomes are rarely decided in first meeting, implying that bargaining or pressure-based negotiation at first encounter is unlikely.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original: - Quoted text Appointments are necessary and should be made at least two weeks in advance. ===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-business-culture

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The French business culture emphasises formality in introductions, use of titles, protocol in seating and greeting, and a clear separation between personal life and business life — suggesting that informal, aggressive negotiating tactics may be viewed as unprofessional.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original: - Quoted text The order in which people enter a room is based on rank. Wait to be told where to sit, as seating arrangements are in order of ranking. ===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-business-culture

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Business relationships in France are built on trust, respect, and long-term professional relationships — not on aggressive deal-making or quick bargain closing — so business negotiations emphasise respect, courtesy, and formality over haggling.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original: - Quoted text Creating a wide network of close personal business connections is considerably important for the French. They are interested in long-term partnerships that are maintained through regular face-to-face visits ===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/french-culture/french-culture-business-culture

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-mo.feature: According to Hofstede-based reporting, France’s MAS score places it on the feminine side of the dimension — French culture is represented as placing relatively more emphasis on quality of life and caring values than on competitiveness and material success.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-mo.original: - Quoted text France scored 43 in this dimension, suggesting a relatively feminine society where citizens prioritize establishing a quality of life and caring for others.” ===from https://www.tbcculturehub.com/post/unveiling-the-cultural-dimensions-of-france-a-tapestry-of-tradition-and-modernity

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-mo.feature: The country’s MAS score is interpreted in some sources to mean people in France tend to value work as a means to support quality of life (i.e., “work to live”) rather than valuing work above life (i.e., “live to work”).
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-mo.original: - Quoted text France has a score of 43 in masculinity making it a pretty feminine country where people value 'work to live' over 'live to work ===from https://www.proquest.com/openview/21652dfb0e92d2348f933eac447808ec/1?cbl=38637&pq-origsite=gscholar

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-mo.feature: Multiple Hofstede-derived summaries report France’s MAS value (numeric) and explicitly interpret that numeric score as indicating a culture closer to “feminine” than “masculine.” (This is a factual reporting of the measured score and its direct interpretation.)
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-mo.original: - Quoted text France's masculinity is 43 percent. It means the country is closer to a Feminine culture rather than that of a Masculine culture ===from https://www.scienpress.com/Upload/AMAE%2FVol%2013_4_6.pdf

Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-mo.feature: Some summaries based on Hofstede materials report that French society displays variation by social class — e.g., the upper classes show more feminine tendencies while some working-class groups show more masculine tendencies — and this is stated explicitly as an observed pattern.
Values_and_Beliefs-culture dimensions-mo.original: - Quoted text A deeper study conducted by Hofstede Insights found a rather unique characteristic of French culture concerning this cultural dimension. Their research has led them to conclude that the French upper class scores more Feminine while the working class scores more on the Masculine side of the spectrum. ===from https://www.tbcculturehub.com/post/unveiling-the-cultural-dimensions-of-france-a-tapestry-of-tradition-and-modernity
